content:
Posted: November 6, 2016
												If Owlboy had come out during the height of the Genesis/Super Nintnedo days, it would be a game you'd look back on with heartfelt nostalgia, and point to as an example of how good the classics were back then.  How good the stories could be, and how deep you could find yourself falling into them.  How fun they were.  You'd remember how lost you'd get in the world, and its people, and the fantastic music and art.  'They sure don't make them like this anymore,' you would lament.  'That was a great era.'Owlboy is a good few decades late to the Super Nintendo/Genesis days, but it honestly stands toe to toe with the best offerings of that era, and I don't say that lightly.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2016
Product received for free
 Target Audience:    Adventuring OR Platforming Fans Summary:  A solid purchase for those looking for a different “platforming” experience. You were probably drawn to the game due to its striking visuals, and well, it definitely delivers in that area. There's some beautiful environments and some great character designs here, and they all complement some great animation work. That great presentation continues with the music as well, as it perfectly captures the mood of each of the gameplay sections perfectly. And that great presentation ends up complementing a rather solid story, with good set pieces and interesting characters. I loved the world that was built here, even if I wanted to see more of it in the end. There's no performance issues, as the 60 FPS never dropped a single frame, at least from what I saw. As for the gameplay, that's where the game starts to show some more faults, but that's not saying much. The “platforming” here (despite it being a game with flying), is rather solid, as it keeps things fresh by changing its traps and reconfiguring them on a regular basis. The combat controls do work and have a unique feel to them, although the lack of enemy variety in the end does end up hurting the game combat sections overall. When it does change up this combat sections, it definitely works, but I wish it did it more often. But the unique feel of the game still carries this game to a solid recommendation. Video Review:  


YouTube™ Video: Owlboy (Review): Boy, what a Hoot! 

			Views: 4,041		

			Should you give a Hoot about this adventure game? This key was obtained from the developer for review purposes. Owlboy went through a long development process to finally come to the various PC store...		

 Lists: Positives: Strong visual artstyle that's backed up with great animation. It reminds me of the 16 bit era, but it also feels like an upgraded version of it in the process. The devil can be in the details, but Owlboy has the details to make it look great in almost every situation.  Story telling is strong. Great Story set pieces that keep you interested in the plot as it develops. In addition, the game keeps a great storytelling pace without any filler content.  Strong “platforming” variety. Game does a good job of introducing new traps and changing up the configuration of already introduced mechanics to help keep things fresh.  Fun characters that make you want to see more of their world.  Like the “weapon” mechanic. Switching between characters, and having the center of the shot gravity be at a different angle from normal: really does help make the game stand out.  Controls are exactly where they need to be for the gameplay in question. Both the keyboard and the controller work here thanks to the game design in question.  If you were concerned about performance, well, don't be. 60 FPS is what you'll get. There was not a frame drop that I could see.  Some of the boss battles are rather cool, like riding a giant rock worm around. Like the final boss battle of the game, as it felt like a little bit of a different twist on the “weak point” formula.  The music is high quality. A good selection that captures the appropriate emotions and feel of each stage in question, and it'll be something that you'll want in your library to listen to time and time again. Can get lost in it. This is a good difficulty in terms of hitting a flexible enough game to be beatable my a majority of people, without it feeling like a horrible waste of time for others. While yes, as I elude to in the negatives, I wanted a bit more difficulty, it feels right for its projected audience. Reasonable options from an indie game, at least in my opinion.Negatives: The combat's difficulty is not where I'd want it to be at several points. This game is a lot about pattern recognition, but unlike Mega Man or Shovel Knight, the precision needed to counter those patterns is rather of a low skill ceiling. Enemy Variety could use an improvement. You can get lost in the game rather easily, and the game doesn't have an in game map for you to easily reference. A simple map would have fixed this, or at least pointing to the direction you needed to go.  Character building can feel off at times, as it seems to miss a step here and there in the natural progression. Some situations can make you feel like you've been backed into a corner, and mostly due to some game design elements. This is rare, but it feels like the game is inflexible for certain situations (changing screens in particular).  In the end, I want a little bit more content out of the game. The game delivers, but with some of the strong world building, I wanted some more side elements for the game.

												I personally had a  great time playing this game. Not going to lie at first i was skeptical about getting it because the price SEEEMED high.  After thinking about it alittle i realized that i've paid more for games that gave way less gameplay or overall lost interest very very quickly.First off if your going to make a big stink over $25 / $22.5 then simply add it to your wishlist, wait for a sale if you must and be done with it. There is no need to cry and moan about a price that was given. There really is no need for that in the forums or comments. A minimum of 10 hours of fun for $25 is pretty damn good if you ask me.After beating the game i can say though that i wish there was more to the ending. The game had it's moment's where it was pretty easy with little to no challenge of progressing. But the further into the story i got, i had quite a few moments where i was getting frustrated at certain bosses and/or areas (Beware of the monkeys!!!!!). The end game boss wasn't as tough as i thought it would be. One of the only bosses that really urked me was a particular monkey.... lots of dying i did. In any case this game genuinely made me feel happy when playing. Enjoyed just flying around mindlessly roaming, enjoying the music. Every time i got off the game to take a little break, i couldn't wait to get back on it. I have my fingers crossed that some DLC of some sort is released for this in the future. Would of been nice to have another character to play as haha. "Owlgirl" maybe? ^^ I loved every moment of the game.... i don't see what's not to love. If your considering it, just go for it and buy it. I don't regret getting this game at all. If your second guessing and don't think it's worth it for the price then you don't know what your missing, then again christmas is coming soon. You could add it to your x-mas wishlist and hope someone awesome gets it for you. 9/109 Because i wish it didn't end! Loved it so much! but honestly it's a 10 :]

content:
Posted: November 30, 2016
												Note: I have played with patience and attention (stopping to explore the world, not speeding though the game, etc.) and for longer than is recorded here for some unknown reason (circa 7-10 hours)I'm not trying to dismiss the work that went into this game or the enjoyment that others have clearly got from it - I just want to share my personal experience, which was most surprising to me.I really, really wanted to like this game - it seemed full of things that I love in games (pixel art, focus on storytelling/character, metroidvania-style gameplay, beautiful music, etc.) and it was clearly made with lashings of love and attention to detail.I just found myself not engaging with the story, the action or even the beautiful environment at all. It's hard to say why exactly, but despite really putting an effort into getting involved with the game, I found myself completely detached throughout - from the characters, the atmosphere and especially the gameplay.The game is much more about twin-stick shooter style action than exploration or platforming, and this is made rather frustrating by a character/weapon swapping/picking-up/dropping control system that pretty much leads to a constant stream of redundant button presses every time there is action onscreen. I was playing with an XBox style controller, and I cannot imagine how anyone could even attempt to play through this without a similar gamepad, such is the amount of trigger/stick fumbling involved. It really puts up a wall between the player and Otis.You'll spend most of your time wrestling with this while battling through a series of rather repetitive dungeon areas - the most challenging aspect of which is the sheer patience they demand, with room after room of beautiful-looking but functionally-similar puzzles/obstacles. I found myself battling through the dungeon areas just to finish them, as opposed to seeing what comes next. Also, the frequent interruptions to play (mainly the over-long recovery times when you take damage), the fact that 90% of the meaningful actions you can take are performed by the characters you are clumsily carrying about, and the sterility of the core flying movement made me feel very detached from gameplay. I was, like Otis himself, just drifting across the wonderful landscapes, not really feeling their presence.  I adore Castlevania: SOTN, Cave Story, Knytt, Within a Deep Forest and Treasure Adventure Game - I'm always on the look out for games that evoke this kind of atmosphere + progressive exploration combination. I was disappointed to find myself just going through the motions as I played Owlboy, eventually stopping before I could finish the final section. I'm probably just missing out on something, given the vast numbers of positive reviews, but I was genuinely shocked at the disparity between the scores here on Steam and my own experience of play. I hope this is not discouraging to the developers, who are hopefully enjoying some well-earned praise at the aesthetic beauty of their creation. I just didn't find this game very much fun.

content:
Posted: November 21, 2016
												I will preface this review by saying that Owlboy is, overall, a good game that most people will enjoy. Looking at it objectively, it is at least a solid 6 or 7 out of 10. Those who value art and are able to get into the story are likely to rate it even higher. This review, however, is here to express the viewpoint of someone who did not particularly enjoy most of the game, and to explain why it might be one to avoid for similarly minded gamers.In a nutshell, there is one thing Owlboy does amazingly, one thing it does atrociously, and a lot of perfectly adequate game in the middle. The pixel art is second to none. The game's lengthy development cycle is evident in every single piece of scenery, every character, every cutscene, and most importantly every gorgeous animation. The artists that worked on this game deserve nothing but praise, as they have managed to achieve something truly beautiful. I have seen a number of people compare this game to Ori and the Blind Forest, and in the art department that comparison is certainly an apt one. Ori may still be the king of gaming visuals overall, but Owlboy steals the crown when it comes to pixel art.Where Owlboy does not compare favourably to something like Ori is in the gameplay, and here comes my greatest nitpick. I say nitpick, because for many people this will likely be much less of a problem than it was for me. If you're a gamer who shares this particular niggle, however, you'll understand immediately how one seemingly small problem can all but ruin an otherwise enjoyable experience:I am not at all exaggerating when I say that I never once played Owlboy for longer than five minutes without the game wresting control away from me. Most of the time the interruptions were far more frequent.Whether it is for a character to deliver a line of dialogue, a cutscene to occur, a door to open, or some other scripted event to play out, Owlboy delights in dragging you out of the moment with constant jarring interruptions that destroy the pacing and flow of the experience. The vast majority of these are completely unnecessary. Even many of the lines of dialogue do not require a pause in the gameplay for them to be delivered. There are moments in the game where characters talk, doors open, and scripted sequences occur *without* taking control away from the player, and they all work perfectly.The most egregious examples of the above are when otherwise intense boss fights are interrupted multiple times for lines of completely unnecessary dialogue to be delivered and phase transitions to occur. I cannot stress enough just how much of a toll this takes on the pacing of the gameplay. Intense moments fall flat, brain-tickling puzzles become annoying, and any section you have to repeat more than once becomes infinitely more tiresome thanks to the arbitrary interruptions. This problem permeates every aspect of Owlboy, dragging the entire experience down and souring a lot of the game's goodness. It's such a shame to see, especially after such a long development cycle, because all of it would have been completely avoidable with more awareness of how to create good pacing in gameplay.Besides the above, most of Owlboy falls into solid "good" territory. There are annoyances here and there, but also plenty of cool moments and clever bits of design to counterbalance them. There's no map or objective indicator, which can at times be a frustration in a metroidvania-esque game like this, but for the most part the levels are elegant and direct enough to avoid too much confusion. The bosses are very fun and satisfying when they aren't interrupted too much, and all of them are unique and memorable. The story is just fine, though nothing to write home about. There's enough emotion and drama to hit plenty of people right in the feels, but in a world where we have games like Undertale or The Walking Dead, the writing ultimately comes across as pretty middle of the road. There's passion and heart in it, however, and while the dramatic beats didn't really have enough substance for me, Owlboy at least puts far more effort into its story than the majority of games out there. The soundtrack similarly hits the correct emotional beats, but none of the tracks ever stuck in my mind for long or made me want to look them up on youtube afterwards.Core gameplay-wise, again, it's just fine. Shooting is fun and punchy. The dash feels good. General movement is okay, but doesn't have much satisfying momentum or weight to it. You don't soar like a bird so much as just drift around the screen. There are a couple of ill-considered platforming segments that do not feel good to play at all, but they're few and far between. Some abilities and their associated controls feel responsive and well-implemented, others are a little finicky. Most of the game's puzzle gimmicks are enjoyable if a little shallow. There's really not a whole lot to talk about in this regard. Owlboy plays just fine. It does what it needs to do. Not great, not bad, just good enough and largely competent.In regards to difficulty, Owlboy is quite forgiving without ever feeling too easy. There's just enough challenge to make beating bosses and clearing areas satisfying. Some bits will be tough for players who are less experienced with the genre, but it's by no means a hardcore game. It hits the middle of the spectrum incredibly well.In summary, I was someone who hoped Owlboy might be a real game of the year candidate for me, in much the same way Ori and the Blind Forest was. Unfortunately, while Owlboy looks every bit the part, it doesn't quite stand up in the gameplay department. The constant interruptions were an ever-present problem, and everything else, while consistently above-average, rarely wowed me in the same way similar titles have. I made sure to finish the game so as to piece together an informed opinion on it, but at times it was something of a slog.If you're not picky about interruptions to gameplay, Owlboy is almost certainly worth the buy. There's a lot of great stuff in there, and if you love good art then it's worth the price tag for that alone. If you're a fan of the gameplay in titles like Ori and the Blind Forest, Shovel Knight or Freedom Planet, however (and if you're keenly aware of *why* their gameplay works so well), Owlboy may be something of a disappointment.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2016
See written review below or watch it here: 


YouTube™ Video: Owlboy - Quick Game Review 

			Views: 1,024		

			Owlboy is a fantastic 2D action adventure that combines flying with platforming in the world floating among the clouds. Written review can be found on my website here:...		

TL;DR: SKIP TO CONCLUSION!Owlboy is a fantastic 2D action adventure that combines flying with platforming in the world floating among the clouds.You play as a mute owl named Otus. Owls are a highly intellectual species, and you are a complete and utter failure in the eyes of your mentor. You’re constantly failing to live up to expectations, and always letting others down. With the imminent threat of pirates attacking, you manage to make a few friends with other misfits that believe in you. Together, you and your friends embark on a grand adventure to try and help save the world. There is a lot of action and combat throughout the game. Combat is interesting, and I like the mechanics. You fly around, spinning and dashing to avoid taking damage. You can pick up objects to throw at enemies, or heal yourself, and you can also carry your friends. While carrying a friend, you gain access to their unique weapon and ability.You switch between your companions to progress through obstacles, and defeat boss encounters. Changing from one companion to another is easy to do, and it’s often very clear which ally you should be using. At first, I was worried that I would have to monitor the ally’s health while in combat, and keep them safe. Fortunately, they can be thrown around and shot at while they aren’t being carried, so you don’t need to micromanage them. While you’re carrying them, you have to be more careful. If you or them get hit, you take damage, suffer a brief daze, and your friend falls to the ground. It’s not too inconvenient to drop your ally though, since you can immediately teleport them back to you with no cooldown on the ability.Pros:great story that's interesting and told well the whole way throughgame mechanics are fun to use, and made for some very enjoyable battlesall of the environments and levels are well designed, and offer good pacing throughout the game for a well-rounded experience; there are some areas where you will need to be quick, other areas where you will need to be stealthy, and then plenty of other places where you can take your timethe high quality pixel animation looks absolutely lovely; adorable characters, and nice environmentsa lot of detail and character development went into each character, giving them their own personality, demeanor, and cute character animations (even though Otus is mute, his expressions are always on point, and you can tell what he’s thinking and how he’s feeling)music and sound effects are done incredibly well throughout the game; the orchestral soundtrack is excellent, and it does a fantastic job of setting the moodcustomizable keybindings & controller supportCons:no cons or things to nitpick about come to mindThe game is open-world. You can venture back and forth between the different areas as you please. There is a fair amount to explore, and you can find hidden treasure if you want to. You collect these coins to obtain items from the shop, some of which increase the size of your health pool.Owlboy took me over 8 hours to complete, and I loved every minute of it. It’s not a game I feel the need to replay, but if I wanted to go back and collect everything, I could load the save right before the final boss.Conclusion:Some people may think that the price is a bit too high. At first I was a bit concerned with the price tag as well, but after finishing my playthrough without a single complaint, I’m completely fine with it. You can tell that a lot of hard work and passion went into creating Owlboy. It’s such a wonderful game, and I thoroughly enjoyed it. I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a well-crafted 2D adventure with unique combat mechanics, charming characters, and an engrossing story. It’s truly an excellent game.If you like my reviews, please feel free to join my Steam group, and follow my curations here.You can also view this review on my website here.[www.azralynn.com]

number of helpful: 49 of 56 people (88%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												I first played this game close to eight years ago as the time of this writing, and when I first tried that demo I got the impression of a good, albeit short, game. That impression was wrong, this is definitely a GREAT game.Owlboy is an adventure in the truest sense of the word. You'll explore, fight baddies, gain powerups, and make friends all throughout a wonderful world and story. The art direction is gorgeous, the animations of the characters and enemies are fun to watch, the music is a treat to listen to, and the story is a great mix of silly fun, abject terror, and heartwrenching moments. When I say that Owlboy is a great game, I mean it.That being said, the game is not without it's faults, by far the biggest being it's difficulty, which is all over the place. You'll breeze through some sections of the game only to be utterly crushed by others. While checkpoints are liberal, you'll be tearing your hair out through some sections of the game trying to figure out what to do, and the lack of difficulty options certainly doesn't help. Exacerbating the issue is that while cutscenes are skippable, some mid boss fight conversations are not, and the aforementioned emotional scenes rapidly lose their luster as your forced to watch them over and over again as you die repeatedly to the more difficult bosses.Also, don't be fooled into thinking this is a metroidvania game. While it is heavily exploration focused, and you can be rewarded for revisiting previously visited areas, the game is actually quite linear, and there isn't much reason to play it multiple times if you aren't going for 100%.Don't let that dissuade you though, Owlboy is a modern day classic, and other indie developers need to look to it as a gold standard for what can be done with both the platforming genre and pixel art. TL:DR Owlboy is a beautiful experience that is both innovative, original, fun, and sets a new gold standard for indie developers that unfortunately marred by some spotty difficulty, but still remains a must own.10/10 would recommend.

												Firstly, I don't think the game is going to be worth $20 for a lot of people that play it. If you are on a tight budget and want to get a lot out of a game, this probably isn't for you unless you're a huge sucker for the art style alone.Gameplay wasn't too strong, but it had some decent parts. Favourite tracks were probably 'mesos' and 'the troublemaker'. 8/10There are some other minor-ish design choices that I was not too keen on, such as lack of maps, the screen was quite claustraphobic at times and I was less inclined to explore everything because I didn't want to waste my time backtracking.Overall, I started out not really liking the game a whole lot, but it kinda won me over by the end. Overall I'd say 75/100.

Posted: November 5, 2016
												Owlboy is a masterpiece of a game that is unfortunately in danger of being severely underated. This game is up there with such indie masterpieces as Shovel Knight and Undertale. The story is fantastic, the emotional moments FEEL emotional and the thrilling moments FEEL thrilling. The fact that a mute protaganist expresses himself moreso than the majority of main protaganists in most modern games is astounding. You are totally emotionally attached to the characters: you want the antagonists to fail and meet their demise whereas you want the protaganists to succeed. If you are skeptical about buying the game, don't be. The price (which, granted is high for an indie game) is justified by the (in my opinion) pracitcally flawless gameplay and story. This game has been totally worth the 9 year wait. 10/10

number of helpful: 133 of 192 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2016
												Owlboy left me wanting more.I was extremely excited to play Owlboy, and was really looking forward to what the game offered after the demo/first area I had seen on previews before.  A game this long in the making that has so much love put into it, with bright art, compelling characters, and good music too?  Sign me up.The game pulled inspiration in its mechanics from many other games I've definitely enjoyed.  It's hard for me to say there's anything "bad" about these elements or their execution.What Owlboy failed to do, for me, was combine the elements to make something unique or interesting, all the while being too short to make use of its by far strongest features; its art, music, and characters.Ultimately, I ended up with a game that felt like I was simply going through the motions.  Everything is serviceable, but nothing grand.Because of this, while I can't call the game bad, I also can't reccommend it if you're looking for the same things I am in a game like this.  I'm a huge player of RPGs, I love metroidvanias, Cave Story and Ori are wonderful action platformers that I can get lost in time and time again, and of course I'm always up for whatever twist Nintendo's been putting on their platformers.  Meawhile, the Ys series of Action/Adventure RPGs really works for combat/bosses even though its stories and characters are rather basic.  I have grander story RPGs to fall back on for a compelling story with developed ensemble casts.  If we want to talk about twinstick action gunning, I'll pull out my Genesis and take out Gunstar Heroes.  Close enough.If you feel you may fall into a similar category, given those quick examples, feel free to read my following thoughts on Owlboy:-The controls work fine, for the most part, as a 360 controller user, but there are times where your hands need to press multiple things at once, and the buttons needed are all over the face of the controller.  Having to keep a thumb on a second analog stick, an index finger on face buttons, and be ready for all shoulder buttons was probably the cause of this for me.  It didn't cause any significant problems, but felt like they could have been better, and more crisp (Compare to something like Ori and the Blind Forest)- The combat is very straightforward and very easy.  Something like Cave Story has much more intense fighting sequences, especially on the boss front.  Look into something like Ys that is straight up -made- for its boss fights, and the combat here pales in comparison.  I found the earlier fights more interesting than the latter ones, but it's still not saying much.- The stealth sequences that augment the combat I personally didn't find enjoyable.  Lots of waiting, and they never really evolved behind "Stay behind cover while enemies move around."  Even with checkpoints after every successful segment, the waiting involved in redoing stealth areas I found tedious.  They were easy, just tedious.- The puzzles are basic at best.  I'd almost argue there's more to puzzles in Namco's Tales Of series, but that's about the quality I got out of Owlboy's.- Exploration is not anywhere near as rewarding as a more common metroidvania.  For one, there's very little of it.  This game's world is -small- and most exploration simply leads to a checklist of coins for a relatively unrewarding upgrade system, and it didn't take much effort at all to get "all those upgrades minus the 100% one."  What exploration did exist didn't really feel like it tested skills so much as it tested ability to poke at every wall.  Missing were sections requiring you to execute some cute little tricks to obtain the reward (Platforming, basically).  Entirely missing are *fun* upgrades scattered throughout the game that increase your ability to navigate or perform.  The upgrades obtained through collecting are more akin to stat bonuses, not really changing how everything is approached.  Given, I didn't get the 100% upgrade, so who knows - maybe it's the most amazing thing.- The dungeons, where you'll spend the vast majority of the time, overstay their welcome a little bit for me, and are quite linear when all is said and done.  I would have preferred dungeons being a bit more compact and getting 1-2 more total areas as a result.- The art in this game is -very- good, the sprites are detailed, emotional, and the backgrounds are pretty full of life and color, given the art direction of the game.  This is one of the game's strong points, for sure.- Likewise, some of the music is fantastic too.  My bigger issue with the music is most of the pieces loved are not heard very often, as the game spends most of its time in dungeons with more of an ambience approach opposed to melodic themes you'd hear in every area of a Metroid, or Castlevania, or Cave Story.- The story and characters are good, but they don't get a time to shine, as everything starts quickly and ends quickly.  These things were very hyped up from many sources, especially considering the main character's status as a literal mute, but ultimately very little was expanded on.  There were many moments of charm, but they passed very quickly, so we could go right back into another linear dungeon.  You may have heard that characters don't do the whole "It's okay, we got this, power of friendship, ACTIVATE!" thing, and the events that happen in the story stick with them.  That's true (to an extent - the friendship-power-buddies thing is still there somewhat), but the weight of the actions upon the characters is never really felt, as there's simply not enough time that passes or dialogue to help facilitate the gravity of everything that's going on.  A short game is not a bad thing, but the other elements must be engaging enough, and in this case, the other aspects of the game simply didn't make up for the lack of time in this story.Owlboy has a few visual moments that are pretty stunning and awesome, but unfortunately it's almost impossible for me not to compare them to Ori's, which I'd say end up superior in both artistic direction and musical composition.  There's certainly one sequence in Owlboy that completely rocks, though.If you've stuck with me, I thank you for your time.At the end of the day, I didn't find myself curious to keep playing, and I just wanted to get it over with so I could see the payoff everyone said I'd get with the characters/story (Again, it ended up serviceable).  The gameplay elements are there, and they work, but I've played so many other games that do each of Owlboy's elements better.  While Owlboy brings them all together, each element ended up mediocre, giving me a very mediocre feeling at the end of this journey, which is a good bit shorter than I had hoped for.Best of luck to you if you give the game a shot, though I'd personally suggest waiting on a bigger sale - I hope you find it more fun and rewarding than I did.  It's clear many people are enjoying it, and I'm just one person.  Again, thanks for your time.Edits: I had some typos.  There are always typos :<

content:
Posted: December 21, 2016
												I feel I need to preface my review with some personal info; I am one of those overly critical persons who never likes anything. That said, the only negative thing I can say about Owlboy is that there isn't more of it. Not that I think the game is technically too short. I simply wish to spend more time in this world. When I sensed I was getting close to the final battle, I had to stop playing for several days because I didn't want this experience to be over.I feel it in every pixel that this is a work of passion, and that speaks to me on a personal level. Owlboy might not delve as deeply into its characters, or have as complex a story, as other story rich indie games out there, but I think that only adds to its charms. There is a definite story arc and development of the main character that anyone who has experienced anxiety will relate to and understand, and it doesn't need to be further explored than what hints and sweet little moments we see in the game. Those who talk smack about Owlboy's story and characters simply haven't looked too hard. The game doesn't spoon-feed you its complex ideas; they're there if you really want to look for them.Were I not a poor student, I would gladly buy this game at full price for all my friends in order to support the creators. Owlboy, to me, is far superior to all the other 'story rich' indie games trying to squeeze out tears through emotional manipulation and exposition. Owlboy feels genuine.Now I am just sad that there isn't more. For the love of ♥♥♥♥, give these people money so they can make more games.

content:
Posted: November 19, 2016
												A wonderfully nostalgic experience for those who grew up in the 8-bit era, and a fine modern game in its own right. The gameplay is tight, the visuals are stunning, the sountrack absolutely soars, and the surprisingly deep story is beautifully told with a cast of likable, understandable characters. A few small sections of the level design feel a bit harsh, sometimes requiring more trial and error than I might have liked. One could argue that this is an authentic nod back to the games of yore, but I felt it stood at odds with the rest of the game's immaculate design. Admittedly there are a few other anachronisms, such as the lack of a map/minimap or fast-travel, both of which became a small hindrance when trying to hunt down all of the collectibles hidden throughout the game world towards the end of my playthrough... but none of this did much to hamper my overall enjoyment of an otherwise brilliant game.Highly recommended!

content:
Posted: December 22, 2016
												Try to ignore the hype around how long the game took to make, it doesn't really show in any area besides the quality of the visuals. Owlboy is a decent game dressed up with really gorgeous pixel art. The gameplay lacks a strong central mechanic, the controls aren't great, the movement speed is just slow enough that traversal feels really tiresome, and I always had the feeling that the level and creature designs were never really playing to the mechanics' strengths.Story-wise, it's an okay effort, but nowhere near what the game or some of the reviews would have you believe. I always felt like it was trying to puff up what was in actuality a pretty small package. At the first campfire sequence before you've reached the Owl Temple, Geddy talks about how it feels like they're on a real adventure. I could think of similar scenes in other games and mediums where there was a real sense of travel and reflection, but all I could think of was "what? we're doing this now? we've only been out of the first town for less than 5 minutes". It was a nice looking scene but it really showed the distance between what I was feeling and what the game wanted me to feel.There were some nice character moments scattered about but, like the story, the cast is not as timeless or loveable as the game might want you to think. They're cutesy and inoffensive but they all felt a bit thin. The only moment that really grabbed me was listening to the old man from the hot spring reminiscing in the ruins. I wished the main characters impressed on me in the same way.Ultimately, the game is okay. I'm marking it as not recommended to reflect a level of overall personal dissatisfaction, but I think the general praise implies that it resonates in some way with a lot of people. I really wish the game was as good as it wants to be.

number of helpful: 35 of 45 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2016
The great but inevitably massively overrated by fans Indie title of 2016No i don't mean that against the game at all, there's just a game each year that fans oversell massively leading to many arguments online, I believe Owlboy is this year's game for that.  The obvious draw to this game is it's immaculately detailed pixel art style with 9 years to create and refine and I will agree along with the many others and say it delivers. The world is vibrant and interesting consistently with beautiful environments throughout. The audio and soundtrack also come in to enhance the art style in order to build a very enjoyable experience. The game is absolutely worth a purchase for it's artistic work in itself(or even grabbing the game + soundtrak bundle).The main overarching plot isn't impressive nor bad, you will probably roll your eyes when you discover it has 'that' story, I won't spoil but you've heard it before. the world however does have enough interest and intrigue to easily keep you invested throughout. Characters however is where the game does start to shine, each one is enjoyable and is interesting enough that you want to hear what they have to say or press the interact button till they run out of lines and you can find yourself caring about their fates. The over the top animations also do a great job of giving a much greater personality to the sorts of characters that would generally be uninteresting.All up Owlboy has successfully done what few games manage to do and that's create a complete package that oozes with charm and is in general an experience that's just enjoyable to experience and be in from start to finish.Gameplay is unfortunately where Owlboy starts to struggle.The main idea behind the gameplay, of Otus being fairly limited in how he fights but can carry objects carries a nice novelty and gets you to think a little differently. Each companion has a unique set of abilities to assist Otus in navigating the world and defeating a handful of creatures littering the world, some unique others are a new skin on classic platformer enemies. Unfortunately these concepts are burdened by the games levels having a clear "use this character here" vibe and very quickly becomes "plant wall, shotgun", "bomb creature, there must be something breakable nearby" some sections of the game do get you to think but unfortunately most of the time you're just absent mindedly running through the motions to progress, there's little room to play. With most of the gameplay then just falling into fairly standard platformer puzzles there's little to impress in the gameplay in that regard, nothing much is terribly done, but there's nothing amazing either, all up it's consistently 'okay'.  Controls can also be a little fiddly with many cases of struggling to interact with a specific item, having to pick up a character and throw them away to get to something or pick up something a few times before you get its position right, all up it's a minor annoyance most of the time and can be ignored.The game could also really do with a decent map, with the world being large with a short view distance it becomes very easy to become lost and i worry about anyone who's a real completionist as finding out the last few areas you haven't been to i can imagine will become a pain to figure out.Late game became slightly less enjoyable with slow tedious time based puzzles where accidentally tapping the jump/fly button a second time ruins everything. Yes, it also does the slowly rising screen where you jump on breakable objects with a split second to jump on the one that's just appeared at the bottom, is there anyone that enjoys that? Especially when it's happening so slowly you're not getting that rush that comes from having to jump at a million miles an hour.Finally, I found bosses, particularly late game to be genuinely unenjoyable with short cutscenes breaking the flow and unclear weaknesses that lead you to blindly shooting till you spot the weakness. the worst of which involving a pirate switched your character, showed a cutscene and then instantly jumps at you giving you some less than fair damage as you try to get out of the way and switch characters before projectiles start flying at you.  If the art style doesn't interest you i would not recommend this game, there's nothing else here for you. Everyone else however the world, visuals and sound track all easily compensate for any gameplay shortcomings and it's absolutely worth playing through if you’re after a game you can just relax and enjoy.6/10 gameplay9/10  as an overall experience

number of helpful: 90 of 139 people (65%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16
												In spite of not recommending this game, I don't think it's bad, by any stretch of the imagination.It just isn't really worth your time by comparison to all the other incredible games in the genre out there.If I could give the game a "neutral" rating, I would.If you're a fan of artistic 2D platforming sidescrollers, Owlboy will give you what you're looking for. However, if you're not already a fan of the genre, Owlboy will not convince you.This is a game that rewards patience. The controls are not intuitive. It is possible and sometimes likely you will get lost. But if you're willing to sit through it and learn, the game is enjoyable.If you're looking at Owlboy and thinking you might like it, you probably will. If you're thinking "man, my friend is going on about this game, but I'm not really into these 2D sidescrollers", then just skip it.It's one of those all-too-common-but-usually-more-than-welcome artisitic sidescroller platformer indie games.Pros:- The art is great- The music is good- The dialogue is excellent- The game is funny without trying to be a "funny game"- There is plenty of complexity and a comfortable pacing of game mechanics- The difficulty is fair without being too easy. There are enough challenges for it to be satisfying, but never extremely frustrating (except for the Cannon minigame).Cons:- The controls are wonky and difficult to get used to- There is no map and you frequently get lost in the "hub" areas- There is no way to confirm/remind yourself what your current objective is- The story is all packed into the first and last 30 minutes of the roughly 9 hour game. Everything that happens in between that time is completely irrelevant to the overarching story, though it's still enjoyable.- It sort of drags through the middle part of the game- It doesn't stand out as being "amazing" at anything in particularThe game is fine. You could just do better with 8-9 hours of your time and $25. It's good, but not nearly as good as Ori and the Blind Forest, Cave Story, Shovel Knight, or Shantae.

number of helpful: 24 of 28 people (86%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 2, 2016
 TLDR: Owlboy is an absolute buy for anyone who likes gorgeous, fun, 2D adventuring games.      Owlboy is an absolutely beautiful game in every sense of the word. Starting with the visuals, Owlboy isn't like most other pixel art games. While many other games use similar art in order to feel nostalgic or just to capitalize on that feeling to sell copies; Owlboy's visuals are a gorgeous, amazing, highly skilled art piece that is just fun to look at. Not once had I felt that a texture was phoned in or a lesser quality than the rest. The whole game feels like it was handcrafted to please the eyes.     The soundtrack has the same quality as the visuals, with several pieces causing the player to feel heartbreak or happiness depending on the track. The composer/musician spared no instrument to make this masterpiece of audio, and this is actually one soundtrack that I highly recommend purchasing.     The gameplay is a fun metroidvania-esque blend of platforming, twin-stick shooting and VERY light puzzle solving. The games metroidvania elements come from Otus' (the Owlboy) ability to pick up his different friends with different weapons. Each friend he picks up has a different mechanic tied to them which allow you to access different areas throughout the course of the game. This same mechanic highly effects combat as you carry your friend around, using the right stick to aim their weapon as different enemies try to attack you. It feels very responsive and is very reliable as it has a soft lock-on mechanic helping you to hit what you want to hit. While the combat controls well, it is too easy at times, especially on the boss fights which are over very soon after they begin. That being said, while the bosses might not have a lot of screen time, they are a blast to fight as you have to figure out how to get past their defenses, using the environment, or just plain outsmarting them. The puzzles, while fun and definitely rewarding at times are so simple most children could figure them out within a minute or two (at least most of them). While it does feel intentional for the puzzles to be this easy in order to keep the game flowing. Owlboy definitely isn't a game for people seeking any kind of puzzle gameplay. Overall the game has great pacing, fun gameplay that changes depending on what friend you are currently carrying, and controls that are easy to use and don't require explaining.     While trying to steer clear of spoilers, the story is centered around Otus. Otus is a sometimes clumsy, if not well-intended Owlboy that tries his best to save his town Vellie from attacking pirates. Using the help of his best friend Gebby, and other friends he meets along the way, he conquers many different obstacles and challenges that arise throughout his journey. The story grips you with its strong talons from the beginning and holds on to you throughout. Due to the gorgeous high-quality art style, each character has a full visible range of emotion that you feel in times of sadness, fear, joy, and peace. The villain is a high enough threat that you feel you need to find a way to stop him, instead of just brute force the problem. Which helps the game stay focused throughout its many different objectives. The story and subsequently the writing, are easily some of the best I have personally experienced in a 2D adventure game.     This game easily deserves all the praise it is getting due to its high quality throughout the entire adventure. The $25 price tag it holds at the time of this review might be a little steep for some people, but it is easily worth the price and those who take that leap are in for an amazing adventure with Otus the Owlboy.

number of helpful: 18 of 18 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5
												tl;dr: Good game, but keep your expectations in check.As someone who has been waiting 6+ years to play Owlboy, it’s a bit unfortunate to say that I have mixed feelings about this game. It deserves a thumbs up simply because the good outweighs the bad, and I'm sure there are people who'll love Owlboy to pieces despite its flaws. It’s great for what it is, but there’s some untapped potential here that I hope will be improved upon if there’s ever a sequel.Personally, I loved the universe, the amazing soundtrack, the beautiful graphics, and the protagonist (despite the fact that Otus never says anything). Interacting with the NPCs is always interesting and a lot of the time they say or do genuinely funny and adorable stuff. Otus’ gunners/companions aren't as likable as I feel they should be, considering that they're always around (since you need them for pretty much everything). Well, the exception being the last one you meet - at least he's got a bit of backstory and is somewhat relatable. I wouldn't mind a bit of dialogue/banter from them when you're flying around doing whatever needs to be done, since Otus (being a mute) is obviously silent all the time and the cutscenes are few and far between. Sometimes it feels like you're just doing levels for the sake of it and not to achieve anything, at least until you bother to read the reminded to see what your actual objective is.My only real problem with this game, though, is the difficulty. It's literally so easy that I don't think I needed more than five tries on the hardest boss - and that wasn't even the final one. There's no learning curve or need for tactical thinking in this game, you just shoot enemies and make the slightest effort to dodge their attacks - and that's the solution to winning every fight. You sometimes have to switch your gunners mid-fight, but you can usually win with whichever one you're currently carrying.Puzzles aren't challenging either, and I say that as someone with sub-par visual intelligence. Even finding every single coin in the world was fairly easy.The most difficult part in Owlboy is actually completely optional, and that is the mini-game that you only have to succeed 100% at if you wish to get every achievement (you'll use WASD to move Otus normally, but I couldn't complete the mini-game until I tried the arrow keys instead. Too bad I discovered that after 2 hours of messing up).I guess I hoped for more challenging gameplay to go with the story, but I enjoyed the game nonetheless. The world is extremely detailed and feels very alive, so getting immersed in it was no problem at all. Level design is clever and there's even a day/night cycle that makes the environment even more beautiful.Completionists will get more out of the game as the story is only about 7-ish hours long, but I’d say that Owlboy is definitely worth picking up regardless of what type of gamer you are; just don't buy it believing it's anything other than a casual, easy-going experience.

number of helpful: 84 of 137 people (61%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
												I'll preface this by saying that I have nothing but respect for the developers who worked on the many iterations of this game for approximately nine years. Their dedication is certainly admirable, and their vision, while not fully brought to its potential, is readily apparent when you play the game. Truthfully, the game feels like it was developed by a team solely compromised of artists, not game designers. As players, we need to try to not hype this game up based on its development time or appearance. Look at how long Duke Nukem Forever took.With that out of the way, however, I couldn't find a way to connect myself to the story, the characters or the world itself. The art, while beautiful, doesn't make up for what, outside of the soundtrack, is a package that feels like it hasn't been properly fleshed out. Both the level and monster designs don't lend themselves well at all to the fundamental mechanics of the game, a conflict that ends up being one of the larger factors that pushes this game into overwhelmingly mediocre territory.The world is mostly empty and, despite its beauty, I hestitate to even call what you can do in this game world "exploration", with the exception of finding the golden discs, as there's a ridiculous amount of empty space and an almost upsetting lack of things to do, see and uncover.The story is about as mediocre as they come, despite its fairly strong start given Otus' state in the first five minutes of the game. The characters fall flat, the tale that the developers spun is nothing short of cliché and all in all, it just isn't anything special.Mechanically, the game is fairly standard twin-stick shooter affair with a few tweaks to the formula. While necessary in the open world, I had a few gripes with the Geddy teleporting system as it lessens the impact of being hit while within a dungeon. It just felt like more could have been done there.Ultimately, for a game so heavily toting its exploration, being able to 100% the experience in approximately 7-9 hours is laughable, and most definitely does not justify the price point that the game is currently sold at at the time of writing. There's very little worthwhile to find, too, which only cheapens the experience.Unfortunately, as previously stated, the breathtaking art and suitable soundtrack aren't enough to salvage a game otherwise wrought with mediocrity. If you're looking for a game that offers the exploration you might be looking at this game for, I implore you to check out Rabi-Ribi. They're very similar games, but Rabi-Ribi is infinitely better in execution as a Metroidvania style game. At a similar price point, you will get so, so much more out of it than you will with Owlboy.

number of helpful: 24 of 31 people (77%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 12, 2016
Product received for free
												Owlboy wants to please you. The game tries it’s hardest to put a smile on your face, and it nearly accomplishes that across the board. Whether it be the stunning pixel art (seriously, this is one of the most gorgeous pixel art games I think there is, period), sweeping soundtrack or the genuinely charming cast of characters, Owlboy’s aim is to please.After nearly ten years in development, Owlboy has finally released and boy is it great. As I mentioned, the first thing you’ll probably notice is the sublime art direction. You can really feel the love and attention to detail that went into crafting this world and is breathtaking landscapes. Whether it be the dusk sky or an underground cave, the game is simply a joy to look at. On top of the wonderful pixel art are the tremendous animations. Everything here is silky smooth with fluidity that really make everything pop and makes the world feel more alive.But graphics aren’t everything, right? Luckily, Owlboy is also fun to play and has exquisite controls to boot. While the minute to minute gameplay and standard enemies may not necessarily be that challenging, I still found it quite engaging to traverse and explore the world. The main mechanic of the game is that the character Otus can fly about while holding one of his friends who can fire their respective weapons. I quite liked this wrinkle and by the end of the game during boss battles, I found it quite thrilling to swap between the three friends to mix and match their weapons. Speaking of boss battles, these are some finely crafted encounters that will test your mettle. I found each boss to be tough, yet fair. I don’t think I beat any of them on my first go, but learning their patterns and weaknesses was very rewarding.While I would not call Owlboy a Metroidvania, it certainly feels like it wanted to be one. The world may seem quite open when you begin but the game is in fact pretty linear. I didn’t find this to be a bad thing, but it’s worth noting. What may alleviate the linearity for some is the excellent level design. The layouts of each area are smart and intuitive so you never feel lost. Going along with the Metroidvania-lite is the fact that there are upgrades, but they range from essential (health upgrades) to useless (hats). While I feel that if the devs fully fleshed this out and made it a true Metroidvania we could be looking at a truly special game, I still greatly enjoyed my time with Owlboy.If you’re looking for a game that will put a smile on your face and throw in a couple of laughs for good measure, you could do much worse. Owlboy is a beautifully realized world with a standout art direction and just the right amount of challenge to be enjoyed by nearly everyone.

number of helpful: 46 of 70 people (66%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 1, 2016
												Revered, exalted, wise. These are just a few of the words I would use to describe Owlboy.The developer D-Pad Studio took about a decade to make this game from conception to finish, and thankfully their efforts have made a masterpiece. I honestly would put Owlboy among the high echelons of indie games and other amazing games that have come before it. I am talking Shovel Knight, Binding of Isaac, Limbo, Fez; games that have shaped modern PC gaming as we know it. They have combined spectacular story telling, fantastic characters, dazzling design/artstyle, and from beginning to end enjoyable gameplay. This game was an absolute treat to play and is easily one of my choices for best game of the year, 2016.I don't say that just about any game. This game spoke to me in more ways than one, it captured my imagination and reminded me what I love about games.Now before I continue I want to put out a bit of warning, I highly recommend this title(obviously) but if you continue to read this I will be talking about game features, characters, and the overall experience of the game. So if you are considering even for a moment of buying this game. DO IT.Owlboy is game about courage, friendship, and adventure in the face of overwhelming odds. You play Otus, a young owl who is being tutored to join a long line of respected Owl guardian figures who protect and aid the people. Like quintessential heroes of yesteryear, poor Otus is mute and thus lacks in the self confidence department. His tutor Asio is tough and sometimes rough on Otus, expecting much from our young hero. The world was once densely populated with owls, but after a mysterious event, most of them have disappeared. When pirates show up at the village of Vellie, a trickster steals an important relic. This sets events into a spiral.It's hard to capture the game in one genre but it's somewhere between a Metroidvania and an Action/Platformer. The game is a side scroller that lets you fly in any direction. Obviously things like walls, doors, and other obstacles prevent from accessing areas you shouldn't but it never felt unnatural in Owlboy. Matter of fact, I have to compliment Owlboy on how natural the game combines the flow of story with little secrets hidden everywhere to be discovered. You always know where to go but you can take the entire game at your own pace. One thing to keep in mind is Owlboy emphasized on its story. It does away with the hundreds of hidden upgrades/secrets for more of a linear adventure like experience. The secrets that are there however, are very challenging to find and once found reveal more of the bright and wonderful world to you.Flying is one of the biggest treats in this game and the controls are fantastic; completely responsive. I mostly played with my keyboard/mouse but had no problems diving, dashing and swooping around my enemies and generally laying down a butt kicking. I can imagine the same could be said for a controller. Both control methods feature rebindable keys and an assortment of different control methods, even for you southpaws out there. The action is equally as riveting as you gather allies and companions giving you access to new abilities, ways to blast enemies and overcome obstacles. The action never got dull for me, as I found unique ways to deal with the many bosses of Owlboy.So now I am going to gush over the graphics and sound/music of Owlboy. Be warned. I want you to take a moment and look at a screenshot of Owlboy's clouds. LOOK AT THEM!I would gladly take these clouds ANY day of the year over any rendered 60FPS thing you could throw at me. The pixel art is gorgeous and there are several times throughout the game where it took my freaking breath away.  Attention to detail is at maximum here with each area/house lovingly given detail. The character designs and animations give the characters life in a joyous fantastical way. Every time Geddy would do his stupid dance, I would laugh my butt off. Don't get me wrong, this game isn't kittens and rainbows all the time. As a matter of fact there are plenty of times I was shocked by game itself and how dark things got. That never stops the game from being nonetheless a fun adventure and this is demonstrated in its art, level design, and animations. I honestly would be surprised if this game couldn't be adapted into an anime.Moving on to the music of Owlboy, the game features an orchestral soundtrack that would make John Williams smile. There is a moment in the game where you are riding on the back of a giant mechanical lizard. The moment that part began, the music drew me in and I couldn't stop smiling. Even as I moved about, dodging debris and everything was going to hell. It was scary, exhilarating and the music just took it to the next level. It's these types of moments that are speckled all throughout the game and which do everything to enhance the story, the art, and again the gameplay.We have arrived at that point where I usually insert something I didn't like about the game. Let me say I was HARD pressed to find anything. The game has no bugs and is extremely well made. Boss fights are challenging but not frustrating. Exploration is difficult but rewarding. The pace of the game is always moving forward at a good clip, as new abilities are given to you for you to experiment with and enjoy. Is the game perfect? Dang near but, there was one thing in combat that did grate on me sometimes. During combat, if you are struck by an enemy, an animation plays that knocks Otus out of the air and kind of stun locks you. If multiple enemies are present and attacking, you can get stun locked for quite a while and lose more health than you would like. There that's it! All I've got.Honestly, If I haven't given you the impression of how impressed I was with this title then, there really isn't much more that I could say. This game took me back to when games were wondrous. Like the first time I played Ocarina of Time or started up Final Fantasy VII. It made me feel like a kid again and I loved every moment of it. To the point where I didn't want it to end. Owlboy is about a ten hour experience more or less. You could extend that by finding every single secret. This may add two to four hours depending on how well you do the first run through the areas. You could say that isn't very long, but any more would be cheapening to the story and experience of this game. Trust me the amount of time it takes is perfect.Replay value is of course up to you, but I personally could see myself playing this game many times over and looking for every single detail of the art, secrets of the story, or just kicking back and listening to the music. Does the game innovate? Not necessarily. But it does refine an age-old style and mechanics perfectly. The game is priced at $24.99 which is above the usual Indie standard, but the quality is more than worth it. These are the types of games you want to see made and these are the games you want to support.I could honestly write more about this games bosses, story, and that awesome ending but I don't want to spoil any more for you.So thanks for reading.I'm off to play some more Owlboy!

												Not the longest game, nor the most complicated, nor the hardest, but Owlboy was visually and aurally one of the best games I've ever played.The gameplay is relatively simple, but satisfying, and some parts required multiple redos - as a person who generally enjoys coasting through games and experiencing them, this is preferable to a particularly difficult retro game ala Mega Man. content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												Owlboy is a fairly good game; my problem is that it isn't worth the price.  Most especially due to the fact that it is being touted as a metroidvania, when in fact the game is extremely linear.  Don't be misled as I was:  this game is actually just an ARPG.  What little exploration there is to be had usually amounts to nothing more than an occasional short branch in the path, and the rewards for such exploration are generally no more impressive than a few coins.The game world is beautiful, and the characters are fun.  Sadly about ten hours is all you'll get to enjoy those aspects of this very short game.  Combat can be a bit awkward when compared to other action games, due to the fact that you spend much of it hauling around your gunners (the only way to damage the majority of enemies).It's possible that I might have been more impressed with this game had I experienced it in a vacuum, but unfortunately it comes on the heels of Ori and the Blind Forest.  By comparison Owlboy is shorter, more expensive, less immersive, less challenging, offers less chance for exploration... I could go on, but I think the point is clear.  My conclusion is that while this is not a bad game, I wouldn't pay more than $10 for it had I the chance to do things over.

												This game so far is amazing. From the varied enemies and puzzles, the incredibly crisp and rewarding audio, all the way to the detailed sprite work and flawless animation- this game is a work of art.The story progresses at a nice even pace that keeps you enthralled in the world, without endless waves of text boring you to tears.The game is a 2D action/puzzle game. Mouse and keyboard works fine too though, and can be changed.This is surely a game that had the developer's heart and soul pooled into it, and you can feel it with every minute you play. Definately glad I picked this one up.Edit: After clearing the game, I can safely say I only wish it was a bit longer, I cleared it with most stuff gathered in about 10 hours or so. Other than that, it was an amazing ride from start to finish and I would certainly recommend it to my friends either now or on sale- you definately have to play it sometime.

												This is my personal opinion of owlboy:Pros:Graphics are great. Story is great. Art is great. Gameplay is very fun with controller. Twin stick shooter is a good idea. The gameplay also never got stale. I never got bored.There was always a switch of game style too. Sometimes it was a sidescroller platformer, sometimes you would need to steer a dragon!!! This does not occur in owlboy and feels really awkward at times.THE CANNON PART OMG. (optional sidequest).Music is good but doesn't stick to me. Undertale had great music and I would listen to it over and over again afterwards. In Owlboy, I can hardly remember the soundtrack. It was great in game but I don't think I would listen to it again. There are some parts where there is just too much talking. I just wanted to play the game. Overall, this game was great. It had small nitpicks here and there but in the end, it was fun. Even though it was short, it was comprised of very good gameplay all around unlike a 60 hour game that has like 10 hrs of good gameplay and 50hrs of recycled gameplay like tailing missions (assasins creed im looking at you).WAS IT WORTH IT??YES

number of helpful: 16 of 20 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 4, 2016
												Nine  years is a large chunk of anybody’s lifetime, for those of us lucky to see a century, it’s almost a tenth of the precious, finite time we get to spend on this planet. I’ve been following the progress of this game since the first few morsels were public and admit to having forgotten about the game several times until inevitably finding more little delicious crumbs to follow until arriving at the 1st of November and a metaphorical cake, responsible for the delicious line of crumbs that preceded it waited to be eaten. I sat there like a mad man, refreshing the store page every five seconds until I was finally allowed to pick up my fork (controller) and dig in (buy and play the game!) Until at last some wonderful music and gorgeous pixel art made way for the menu buttons, the new game started and I started to take the first bite.After a brief and somewhat emotionally uncomfortable introduction to basic mechanics, the game proper began in a lush, warm room, I stayed here for five minutes mesmerised by the level of mastery the artist had shown through animation, colour palette and precision of pixel placement. Everything looked as it should, as the artist had no doubt spent hours meticulously on this single interior, this prospect left me feeling both excited and somewhat flabbergasted as to what might be waiting for the majority of the game that was waiting for me.Outside, the incredible visuals began to be accompanied by some understated but catchy music, fading and acquiring new layers to its depth as the area was explored, and explore I did. I spent a good hour just playing, interacting with objects, smashing pots for the glittering coins within and hitting flowers before watching them grow back. It might be an overstatement to say that small details like this are what make good games great but what it shows is a deeper level of understanding of the symbiotic substance that is a video game. Video games  are a composition of audio, visual and active interaction; the greatest challenge of any game designer or indeed, member of any games design team is to anticipate player action, it may seem stupid but by placing a seemingly small and insignificant flower for me to repeatedly lop the head off of is testament to the level of thought that has gone into building this lush, interactive world to explore. The devil is in the details, when you move slightly a cloud of dust forms at your feet, when you flap and roll, the air visually moves behind you and it all contributes to making the movement feel dynamic.  Audio, visual and interactivity composed to make even the simple act of movement fun and engaging, which is a relief because as this is primarily platforming and exploration you’re going to be doing that a lot! Quite a few critics have, in my opinion, unfairly described OwlBoy as having a “retro pixel art aesthetic”. There is no appeal to retro-activity to be found in the sublime pixel pushing of this artist but simply a love, understanding and desire to show the gaming community the brilliance of pixel art as a form of visual art in and of itself. There were so many occasions where I sat there in sheer awe of the level of detail being presented to me in one of the harshest, most technically difficult mediums to present such things. Any person can pick the pencil tool in paint and draw an isometric cube, provided they clicked one pixel at a time this could be described as pixel art but that would be the same as getting someone to paint a portrait of their dog in oils and calling them Rembrandt. OwlBoy is a master-class in pixel art; it is the interactive equivalent of going to see the finest works of art at La Louvre in that it showcases the medium of pixel art in a manner so far unmatched in any indie game thus far and I would put it on a level equal to some of the greatest pixel work done in video games, ever.As mentioned earlier the visual is accompanied by some of the most whimsical, brilliantly executed musical pieces that I have heard for some time, everything is meticulous here, considered and there’s no better way to understand that to simply play it yourself. The visual and audio contribute to making each and every area feel unique, hand crafted and a pleasure to explore.The ability to fly is such a huge and wondrous ability, usually limited to the final parts of many action-driven platformers, so it is such an ingenious twist to  gimp the main characters abilities in the realm of combat very rarely can you do anything but dodge or defend when playing as Otus (the titular owlboy) alone. Luckily the designers were kind enough to supply you with three very different (mechanically and characteristically) friends to grab hold of your feet and offer their projectile shooting abilities, each has their own uses, from providing a piercing rapid fire to cover most basic enemies and weaker structures; to huge bursts of musket fire to incinerate. Not once do you feel like a character is merely there for the sake of it, they have been designed and the world and all of its dirty little secrets has been designed around both your ability to fly and their ability to help you to. Speaking of dirty little secrets, there’s quite a few, hidden walls to find that usually contain some point of interest such as chests or coins. At one point I discovered a secret, only to return later and realise it held and even bigger one. Discovering these things always feels organic, as though you were meant to and that speaks volumes of the game as a whole to be honest, everything feels as though it was MEANT to be that way, it feels crafted, designed out of a labour of love. There will never be coins you can miss, they’ve been placed in areas that you can access after exploring an area; such is the level of foresight possessed by the creators. The narrative, story and plot are all wonderfully executed; you’re always kept guessing and there’s enough mystery to fuel a fan base who will inevitably be making discussion threads about why certain things are said or done. The pacing feels tight and considered, not once did I feel the story was rushed or there was too much exposition thrown at me at once. Ultimately, once more, everything felt like it had a purpose, as though it belonged for a reason greater than simply “because it can”. I’ve spent 20 hours exploring in this game and I don’t feel like single second of my time was wasted in terms of the main content of the game, there’s one mini game whose inclusion seems rather odd and out of place but this would be the singular negative in an otherwise brilliantly executed piece of art. OwlBoy rewards you for exploring, for interacting and provides some of the greatest pixel art I’ve ever seen in a game together with some top notch music. I’d like to take this opportunity to thank the development team, thank you for spending the most precious thing you have in your life, your time, for making what has been a wonderfully fulfilling experience. You are all amazing and if I were rich enough I’d buy the game a million times over.

content:
Posted: January 3
												This wonderful masterpiece. where do i begin. i rarely write reviews but boy does this one deserve it. I'm not as good as other reviewers that perfectly setup their reviews pro's and con's, but let's begin.Owlboy is a hybrid platformer with flight that follows a story that slowly starts unfolding at first but quickly advances.It is full of emotions right off the start and you get spoon-fed with visual emotions such as the beauty of the music and scenery. You get the feel of wonder, adventure, and danger depending in the scenery or dungeon you're in, the music just sets the mood just right. I praise this game for it's visual, music, characters and personalities, the controls are responsive.The story is beautiful in my opinion, i know there are others who would disagree. But it's a beautiful tale of character development that you have no idea who the protagonist is besides what you see in the beginning, where are his parents, and who are his ancestors, and what your character is capable of. You are in control of his destiny as you continue the story to save the world. If by option you explore every nook and cranny you'll find secrets that give clues to your ancestry or story about people you know, with the music on top of it it just makes it so emotional and it complete's the story, as well as items to help you feel complete and powerful. You even have the option to load up the game after you beat it to explore the previous places you visited to finish loose ends which in return gives even more story, in my case i just wanted to find out why i couldn't open a certain chest which is only possible after you beat the game and well... it was full of feels.Everything about this game, from its sprites to the music, you can tell love was put into it.The main protagonist and his companion's are incredibly memorable with beautiful personalities, rich of character.Everywhere you explore is beautiful, so much detail was put into this game.I give this game a solid 10 out of 10.In my opinion the best beautiful sprited game of this recent modern era.unfortuntely i don't think there will be a sequel, and i just hope that if the developers of owlboy decide to make a game just as great as owlboy that it gets the same love and devotion but made in less time. They have the money and resources now to develope a game just as great in less time thanks to Owlboy. And if the staff splits and goes to a different company, that they continue to give all their heart and love into whatever new game they're working on just as they did with owlboy.

Posted: November 26, 2016
												Owlboy was the only game I have actually looked forward to playing in a long time, and one of the few games I have bought at release.  Overall,  Owlboy is worth it.  The game has been in development for 9 years, and the effort definitely shows.  Easily one of the best soundtracks of the year, and probably the best pixel artwork out of any 8-bit game.  The flying mechanic felt extremely fresh and new for a 2D game, and Owlboy executed it perfectly.  I have not felt immersed in a game in a long time and Owlboy gave me that feeling.  When I stopped playing Owlboy, I honestly could not wait to start playing again, something I have not felt towards a video game in a long time.  The only negatives for me is how short the game is (however, I did not 100% the game), and the relative easiness of the game.  The game never felt particularly hard, with only one memorable platforming challenge, and only one boss fight that took more than 3 tries.  One of my favorite games of all time is CaveStory, and if you are looking for a challenge similar, you will not find it in Owlboy.Overall, Owlboy is a lot of fun, with a very interesting game mechanic that no other game has done (or done well), and the story and characters were fun and immersing.  The major stand out points for Owlboy are definitely the art and the soundtrack.  8/10
