number of helpful: 41 of 71 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9
												Owlboy is the very definition of the dedication that can come from the Indie space. The game was in development for about 10 years from D-Pad Studio. While the gameplay doesn't fly as high as I would have liked, the story and animation do help to pick it up to some extent.Rising Up:Before we can talk about the gameplay, we have to talk about the story and aesthetics. Owlboy may not have the graphical wow-ness of something like Hyper Light Drifter, but the animation quality is one of the best I've seen. Character details and the backgrounds look amazing and right out of a late-gen SNES title.The story follows Owl in training Otus who has spent his life as a mute. Considered a failure by his mentor, Otus is thrust into action when pirates invade. The story continues to get darker, especially for a 2D game, but I don't want to spoil it.While this is a 2D platformer, you won't be doing as much jumping compared to other titles. Otus is free to fly around for the most part, and performs a spin attack. Otus has to rely on his friends as his spin attack won't hurt enemies.Early on, you'll gain the ability to teleport his friends directly to Otus. Carrying them, each person has an attack that you can make use of for combat and puzzle solving. Because you are free to fly, this meant that the developers had to figure out other ways to add progression.Aerial Exploration:Special coins can be found and cashed in for various items. Coins are usually located in hidden chests or rings that you have to fly through. The dungeons themselves feel right out of home from a Zelda game.Each one has the standard design of one unique quirk that you have to work around. Due to Otus not having a real attack, you need to rely on your best friend to do the bulk of the damage. While combat is not the focus of the game, there are plenty of arena fights and a few bosses to deal with.As you play through, you'll unlock a total of three friends that will allow you to find more hidden areas and coins.All around, Owlboy is a good game, but the gameplay can't match the high flying atmosphere.Crashed:Owlboy is unfortunately an example of how a unique mechanic doesn't always lead to amazing gameplay. A lot of your time spent in the game will be air rolling across wide rooms. The different dungeons never try to build on their initial quirk. Once you've solved one puzzle, expect to do it repeatedly throughout the dungeon. Outside of your three companions, no new abilities or systems are introduced.Due to the flying mechanics, there is very little platforming outside of the final area. The problem is that nothing was really added to replace platforming as a challenge.The combat system is the weakest part of the game, but is used the most. I would have liked to have seen more bosses that require other tactics than just fighting.Depending on how you play it, Owlboy can be beaten in a few hours if you skip the cutscenes. Outside of hunting coins and three mysterious items, there's no reason to go back to the game or advanced challenges to find.From a technical point of view, I had some issues with quickly performing commands using the grab button. There were cases where the camera transition between screens did screw me up in terms of dodging attacks.Gliding Along:Owlboy is an average game with a story and animation style that attempt to elevate it higher. If you're looking for a great platformer, I can't recommend Owlboy. This is one of those games that is greater than the sum of its parts, but how high it flies depends on what you're looking for in a 2D game. I didn't want to give it a thumbs down, but at the same time, there's just not enough in terms of gameplay for me to recommend it.For more reviews and talks on video games and game design, check out Game-Wisdom[game-wisdom.com] and our YouTube channel for daily video content.

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 28
												After 10 long years of development, Owlboy has been released for the world. Was this worth the time for you to pick it up?The artwork no doubt catches the eye before the story or gameplay. It can be amazing how much pixel art can accomplish and it is displayed amazingly in Owlboy. Everything is vibrant and detailed, everything being distinct from one another. Each area telling it's own story with their individual design that you can easily tell where you are without the game telling you (especially since there is no map). Every enemy beautifully designed and animated so you can easily tell what they do. Every character is distinct from one another with their design and their own background. Owls, which could of had the same cloak design, having different owl cloaks ranging from color and wingspan. While the soldiers have the same outfit it speaks for itself and the citizens all having unique designs. Little details were able to be put in: puffs of wind on the ground when flying close to the ground, day and night cycle, and giving expressions to everyone.You play Otus, a young mute Owl working with his friend Otus to protect their floating home from sky pirates. Teaming up with others to help in his journey. Getting a tiny bit sidetracked with a few things in the progress. As I don't want to spoil anything, you should experience the story yourself.Story and lore is effortlessly integrated into everything. The designs tell their own story and you can get more by interacting with the world. The characters are charming, not suffering from cheesy writing, as they tell you about themselves or various other things. There are two collectables, golden disks and Buccanary coins. The golden disks reveals information an important plot point when put in the right place, but it doesn't happen till the end. The Buccanary coins lets you unlock optional items that also include very cute chatter between the people you give them to. This can range from hats, to more health, to buffs. I would be lying if the Owl in Owlboy didn't make me interested in the game. This is not just a regular platformer but one that you can fly in and access every free space you can. Otus, on his own, can roll, injure enemies by spinning, and pick up objects to throw around. However he can not make it on his own without friends. With his friends such as Geddy and Alphonse, you can directly attack them from afar. Not only that, your friend's special ability is necessary to navigate around your environment. You can easily access them by picking them up or teleporting them to your hands.Since you do carry your friends to use their ability, dropping them to pick something else up can be a little confusing to the game. Your friends will always be first in line no matter what you want to pick up. Want that berry to heal up but Geddy is right by it? You will pick up Geddy instead so take that time in throwing him the other way (perhaps hitting him a few times for that achievement?) so you can eat that berry. To mix things up there are stealthy parts. The first time can be very frustrating, especially when the floor disappears on you like it did for me. This is also one of the parts where bum rushing it is a strategy to get past it without having to waste time fighting. Later on it does get better as you try not to provoke enemies as much in those areas (they always seem more vicious than the regular enemies).This can easily be classified as a casual game with how easy most parts can be. Once you get over learning how each enemy moves and attacks and the environmental hazards it can be a cakewalk. Checkpoints are very generous, the last one being right before the last boss, enemies being very easy to defeat, and Otus being able to take a lot of damage. The bosses are really the only thing that is challenging as they have you think on the spot with their unpredictable behavior. I actually was stuck on one of the last few bosses since it has you dodging a lot but I was able to collect more Buccanary coins to unlock more health. The only thing that might not be as easy is navigating to each area. Sometimes you either can't find the right entrance to the area or find out where you have to go to progress in the story.You can not mention Owlboy without the soundtrack. Every piece nails the mood of each scene and does a great job representing the area it is placed in. It no doubt made the game as much as the gameplay and art did. Owlboy is definitely worth picking up, discount or no discount. Easily bring in 10 hours of gameplay and more if you desire to 100% it. While it does have flaws, everything else that Owlboy brings to the table keeps the experience intact.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2016
												Pros:- Very good soundtrack (strongly recommend buying the soundtrack as well recently found out that the soundtrack available doesn't actually have all the songs, so recommend listening to it on youtube or somewhere else).- Nice, expressive and rounded characters that all feel very human, brimming with personality and flaws.- Stealthing is enjoyable and not impossible to recover from if you screw up.- Lore is very intriguing and left me wanting to find out as much as I could about the world.- Majority of the mechanics are intuitive and fun to use.Neutral:- Only about 5-10 hours of playtime for a single runthrough and not much replay value after a single play. Depending on your views about dollars-per-hour this can either be a good thing as it means the story doesnt outstay its welcome or a bad thing as it is over too quickly for $25.Cons:- Could use some tighter controls (navigating through the vines was a small annoyance)- Some of the side quests are a bit difficult and tedious compared to the meat of the game. Wouldn't be a complaint by itself since they are not mandatory except...- Main story only gives closure for Otus and his three companions. Most of the lore you learn about along the way only gets any real fleshing out through the difficult and tedious sidequesting and some elements are left to fan speculation.

												Reccomended to me by so many people, I finally got around to playing Owlboy. And if I had to explain it in one word, it would be: "polished". This game is not only beautiful to look at with its "hi-bit" graphics, you will definitely notice the orchestral score. None of that is compulsory, you can finish the game just rushing through it, yet it is breathtaking how much care and attention to detail went into this game.If you have 20 bucks to spare, you really can't go wrong with Owlboy. It's a lot of fun and while it felt a bit short - it was more like I didn't want it to end yet. I'll definitely come back to it someday and wholeheartedly reccomend it to anyone.

content:
Posted: January 3
												Owlboy is a love letter to the pixel games of the SNES days. I wish all future pixel games would put the amount of detail into graphics. The game looks stunning. Now with that out of the way, let see if Owlboy is as good as it looks.Story: Otus a mute owl boy set off on an adventure with a miscast group to save his home and the world from the pirate and the power of the ancient owl relics. Honestly this game have quite a few cut scenes in it and I can't really go more into detail without spoiling the story. Although I found it funny how they specifically mention in the beginning that Otus is a mute. It always funny how must game just say the main protagonist don't talk much but they actually made Otus a mute to drive this point home. The cast you go through the game with is funny/quirky and memorable in their own way. Although I felt the game were short and the story felt rushed in some partsGameplay: Otus is an owl boy so he can fly about the screen. He can roll to dodge attacks, and has a spin attack that is use more for stunning enemies than actually defeating them. His real offense come from his friends. Each one with their own unique projectile attack or ability to use. I can't go into detail about them without spoiling the story...My only complaint was that often time it felt overwhelming trying to switch characters while flying and dodging attacks. There are time I felt I was hit because I could dodge due to losing track of my hitbox due to having to account for Otus & his companion.Overall: This is a short game, and its more story driven than anything. Some cutscene may drag on too long for players who just want to to get to the gameplay. All in all it short but fun little adventure to engage in. Just make sure you do not get this game for the full price (at the time it is $24.99). The game is too short to justify paying close to $25 for it. I got it for $19.99 and I felt I should have waited till a sale when it dropped to $15 or less. Owlboy is a soaring good time but it's price need to fall from the sky.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2016
												Owlboy is a very, very well created game (So far, I'm only a number of hours into the story), that I hope doesn't end up being severely underrated.The graphics are as described, pixel art, but of high quality, with each sprite and area design looking like it was made with lots of care and critique.It has a certain loveable charm to it in its dialogue and characters, and presents itself almost like an old 'coming-of-age' story, and it's given well.The music in Owlboy is also very wonderful. From simple tunes in tone with the art style to absolutely beautiful full range melodies, it really helps paint a wondrous, beautiful world to explore.The most important factor, the gameplay, is also very strong. It's a 'sort of' platformer, with 'sort of' coming from the fact that the protagonist can fly. In addition, it also has light puzzle elements, and in a few areas, well made stealth portions that don't suck, and serve as world-painting and mood setting. All in all, Owlboy is VERY much worth $25, and something that shouldn't be passed up, even if you're not a strong fan of platformers.

												Great game for the nostalgic gamer. The artwork is beautiful, the soundtrack amazing, and the gameplay fun. It holds onto the ideal of sidescrollers, but yet brings something fresh to the table. The mecahnics of flying and the friends is enjoyable. The puzzles are designed fairly and intelligently, where they won't keep a player bogged down for too long, but they still do not feel too easy.  I fell in love with the game instantly and was unable to put it down. The characters are enjoyable, the setting and levels unique, whimiscal, colorful, and intriguing. The story is not groundbreaking or a cinematic masterpiece, but it is fascinating enough to keep the player's attention. Being a fan of some of the old 2d sidescrollers, this game felt like a love letter to gamers such as myself who yearned for something fresh that still offered that nostalgic feeling. If only it lasted a little longer... Just when I found myself becoming attached to the characters and the story, the game ended, and I just wish there was a little more to it. Owlboy is not perfect, but the game deserves the praise it has received and is defintely worth the play. 9/10

number of helpful: 50 of 92 people (54%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
Owlboy definitely looks and sounds beautiful and has tons of polish, but unfortunately it fails with an underwhelming story and slow progression. There are some other questionable design decisions, too, that I'll go into a bit. This is some of the most breath-takingly beautiful pixel art, though. The musical score isn't far behind, either. Controller support was good, but the flying mechanic isn't novel enough to carry a whole game on. Maybe it would have been nine years ago when developement started, but it just suffers from the case of too-little-too-late IMO.Some of the strange design decisions include the hoops you fly through (and get money). Usually in flying games, the hoops are something to test your skill. You don't even fly through them quickly in this. It just feels odd. Why does it have to play a painfully slow animation everytime a gate opens. Yes, I know that probably took a lot of time and effort to do, but I don't need to suffer through it every time. There are also a few sort of goofy one-off 'mini game' (for lack of a better word) moments, such as getting you and your friend out of the spider webbing. Just felt forced, or at the very least, unnecessary.As far as the actual game, the story is real 'meh'. Is this really the best story that could have been crafted in nine years? No, I don't know the whole story, but what I saw was pretty forgettable. Felt like something Disney would crap out. The dialogue was well written, I will say that. A bit of side-dialogue from my brain thoughts: many people embraced the nine year developement as something really amazing. Like, perhaps this game aged like a fine wine or something lol. This isn't ToME with layers of complexity and lore that has been crafted over the years. Nine years is kind of embarrasing, really. The indie gaming industry changes fairly quickly, and I think this title suffered from the long dev cycle.Pros:+Beautiful artwork and soundtrack+Controller support is good+Very polishedCons:-The flying mechanic is not nearly enough to build a whole game on-The story was 'meh' as far as I had experienced it-Slow progression and slow animations/cutscenes IMO-A bit too pricey for the hours I see people get out of it (I refunded)I had hoped to fall in love with this one. Don't get it twisted - this isn't a 'bad' game by a long shot, it's just not some indie gem worth twenty bones. I'd watch some LetsPlays if you are on the fence.Peace,

content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												This game is short, but there's enough secrets and extra completionist tasks that warrant the price for this game. The story is enveloping, and one of the best story-puzzle platformer games I've played since the Legend of Zelda series. Portal, and others. I think it's one of the great games of our time and I hope it gets reception and notoriety as big as Undertale. This is a very worthwhile experience of a game that I've had the pleasure to play. If it means anything, this is the second game that has made me cry (MGS ending was the first), and I have played more emotional heart-strung games like Flower, Undertale, Fire Emblem, Golden Sun to give a few examples. Describing the story in any way ruins the magic, but I'll give a few details. IThe plot of the story and how it progresses can seem like a given halfway through the story, and if you have played many story games, it may seem a bit predictable. However, the atmosphere of the world makes up for these potential shortcomings, and I think works in its favor. The plot and story line is motivating enough to make the player want to drive on through the world as fast as they can, but I urge you to try and take your time and appreciate the work done around the enviorment. It left me awestruck how well each area was designed.TL;DR Do you wish more games were like OOT were out? This is one of them. Get it.

content:
Posted: April 10
												This is another case where I wish there was a "neutral" option when reviewing a game. On the plus side, Owlboy is a beautiful game. Otus controls well,  picking up new allies whilst playing through the game was motivating, and altogether the game was a relatively enjoyable experience. I understand the development that this game went through, and I think that it makes this game all-the-more inspirational.Despite all of this I couldn't bring myself to recommend this to everyone, so therefore I cannot leave a thumbs-up. Don't get me wrong, the game is a relatively good platformer. It looks good, it plays good, and the fact that it was created at all is incredible.There are a few small nitpicks here and there. Thanks to the art style some of the jumps can be frustrating, and Otus' rolls never quite seem to make it. I don't care about these things, however. Again, the game controls amazingly well anyway, and any small frustrations caused by them only last a minute or two.My reasoning is that the game is incredibly unfulfilling to the moderate gamer. Casual gamers will have a blast reading through the story and enjoying taking the game one step at a time. Hardcore gamers might get bored, but Owlboy clearly has some potential for them a long as they are patient.This game is incredibly unfulfilling, even tedious to the middle-of-the-road gamers. This is not because the game is bad, but because it is both a puzzle-action platformer AND a collect-a-thon.The smallest issue I had with the game came in the form of the monsters. Any monster not part of a puzzle was practically worthless. This is fine by itself: add some filler monsters to add some life between getting from point A to point B, but then the collect-a-thon bit comes in.While playing the game players will find coins littered around everywhere. Reaching certain coin milestones will grant rewards, although they are entirely unnecessary to beating the game. Still, getting gun upgrades and the such is usually worth it, and coins tend to be everywhere. The is a finite number of them, however, and this is where things took a dive.For as quick paced as the game can become during key moments Otus is SLOW when trying to move around the gargantuan overworld. If you want to find EVERYTHING the game has to offer get ready to triple your playtime. If you expected to play through the game casually and then collect everything you must first figure out how to turn your brain off.Because you WILL spend hours just circling around the same dungeon over and over again to find the last 10 coins you need.And then you will spend 5 minutes to get back to the next dungeon.And then you will spend another hour or so going through that one.I don't think that this sort of thing is bad by itself. Collect-a-thons are usually tedious anyway, so that's all fine. In the end, I collected all three owl thingies and put them in their corresponding pillar thingy. This is when I started questioning my decision to do so.Many similar games that require you to re-explore dungeons give you something as a reward. An alternate ending, perhaps. Maybe it'll grant you some special power, or maybe it'll be the final nail-in-the-coffin to figuring out the story.I got nothing. Just a few holograms that gave me some information I already knew. I felt like I might have missed something, perhaps I needed to go through the end of the game cutscene for my reward. Still, nothing. There isn't anything else to find. No alternate endings, no bonus cutscenes, just the credits and back to the title screen.I didn't even bother getting all of the regular coins. You can see the reward before you nab them all anyway: just a spiffy looking cloak, probably some funny dialogue along with it. I wasn't going to try watching and re-watching a youtube walkthrough a million times to find out.In the end, playing through the game itself wasn't so bad. It slowed down painfully at times, but it was okay nonetheless. The pixel art is great, and if you just collect the extras that you come across you probably will enjoy yourself.If I could go back in time, this is the information that I would have told myself. I've spent hours of extra gametime flying back-and-forth in the world to no avail. But my biggest complaint is that there was no real reward for doing so, at least not any award that was worth the extra hours gone to waste. If you wish to buy the game: play through, enjoy yourself, and if there is anything that would be tedious to do, don't do it.

content:
Posted: January 30
												A fun game with some tight mechanics. The collectables aren't TOO hard to find, with only a few things here and there being hidden a bit too well. The hardest was definitely hitting all the rings on the cannon challenge... and FINISHING the cannon challenge! It's too fast with too many screen switches and blind turns!The story is relatively simple, and while I think the ending was lack-luster (no spoiers), the bad-guys are fun, the allies are fun, and there are some seriously emotional moments, and 'Holy Crap' visuals. And the MUSIC! Good soundtrack, for sure. Overall, the experience was a fun one.Pros:Controls are tight and responsiveMusic is FANTASTICVisuals capture the feeling of what's happening very well, and are a love-letter to classic bit-style graphics of the late genesis/SNES, early PS1 days.Metroidvania style gameplay that works well.Right from the start YOU CAN FLY!!!!Cons:Story is a bit simpleThe 'twist' kind of detracts from the storyFights can sometimes be a bit chaotic when needing to swap between partnersSCREW THE CANNON CHALLENGE!A bit short. Completed the game 100% in just over 10 hours, and that was with taking in the scenery.Very linear. Little to no replayability, outside of just wanting to experience the visuals and story again.My score would be a 8/10. Good game that is a little short for how long it was in development, but the visuals and the music, as well as the tight controls make it a great game. $25 price is a bit high, but $20 is good. Buy it on sale, or wait for a price reduction.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
												+ Highly polished graphics+ Fun and engaging gameplay+ Immersive world; lots of tiny details (e.g. birds, rustling grass, etc.)+ Excellent and memorable cast of characters+ Good puzzles+ Good soundtrack+ Great story+/- Difficulty varies from area to area+/- Gameplay feels both smooth and clunky (in some areas)- Lackluster ending- Some bugs here and there- Feels incomplete on the whole; lots of loose ends- A bit short; the game can be completed 100% in less than 15 hoursAdditional notes:On the whole, I think the game was worth it and I would recommend grabbing this game. Gameplay progression is excellent - new mechanics are continually introduced as you progress so it doesn't feel tedious at all. The story hearkens back to the good old days where the story revolves around saving the world from an impending threat. The world building is complex and deep enough to leave you interested. I personally love the protagonists in this game, each has a fleshed out backstory so that you can relate to them to some extent. Most of the villains are terrible, only one of them was well written, the rest feels rushed and uninteresting.Game has a lot of puzzles in it which are not so easy that you would breeze through it and not so difficult that would leave you stuck in the same puzzle for hours. It's got the right amount of difficulty, enough to get your brain to function and think. The gameplay was innovative, I guess, but the gimmick is really nothing special. It plays well, however, and the gimmick is implemented well enough such that it feels natural after the first hour of gameplay.The biggest letdown to me was the ending. It felt rushed, incomplete, and unsatisfying. I wore a blank face throughout the ending sequence - the development was too sudden and random that I was suddenly felt detached from the story. The world building also feels incomplete; too many questions are left open and never explained throughout the game. There are some areas in the game where you would think may hide some secret lore, but instead what you get is a blank map with nothing in it.That's all there is to it - the (very memorable) story on the whole is excellent (I absolutely loved everything from the start of the journey until just before the final stage) which more than makes up for the terrible ending. The graphics as well! It's practically pixelated wallpaper: the game as the graphics are consistently top-notch all throughout. Despite some setbacks I think the good points outweigh the bad so I will recommend buying this game.

content:
Posted: January 19
												It is no secret that I have a huge love for both indie games and emotional games.Owlboy from the Norwegian developer D-Pad Studio manages to capture everything I love in games. From beautifully crafted pixel-art visuals and wonderful music, through its amazing gameplay that combines elements from Zelda, Metroid and flying games to its humor, emotional moments and great and often relatable characters. The first few minutes themselves managed to make me love the game. PresentationI dare to say that Owlboy is one of the best looking games of 2016. The pixelart is this game is often breathtaking. The attention to detail, beautiful scenery and really nice looking and expressive sprites with a sort of Zelda-esque style make the game really pleasing for the eye.10/10As for the soundtrack, it's equally beautiful with many wonderful orchestral pieces mixed with some ocasional electronic bits. The music often manages to build up atmosphere and sometimes even play on your emotions.10/10GameplayThe best way to describe the gameplay is that it's a mix of Zelda and Super Metroid where you can fly. One of the main features is carrying things while flying which has many uses in solving puzzles etc. You also get to carry your buddies who will, for the most part, be attacking the enemies for you. On your adventure you'll get to explore the world including several big open areas and a few big dungeons, full of puzzles, challenges and a lot of secrets, some of which are hard to find. It all works nearly perfectly with some very minor issues. The game isn't the longest, but it's an acceptable length for this type of game, especially if you want to enjoy the game to its fullest by 100% completing it.9.5/10StoryNot gonna reveal anything about the story as I think it's best to experience it without any spoilers, but all I can say is that in many ways, it is similar to games like Mother 3 or Undertale, with very memorable and often very relatable that you really care about, many humorous moment as well as emotional moments that might drive you to tears. It might not be everybody's cup of tea, but I hold games like this really, really dear.9/10Overall: 10/10

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 7, 2016
												From its artwork, to its music, to its atmosphere, to its story, to its characters and their interactions, Owlboy is one of the most beautiful games I've ever played.  I didn't want it to end.  As clever, fun, and full of surprises as the main adventure is, perhaps the moments I treasure the most are moments that were entirely optional to the completion of the game.My dislikes are few and minor.  There are some startling, frustrating difficulty spikes at times.  I had to backtrack through every area in the game hugging every wall and defeating every enemy to obtain all the coins for Buccanary's shop, and even then, there were things that I missed and secrets that were perhaps a bit *too* well-hidden.  But I can forgive this, partly because the coins and secrets are optional, and partly because scouring every inch of the game to find them allowed me to spend more time in its tranquil, rich, whimsical world.Few games have as much heart visibly poured into every detail as Owlboy, and I'd recommend it to anyone.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
												This game gives me THAT feeling... The one that can be commonly associated with indie titles. You know the one. No? Let me elaborate.After breezing through Owlboy in 7 hours, I can safely say that I was not satisfied with the game, and only artsy indie-only ♥♥♥♥♥♥s will come out of the game thinking "yeah, this was worth my money. Poor Indie devs took like 10 years man!". I got this game at the lowered price of $20, and even at this price I will warn you that Owlboy is not worth anything higher than say, $10. Now that I have prefaced this, let me get into some of the issues. - THE BAD - First off, this game controls like garbage. This astounds me, because there are not that many controls in the first place. The worst thing I had to deal with during my boring journey was that YOU HAVE TO ♥♥♥♥ING ROLL FIRST IN ORDER TO SPRINT. This ruins so many things by extention. Because your movement speed is worthless, you will unfortunately be encouraged by the game to spam rolls constantly, inhibiting precise movement and making a really, really ♥♥♥♥ing annoying sound. Once you begin to move about the world this way or as slowboi, you'll notice something else. This game feels... Empty. This is due to many things, such as:1. Few Enemies2. Low Enemy Diversity3. Pointless NPCs4. Weak Worldbuilding5. Few Collectibles (Coins and ♥♥♥♥ discs)6. Lore = Three ~5 page books* (like 10 words per page), and some dumb♥♥♥♥ lorenerd.7.. Gorgeous open areas... With nothing to do in them.About that "feeling". This is what causes it, and is the second largest reason for my not recommending this game. It is the feeling you might get from, say, a unity built game that looks pretty, but lacks purpose and substance. You feel alone. It feels wrong, Owlboy! Don't do this to me! - THE MEDIOCRE - Those two problems are by far the worst, but this game has plenty of other issues.Combat - Can be quite boring, and tends to be floaty. The bosses in this game are meh. Of the companions you will pick up, only one is really quite effective for combat. Others are either backup, waiting for this other companion to reload, or primarily used to get through lazy metroidvania style blockages in the world. Characters - You won't get attatched to anyone in this game, and you certainly won't care about their mortality. All of them are either painfully boring, total♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ or don't get enough screentime to be used effectively. When I started this game, I really wanted to care about these characters. But, by the end, I didn't care about any of them.Story - SPOILERS  Basically ♥♥♥♥♥♥ poor man's Bastion with owls and less memorable characters and events. So little from the story is important enough to remember after finishing this game. There was one moment that I thought I enjoyed - where you go up and hug your teacher, after escaping from the pirate HQ. I thought 'hey, that's kind of cute'. But besides that, nothing really sticks out storywise. Owlboy's story suffers from a few major plotholes here and there, but I can excuse them due to the sometimes wacky nature of the game. What I cannot excuse, is the♥♥♥♥♥♥poor pacing. It is extremely noticeable, especially at these points: Everything after advent, Recruiting Spiderboi, and the non-fight with Molstrom. The only good buildup this game ever dedicates to properly is the fight with Dirk.  - THE GOOD - Now that everything else is out of the way, let me say something good about the game. This game is similar to a lot of indie games coming out these days, in that it banks on pixel art to draw people in. And truth be told, this game is actually quite gorgeous. Not as good as something like Hyper Light Drifter (a game that actually plays well AND has good art), but still pretty nice to look at. I guess most of those 10 years in development were spent drawin trees, aye?And, though somewhat generic, this game does actually have a decent soundtrack. It's orchestral, and can sometimes aid the world in feeling large, even sometimes managing to make your journey feel "epic". It is not, do not be fooled by the good music. TL:DR Owlboy is not worth $20. Pick it up if it goes on sale for $10 or less. It suffers from bad controls, an empty world, weak combat, bad characters, and a dull story. However, it does have good art and music.

content:
Posted: January 14
												I played many platformer/metrovania games before and I honestly didn't enjoy the game "Owlboy" for many reasons.I was really disappointed by the game after reading so many good reviews.This will mainly be a list of pros and cons based on my personal opinions about the game but I will try to explain some of them.Pros- amazingly beautiful pixel art- nice soundtrack - story was quite niceCons- controls are mediocre- gameplay feels lackluster¹- collectibles feel like non-existent²- nice gameplay elements or sections are usually only used once in the whole game- more annoying enemies than actually well designed ones (gameplaywise)³- some animations are really annoying and disturbing1: You can have multiple friends that you can carry around, drop them somewhere, pick them up again and use their weapons. Those friends can be called and send away with some kind of ancient teleport device. You can imagine the many possibilities this could be used for. In reality you just use them like one time each when they join your team, the rest of the game they are just used as your weapon or to clear paths that you cannot take otherwise. The most part of the game they feel useless.2: I like achievements and collectibles etc very much and I was sad to see that there were no collectible at all except normal coins (which there are a limited number of) and 3 big coins. With coins you can buy up to 8 items. Five of them are stat upgrades the rest are cosmetics. These cosmetics are temporary and lost the next time you take damage. After collecting everything you get one item that increases your utility...3: I don't care about hard games having frustrating enemies but I feel in this game they are completely unnecessary since you have no real disadvantage of dying. (You just get set back to the beginning of the room) My point here is that having actually well designed enemies would be much more profitable to the game than ones that chase you through multiple screens even though there is nothing to get from them anymore.All in all the game felt really nice in the beginning but went downhill in the middle. At some point the awesome art style couldn't really compensate the unsatisfying gameplay. I don't think good art style is necessary if the gameplay is good but this game just felt like it tries to justify underwhelming gameplay with a really amazing art style.Remember this is just my honest opinion about the game so you may like it but I didn't and I still don't think this game is worth ~20 bucks.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2016
Product received for free
												This game was not what I expected and disappointing in many ways, but I also like it a lot. I’ll try to explain my reaction with some examples.First of all, I was expecting an old school platformer. It’s not a platformer, but rather a dual stick exploration shooter. I expected Owlboy to be the main character, but you mostly interact by carrying around other characters that are sort of your weapons and gadget.I loved the action, music, and art in their other game Savant, but this game isn’t quite like any of those. There are a few boss battles, but only one set pieces that’s crazy enough to be like Savant. The music is beautiful, but orchestrated rather than hard hitting dub step. The pixel art is similar and character designs are great, but I don’t love it like I expected to. Later on I realized I needed to enable letterboxing which fixed the aspect ratio and vastly improved the look of the art, but it’s still not quite what I expected. The rotating arms for twin stick aiming really throws me off and kills the look for me.It turns out that it feels much more of an homage to Zelda games or even Okami and really finds its grove in the middle. The puzzles and pacing is perfectly design. Everything feels like it was meticulously design to live in this world and it all fits together perfectly. The story is very grandiose and really pulls you through some massive events and character growth. The written dialog is top notch, funny when it needs to be and to the point.And then at the end it suddenly turns into the old school platformer that I expected at the beginning, and by that point I don’t really want it. A really odd choice and somewhat unsatisfying end. But the journey is great. There’s so many unique environments and no filler. It’s weird enough that it’s tough to recommend, but there’s also nothing else out there like it. Owlboy is the best Owlboy game I’ve ever played.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 19, 2016
												PLEASE NOTE: the following is my review of the game and MY opinion about the game. If you don't feel the same way that I do, please consider that this is only my opinion, and that it's completely fine if you don't agree. It won't change my mind. ...Where do I even begin with this game?...Owlboy. You don't think much of a title like that right away...But then this game pulled me in. I heard about this game from VideoGameDunkey, in his PAX video I believe. I saw the art and thought it was intriguing, as I am a big fan of art, whether it be music or visual art, or otherwise. Seeing that the game had come out recently, I bought it and started playing it. What I found was a great journey of many emotions and many wonders. I honestly felt like a child again playing this game. Owlboy pulled me in right from the start. I was interested in the characters, their plights, and I wanted to like everybody. And honestly, I did. I can safely say I like EVERY character in this game, good or bad, for different reasons.The art and the music is just simply breathtaking. I found myself getting lost exploring this world the whole way through. Quirky characters, funny items (play the game you'll understand), and the journey that was taken with friends. Owlboy makes you love every single friend you make in this game. Now, this all might be fine and good, but what about THE GAMEPLAY? I can assure you, the gameplay is great. It blends so many elements of metroidvanias, zelda-esque puzzle-solving, and platforming together seamlessly into one nice ball of fun. The bosses are all exciting, encourage solving another puzzle, and keep you gripped on the story. Play this game for about thirty minutes, and you'll see what I mean.D Pad Studios, if you guys are reading this, you spent a great 9 years making this game. I can't thank you enough. PLEASE, I IMPLORE YOU, consider porting this game to consoles, as other people should experience this wonderful masterpiece of an indie game. Any other developers that are out there playing this or considering this competition in any way, THIS IS HOW YOU DESIGN A VIDEO GAME. So many game developers today lose sight of how to design in an effort to rush a product out to grab cash quick. This game has been in development 9 years, and it's probably the best game I've ever played. No hyperbole, and no sarcasm.In conclusion, Owlboy is a fantastic journey through a beautiful world with rich scenery, a great soundtrack, WONDERFUL characters and an absolutely wonderful story that will have you on the edge of your seat the whole way through. My only gripe with this game, is that I wish I had more. This game gets a 10/10 from me, and that's a hard score to come by from me these days. Thank you so much for making Owlboy, developers. All I want to do is jump back in and play the story again.

												Absolutely gorgeous and a total blast. Infinite flight in a metroidvania-ish game is an interesting take and the developers have pulled it off excellently. If this seems like the kind of game you'd be into, then play it immediately.If I had to say one thing bad about it, the exploration aspects are kind of a pain in the neck. Most of the secrets are of the dull "rub your face into every single wall in the game" type. That's only really an issue if you try to 100% it though, and even then it's not a huge one.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												Okay, so... I pretty much knew very little about this game when I picked it up. I was aware that the plot was a big deal and that it was considered to be a good game. I wasn't disappointed.Let me get something out of the way: the story was, indeed, quite amazing. The narrative goes from the main character being a screw up to showing everyone that he was much more than just a kid by the end, and it has an overall feel-good tone all along. The musical score is also brilliant and uplifting (no pun intended, since you fly around as the titular owl boy Otus). The store page didn't lie about the boss fights: each and every one, considering how simple the game mechanics are, feel well balanced and engaging from the very first one.That said, Owlboy feels a bit short for an averagely skilled gamer used to exploration games with puzzles. The main source of longevity for the title is just in going through the story again because otherwise it's all about the collectathon for the 100%. Picture this: every area has some coins, which basically once you reach certain amounts you get health upgrades and QoL upgrades for the guys you use as gunners. The final upgrade in this chain grants you invulnerability (no joke!), which by the time you do get it you'll use it for the otherwise considerably-hard final encounter. If you ignore looking for every collectable and just do the actual game you might clock in at around 5 or so hours; that's not bad, but you can understand where I'm coming from, likely.It should be noted that dying in this game is litterally a minor setback with practically no consequences, given how you are restored to full health and the game likes to auto-save a lot on area transitions and clearing things (such as unlocking a door or collecting some thingamajig).Should you buy it? I guess. It is a good game, after all. The music really is great and the story is memorable. There's a funny moment here and there so it's not too bad. The post-ending extra area that clues you in on some very important key points of the plot also feels well done.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1
												Owlboy review:Owlboy is an action/adventure gsme where you play as a little owl called otus. Otus is seen as a good for nothing by his fellow owl students and his teacher asio since he makes many mistakes while learning to become a proper owl. Though otus does have one friend geddy. Geddy is a human unlike otus but they get along very well. our story begins whit asio waking up otus. He informs otus that they have overwatch duty and have to watch for pirates. Suddenly a random trouble maker shows up and otus and geddy start to chase said trouble maker. They run into a cave where they find a weird looking relic. Geddy decides to chip a piece of the relic and to there suprise geddy starts to teleport. this is a big mechanic in the game but more on that later. when Geddy and otus find there way out of the cave there are pirates every where. This leads into a stealth section where you cannot get spotted. Otus and Geddy manage to flee there town safely and our adventure begins. Alot more happens in the story over all and i found the story to be compelling. Story:7.5/10 charming characters and good lore.Gameplay wise Owlboy is a blast to sit down and play. Otus cant really do anything to protect himself but that is were geddy comes in. Geddy has a blaster that he can use against enimies that is why the teleporting mechanic is so important. being able to teleport Geddy and eventualy other partymembers by your side by pressing the E button is seemless and works really well. other than that there are many different puzzles to solve through out the story. The puzzles were never chalenging but fun non the less. There are also a few memerable boss fights. They are both challenging and uniqe. Gameplay 8/10 challenging fun The best part about owlboy by far is the presentation. The sprites are fantastic and the music is amazing in every way. It took the develepors 10 years to make this game and the sprites are probaly a big reason for that.Presiontation 10/10 Fantastic Verdict: Owlboy is a game whit a breif but compelling story with charming characters and fun dialouge. The gameplay is different, Challenging and Fun. The presiontation is amazing with beatiful sprites and music that made me stopplaying and just listen. And with all that in mind i give owlboy an overall score of:9/10 PLAY IT NOW

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10
												Fantastic game, whose art style and charming - if simple - narrative direction lends size and gravitas to a world that is actually much smaller than it first appears. I completed the game wishing I could spend a little more time in this world.The characters all have a rough, silly charm. It's an adventure of misfits coming into their own. In the way the story unfolds, it becomes clear that all characters have a certain real dimension often lacking from the cardboard cutouts featured in some AAA releases.The pixel art is breathtaking, and I look forward to more "hi-bit" games in the future. The mix of chiptunes and orchestral music help transition scenes from video-gamey exploration and combat to heavier, emotional scenes that convey tragedy, majesty, joy, or melancholy.Gameplay is fun. It was probably a challenge to make such a free-movement system feel challenging, but with the use of clever barriers and the unique companion system, the game can really become challenging.Perhaps most importantly, the game is rich in secrets and lore. Finding coins, while sometimes frustrating, is a rewarding endeavor. In a game like this, no pixels are out of place, so pay attention to subtle details like the movement of insects or the prominent foreground look to some walls. The last lore reveal is tragic, terrible and beautiful. I never felt like the game was wasting my time.All-in-all a great game, doesn't overstay its welcome, and hopefully an inspiration for future indy projects. 9/10, great for most gamers.(Side note - I played with a controller and found it a little more fluid than mouse and keyboard, fwiw)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10
												I could talk about the amazing and unique gameplay that is constantly evolving throughout the game. I could talk about the amazing soundtrack. I could talk about the amazing story and lore. I could talk about the amazing characters and character development.But all I really want to say is, how dare you make an ending that emotional? And not just the ending-ending when you've stopped playing and the credits roll. Nah. The WHOLE ending. I've never made so many uncomprehendable noises towards my computer screen in my life.... so yeah. Good job.

content:
Posted: January 28
												Never would I have thought that a 2d platformer could jerk a tear from my eye. Without going into spoilers, this is a story of redemption and friendship. Characters evolve in a way that makes sense and feels right. In terms of mechanics the game feels very good. Platforming is a little bit janky sometimes with Otus not exactly doing what you want him to but nothing game breaking. Level design is superb and the puzzles, though quite simple, add a bit of fun to the general exploring. Overall a must buy in my opinion and since you could probably run this with a bag of chips as a gpu and a hamster wheel as a processor, you honestly have no excuse not to.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
												Spectacular, Amazing, and extremely fun to play.The absolutely beautiful 32-bit graphics made me feel nostalgic all the way through the game, and put detail and life throughout every area that you explore. The emotional, and occasionally touching cutscenes really do make you care about the wonderful, and diverse characters that you meet. The gameplay mechanics were perfect in almost every aspect. Everything comes together in this incredible adventure that you have with Otus.It's not hard to tell that this game has had a lot of tender love and care put into it throughout its long development cycle of nine years, because this is one of the best games I've played this year.100/10 An experience that you simply cannot miss.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2016
												Owlboy was a charming and beautiful little game that I very much enjoyed. For me, the game was a good difficulty level - it presented a decent challenge while not causing me to rage-quit. The characters are cute and had many moments throughout the game that were lighthearted and amusing, as well as dark, which made me feel a full range of emotions. I cannot compliment the artwork and music enough. This game is gorgeous, especially when one single person created all of the pixel work!That being said, this game is not perfect. The story is interesting, but not overly so. And while the game is beautiful, a lot of the areas felt a bit empty. I was able to 100% this game in 10-12 hours. That is something to keep in mind if you are thinking about return on investment. Still, I would definitely recommend this game.

												Very polished, well done indie adventure game. From the character design, level design, visual themes, music, gameplay, the story - everything about this game is well done. I'm not sure how to better articulate it...The gameplay teaches you the correct way - no tutorial. Instead, its a story you play through that requires you to do certain things. You naturally learn on your own terms how to play the game through actually playing the game.The puzzles are intuitive and engaging.The combat allows you to approach from many different angles.The story is SO well tied together with so many layers of depth (this will especially be true if you go through the trouble of discovering all of its secrets hidden throughout the world).

												Definitely a very fun to play game with somewhat unique mechanics and a good story that keeps you playing on. The visual style is adorable and feels very pleasant, the animations and expressions of the characters feel very well made. The music is good and adds to the general atmosphere and feel of the game.I haven't finished the game yet, but I do feel that there could be more done when it comes to the items that upgrade Otus and his friends, more choice to what you can do and how that helps or does not help you in your quests. I play the game with a logitech controller and it's quite fine but I don't like the aiming with right stick, it feels quite difficult to pull off for some reason, especially when you have to aim quite precise (Twig).I did ran into some bugs, such as getting knocked into a wall and not getting out of it, and sometimes the audio disappears for a few moments, and sometimes the cutscenes are loading really long. But overall, these are minor issues and should definitely not hold you back from giving Owlboy a shot.

												✓ || Dust and Elysian Tail || ✓✓ || Ori and the blind forest || ✓✓ || Undertale || ✓✓ & ✘ || Owlboy || ✓ & ✘Owlboy is a great game, it's more fixated on the atmosphere and character development more so than the gameplay which I both loved and disliked and puzzles which are not all that impressive for a platformer in 2016. The game was short...(for a 10 year game in the making that's kinda lame, yes yes you'd like to see me try and make a game like this.)What I mean is the game has nothing to offer once you complete it, and takes a mere 5-6 hours to complete. But this is just me, since I play a lot of JRPG's and such that always end up being a minimum of 30-40-50 hours to complete and 100+ hours to finish 100% that also offer deep back story and sometimes the ability to change history not to mention a NG+ with bonus content. But again that's just me being picky. TL;DRIt's a wonderful "SHORT" game, that will make any reader / fantasy adventure fanatic roll around for. If you're into the whole punch people in the face aspect of gaming, you're going to get bored real fast.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 21
 I'm going to warn readers now that there will be spoilers for the game's ending. I will mark spoiler territory with a spoiler sign. BackgroundOwlboy is an indie platformer developed by D-Pad Studio. It has been in development since 2007 and was relesed November 2016. PlotThe plot of Owlboy is set in the land of the sky and the islands of the world below has been separated by a catastrophic event. You play as Otus, an owl-human hybrid race called Owls. The game has a unique mechanic in the fact that Otus cannot really defeat any enemies, just stun them. Luckily, you get the help of your best friend Geddy, whom you'll be able to carry around and shoot enemies with his gun. Your duty as an owl is to guard your village from Pirates whom have recently united under a ferocious leader named Molstrom.ReviewLet's start by pointing out the obvious; the game is bloody gorgeous. The pixel-art for this game looks amazing and it is, in my opinion, one of the prettiest looking games I've ever seen. The world of Owlboy is extraordinarily pretty and the attention to detail is amazing. The characters all have their unique design which, in turn, makes all of them very memorable. The game's writing is also something you have to thank for that however, since all the characters have their own unique written personality. The people you meet all feel like genuine and real people.The soundtrack is great. It's not perfect, it's a rare thing that games pull that off, but the people behind the orchestral tracks of Owlboy has done a great job on tracks that are supposed to be more happy and adventurous, my favorite being the Tropos Day music. Unfortunately I can't really mention any boss themes that I found memoreable, but on an overall scale, I'd say that it's one of the best I've heard in recent years.The gameplay is simple. You fly, walk, shoot, jump, roll. Basic stuff. You have to fight your way through many bosses and puzzle your way through ancient dungeons. If I have to criticize something, it's the fact that a lot of the puzzles are too easy. The fact that you can fly makes a lot of the platforming almost non-existant. However, the boss fights are interesting, they are fast-paced and they are exciting. The pacing during fights can be a bit off sometimes, as there are bosses with attacks that are way too fast for a first-timer. Bosses should start easy, then scale up in difficulty, but Owlboy unfortunately often throws too much at the start of the fight and then doesn't up the difficulty enough to make the fight truly feel like a threat.Enemy variety gets a bit stale, but seeing how the game focuses around puzzles and platforming, it's not much of an issue.The story of Owlboy is simple. As I've mentioned above, the characters you meet during your journey really is what makes this game interesting. However, if you come to this game and expect a story as deep and touching as Undertale, you're wrong. The story works well, it has its plottwists and touching moments, but unfortunately it feels rushed. The pacing feels off sometimes and there are moments where you're supposed to get deep emotions, but because the pacing is too fast, you don't get enough time to attach to things. There are of course moments where you do genuinly feel sad or touched, but not as often as the game would like you to.Spoilers for the game's story up ahead.  The perfect example for this feeling of rushed is when the capital, Advent, gets destroyed during the pirate attack. The whole world around you is supposed to have been changed for the worst, but the player can't really feel much sympathy or sadness cause you do not know enough about the world to really feel sad for it. The whole story about the pirate threat feels rushed too, since one does not get proper establishment that they exist and they are a threat. The game just throws it in your face that "Boom, they're here, they're bad, deal with it."The ending is also something I have to criticize. Because of the pacing, the ending feels unsatisfying. Your part of the whole saving the world scenario is explained to not really matter. Solus, the 'Final boss' of the game, is explained to have just tried to save the world from floating up into space all along and one also realizes that your role is pretty useless. Solus' plan would've worked even without you interfering and the only thing Olus' does is actually almost ruining the whole thing. Your sacrifice in the end is pretty lame, due to the fact that the only thing you really did was to amend your own mistake. It doesn't make any sense either that Solus doesn't explain his intentions from the start. If he truly meant good, say so, don't just run away without explaining it.Spoiler territory over. Speaking as a person who cannot buy everything I want, 22.99€ is quite a price for an 6 hour game. After beating the game, I don't really have any feelings of wanting to go back to collect every item or coins either. The Bougin challenge is not fun either. Final Thoughts and Verdict It seems like I've been bashing the game more than I have been praising it, but I am really fond of this game. It's not going to be the next big hit like some might've expected, but it is an extremely polished game with some of the best visuals and characters that has come out over the recent years. The music is good, the visuals are fantastic and the characters are memoreable. I do highly recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of platformers or just wants to have a good time, cause you'll certainly find it in this game. The 9 years of development time has certainly paid off in this happy and touching touching about one little Owl.

												This game is splendid. Absolutely beautiful. The moment I saw it, I knew I had to play it even if I had to buy it during release. And that's saying something because I'm very cautious with how I spend my money and I can say I am not disappointed. The gameplay unique and the scenery has that vibe similar to other platformer series I love such as Rayman and Megaman Zero and ZX. Story is beautiful and l am at a loss for words on how else to define the game. The story is long enough to enjoy the game and offers point collecting and unlocks for the diehard completionists. The music is amazing and fits every moment in the game. I love the soundtrack so much I had to buy the soundtrack after I only paid for the base game. All I say is this game is very beautiful. I can't say it enough. I would rate the game a perfect 10/10 and doesn't have alot of cons, if any, whatsoever. I'd recommend buying the OST pack as well because the soundtrack is absolutely gorgeous.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2016
												Owlboy is a game that traditional platforming fans might find lacking,  as there is not much in the way of challenging platforming sections in the game's ~6 hour runtime. Most of the challenging platforming is concentrated in the last hour. The mechanics of the game (infinite flight for the protagonist) naturally make it difficult for the developer to create platforming sections that test the player's mastery of the game's physics. The platforming is not what I would call the game's strong suit, but it doesn't have to be- everything else is top notch.The pixel art is jaw dropping and backgrounds are frequently gorgeously animated. The music is a standard orchestral affair, and there are plenty of strong tracks within the soundtrack. The characters of the world are great- Otus, the main player character, is established early on as a sympathetic failure of an owl whom most characters brush off as useless or disappointing, especially so Otus' teacher, Asio. Otus starts out almost friendless, but the band of buddies Otus meets along his journey keep him in high spirits. My favorite surprise of the game was how expressive Otus was- despite being mute, he has a litany of facial expressions that keep him from just being a stonefaced protagonist. Every character in the game has great dialogue, especially so for Geddy, Otus' best bro. Geddy is the star character of the game scriptwise. He says the right stuff at the right times.The game does not last any longer than it needs to. It establishes the main conflict well within the first 20 minutes of the game and solves the conflict within a reasonable time period- should the game have lasted an hour longer, I imagine I would've started to feel the tedium of traversal in the game through the same areas weigh on me. The level design is about what you would expect it to be for a game featuring a flying protagonist- many floating islands in the hub-like areas and frequent linear sections limiting flight possibilities in the areas related to plot progression (though these flight limiting sections are often not as interesting as I would like them to be personally, but again it's not a dealbreaker). To that end, if you're expecting a hardcore or extremely difficult platforming experience with Owlboy, this game is simply not for you. Look elsewhere.However, if you want a nice 6 hour experience with amazing presentation that tells an engaging story with a great cast of characters....this is the right game for you. Is the game worth the 25 dollar price point? I'd say the value I would put it at is closer to 20 dollars.... Though of course, if your game is in development for 9 years, I suppose you really want to get your investment back sooner rather than later, so I can understand why the devs put the price point where they did.

												2 hours in and I found myself struggling to take a break. Almost a decade ago we were introduced to this promising classic take on a pixel 2d platformer(ish?) game and despite them working behind closed curtains I can honestly say it was worth the wait. I honestly only caught wind of the game's progress because a friend of mine mentioned it was well along development a few months back and could release in a matter of months. What do I have to say about the game itself? - Well, the protagonist is pretty nice. I genuinely felt a little bad for the fella in the beginning but he's currently off to make things right in the world of Owlboy. - The first few (mini?) boss fights I've encountered were kinda mindless. I literally stumbled into them, steamrolled the bosses and kept it moving without much thinking power.- The puzzles so far are somewhat interesting but a little straightforward. I'll save judgment for that for now though since I don't think I've even made it halfway through the game yet.- The soundtrack is oddly interesting with its differences. Some parts of the game are like chiptune-ish while others are like modern-day soundtracks. The inconsistency kinda throws me off sometimes in terms of immersion.I don't really like writing stupid long reviews so I just want to keep it short and simple as possible. 9 years of work right right here and it's visually appealing and plays well.
