content:
Posted: January 13
												If you like a certain genre of games, they sometimes can run together. You like Mega Man style jump and shoot games? That mechanic can get tiresome after a while, unless it’s changed up sometimes. What about rail shooters? They can be fun, but after ten of them you start to chafe under the yolk. Now, I love me some Metroidvania. Defined broadly as a story driven adventure game with a focus on exploration, getting new abilities through gameplay that allow you to find new areas of the game world. And seriously, any time I see that tag on steam I have to keep myself from clicking "buy now." I've failed on multiple occasions, of course; this stuff is like crack to me. I always have to have one ready to go… but even your favorite game become tired after a while. If the story is dull, if the characters aren't engaging, if the exploration is barely there... meh. Why even bother. So with all that said.BUY THIS GAME. DO IT NOW.I just finished it and I can say this was, without a doubt, a straight 18 hours of fun. So let’s get into it.The game’s story starts off simple. You play Otus, a young boy training to be an Owl. With a special cloak, you are able to fly and carry heavy loads, which is important because throughout the game your powers are based on which friend you are lifting into the sky. Now this is a really interesting take on gaining new abilities, which is a Metroidvania staple. You don’t just find a new item that lets you jump farther or destroy certain obstacles – you find a friend that helps you. I was struck particularly by this… Most of the time we are a hero on a journey through a strange world, and maybe someone comes along and helps at different times in the story. In Owlboy, the story is all about personal connections. Friendships, mentors, fellow students, enemies turned allies… Even your connection to your sense of self. Growing from a kid who is just trying to get through the day to a full blown savior of his village. The writing is impeccable, and it always returns to the main theme – friendship, cooperation, and loyalty to those you care about gives you the power to do anything.Visually, D-Pad decided to go with a style the call Hi-Bit. Using the look of a 16-bit era came, but incorporating modern aesthetics. 16 bit art doesn’t have the fluidity of motion or the depth that can be attained with current technology. Think games like Shantae or Fez. It’s not just paying homage to the era of the Genesis and Super Nintendo – its applying that style to enhance the atmosphere and experience.The game music is wonderful, and again enhances the overall atmosphere. It never seems repetitive, and the changes never seem jarring or out of place. When day turns into night (The game has a day/night cycle… and I don’t think it actually affects the gameplay, which is even cooler) the music shifts slightly until the sun rises again. The main theme has been running through my head all week.According to steam, this game clocked in at 18 hours. That is my playing through the main storyline, without seriously trying to be a completionist. I got most of the additional items, but could beat the game without them. I think a really good length for any game is about 20 hours, so this hits the sweet spot.Music, engaging story, loveable characters, and an interesting artistic style… this game hits all my buttons. If you like Metroidvania, if you like games that are challenging but not punishing, this is a wonderful choice.Rating: 5 out of 5 hours past bedtime. I’m glad I played this mostly over the weekend and on days off, I would have been screwed at work.

content:
Posted: February 2
												Game of the year material.Owlboy is a beautiful game with fluid, interesting, yet challenging gameplay. The characters you meet create a lot of variety in this department. Your ability to switch between them creates a very high skill celing, leaving even the best players the ability to improve, though the game isn't hard enough to require it by any means. The characters are also important to the story which is well presented, if a bit silly. The soundtrack is wonderful too, and worth picking up if one is into video game music, I would even say it puts the classics to shame.The game runs excellently, even on my somewhat old graphics card (GTX 660) and I am confident that you could run it on much lower end hardware with no problems. You only need openGL 3 so it will work on any card made in the last 10 years. I experienced no performance problems and my steam controller worked out of the gate with a great setup. I would highly recommend using a gamepad for this game, though it is not at all required.From what I have played, about two thirds, I would absolutely recommend this game.

												8/10.Its fun but it has some problems like the controls are pretty decent because right click stops you from flying teleports your team to you and also makes you throw stuff which other than that its fine.its WASDS to move  double click W to fly space to roll left click to spin E-Q and also the scroll to change guys. Then after that boss you fight a group of basically 1 shot enemies and I mean like 7 of them at once. Then literally before any other gameplay other than screwing in a screw you have to escape lava and physically right after that you fight another boss.The good stuff of it is that it looks nice and has good music the usual. Its the fun kind of challenging 90% of the time. Goodstory and characters I guess im too tired to go into detail. good night even tho its 4 o clock pm.Also there is a part while you ride a giant rock lava snake in a volcano and crash it into a wall . 10/10 best game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2016
												I am not very far into this game so I can't say much about the over all story but what I can say is this;      Owlboy is a "platformer" that will go down in history, I think. The animation is superb. The emotion that these 2d sprites can evoke is phenomenal. The general atmosphere is truly something to get lost in. While at first, I was getting some Fez vibes which, say what you will, can be a good or a bad thing, but very quickly I started to notice that that would not end up being the case. Characters have motive and purpose, and the setting is purposely set quite differently to the tone of the games characters. It's written much more like a good film from Pixar than it is like a typical platformer. I can't say yet whether it's worth the price tag but with the time and effort put into it, I can't really say there's any going wrong with buying this game. There is a lot of love behind it and it's easy to see. It's absolutely not for everyone but everyone should try it, nonetheless. Maybe it'll make a convert out of you.    I'll update the review as I get further (probably)

content:
Posted: January 13
												If you like a certain genre of games, they sometimes can run together. You like Mega Man style jump and shoot games? That mechanic can get tiresome after a while, unless it’s changed up sometimes. What about rail shooters? They can be fun, but after ten of them you start to chafe under the yolk. Now, I love me some Metroidvania. Defined broadly as a story driven adventure game with a focus on exploration, getting new abilities through gameplay that allow you to find new areas of the game world. And seriously, any time I see that tag on steam I have to keep myself from clicking "buy now." I've failed on multiple occasions, of course; this stuff is like crack to me. I always have to have one ready to go… but even your favorite game become tired after a while. If the story is dull, if the characters aren't engaging, if the exploration is barely there... meh. Why even bother. So with all that said.BUY THIS GAME. DO IT NOW.I just finished it and I can say this was, without a doubt, a straight 18 hours of fun. So let’s get into it.The game’s story starts off simple. You play Otus, a young boy training to be an Owl. With a special cloak, you are able to fly and carry heavy loads, which is important because throughout the game your powers are based on which friend you are lifting into the sky. Now this is a really interesting take on gaining new abilities, which is a Metroidvania staple. You don’t just find a new item that lets you jump farther or destroy certain obstacles – you find a friend that helps you. I was struck particularly by this… Most of the time we are a hero on a journey through a strange world, and maybe someone comes along and helps at different times in the story. In Owlboy, the story is all about personal connections. Friendships, mentors, fellow students, enemies turned allies… Even your connection to your sense of self. Growing from a kid who is just trying to get through the day to a full blown savior of his village. The writing is impeccable, and it always returns to the main theme – friendship, cooperation, and loyalty to those you care about gives you the power to do anything.Visually, D-Pad decided to go with a style the call Hi-Bit. Using the look of a 16-bit era came, but incorporating modern aesthetics. 16 bit art doesn’t have the fluidity of motion or the depth that can be attained with current technology. Think games like Shantae or Fez. It’s not just paying homage to the era of the Genesis and Super Nintendo – its applying that style to enhance the atmosphere and experience.The game music is wonderful, and again enhances the overall atmosphere. It never seems repetitive, and the changes never seem jarring or out of place. When day turns into night (The game has a day/night cycle… and I don’t think it actually affects the gameplay, which is even cooler) the music shifts slightly until the sun rises again. The main theme has been running through my head all week.According to steam, this game clocked in at 18 hours. That is my playing through the main storyline, without seriously trying to be a completionist. I got most of the additional items, but could beat the game without them. I think a really good length for any game is about 20 hours, so this hits the sweet spot.Music, engaging story, loveable characters, and an interesting artistic style… this game hits all my buttons. If you like Metroidvania, if you like games that are challenging but not punishing, this is a wonderful choice.Rating: 5 out of 5 hours past bedtime. I’m glad I played this mostly over the weekend and on days off, I would have been screwed at work.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2016
												What defines a good game?Storytelling?Level Design?Visuals?Well. you'll find a lot of that here in Owlboy.Let's start off simple, the Visuals. Owlboy is very Visually appealing. Every sprite looks crisp and clean. and fits into the world around it. The visals for the Floating Islands are just beautiful. Most importantly however, is that every character's design fits in with their personality. Overall, the Visuals are enough to pull in anyone who's a fan of the 16-bit Era of gaming. And maybe even some who aren't. Level Design, What makes a good level? Well. I tend to look at the 'Mega Man' Formula when it comes to level design. where you Introduce one gimmick at a time. and then expand upon it. And this game does it brilliantly. You never feel like you're thrust into situations unknowingly, without having prior experience with a GImmick to an area. (Although there are two exceptions - Which I won't get into here as they are late-game spoilers, All spoiler things will be at the bottom of the Review past 'Final Score') Enemy placement never feels unfair. If you take a hit, it's your own fault. and that's something I can get behind. Oh, and do you like Secrets? This game has plenty of little Secret rooms in which to find Collectibles. Another thing is that every room in the game's dungeons has some form of Puzzle to it. Be it simply dropping a block on a Pressure switch, or sneaking past enemies who would otherwise easily overpower you.Storytelling. That's the big thing, What's the story about? How does it reach it's end? Well, as the Spoilers are at an end I won't go too in depth. but the Story progresses like a novel. you have an Opening part where characters are established, then Conflict. then a solution. and then a bigger conflict pops up, then a solution, and a conflict. and then the climax in which the solution ties solely into the solutions for past conflicts. The storytelling is great - Although the game does suffer slightly from being an Open World. the story can say "You must rush to point A." And you can go off and find collectibles for two hours. and then stroll over to point A to continue the main plot. Also, be prepared for Feels, as this game will bring you on a small Rollercoaster of emotions. Not that that's ever a bad thing in a Story-driven game.Overall Scores.Visuals: 8/10 - I Personally adore the Sixteen Bit style of games, always have, always will. it's not for everyone.Storytelling: 9.5/10 - This game's storyline had me so interested, that I completed the game from start to finish in a single sitting.Level Design: 7/10 - The Level Design is overall good, however in some cases the 'Stealth Sections' you're introduced to can slightly irritate. Another slightly frustrating moment happens later on in the game - See 'Spoiler' Section below.I cannot recommend this game enough, It had me hooked enough to complete it in a single sitting. I recommend that anyone who loves this sort of thing do check this game out. It's one of the best games I've played since Dust: an Elysian Tail.~~Spoiler Section - Be Advised~~Level Design Complaint - Surfing the Robotic Dragon/Snake/Wyvern thing. Acting fast can be a problem for some, Especially when you can only move up and down in about five set places. this can cause you to scrape your head on the ceiling repeatedly. Which is painful, even at the Maximum Health Bar.Storytelling Spoilers: The protagonist is a mute who - despite all he does to try and help, messes up more often than not (Sometimes even just percieved as messing up by his teacher), So his teacher scolds him, Saying various things like "I am Very Dissapointed in you." "You're the worst student i've ever had" "Don't let me catch you coming back here." Also, the Ending. My god. the Ending, I'll keep spoilers low - Even if this is the Spoiler Section - But my god. that was such a Bittersweet sort of Ending. a very much "But at what cost" Type of ending.Also, Watching that Tin Soldier get vaporised when he's been built up as an unstoppable wall of Metal and Strength. so satisfying. Thanks devs. c:

content:
Posted: February 2
												Game of the year material.Owlboy is a beautiful game with fluid, interesting, yet challenging gameplay. The characters you meet create a lot of variety in this department. Your ability to switch between them creates a very high skill celing, leaving even the best players the ability to improve, though the game isn't hard enough to require it by any means. The characters are also important to the story which is well presented, if a bit silly. The soundtrack is wonderful too, and worth picking up if one is into video game music, I would even say it puts the classics to shame.The game runs excellently, even on my somewhat old graphics card (GTX 660) and I am confident that you could run it on much lower end hardware with no problems. You only need openGL 3 so it will work on any card made in the last 10 years. I experienced no performance problems and my steam controller worked out of the gate with a great setup. I would highly recommend using a gamepad for this game, though it is not at all required.From what I have played, about two thirds, I would absolutely recommend this game.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2016
												8/10.Its fun but it has some problems like the controls are pretty decent because right click stops you from flying teleports your team to you and also makes you throw stuff which other than that its fine.its WASDS to move  double click W to fly space to roll left click to spin E-Q and also the scroll to change guys. There is a lack of direction which is annoying for alot of people but i only found a problem with it halfway through the floating cave place its really bad and needs to have some direction in it. There is also no break from boss battles / events where I think in the spam of a 45 second part you fight a pretty hard boss but is easy once you got the pattern down but the third form has no direction yet again. Then after that boss you fight a group of basically 1 shot enemies and I mean like 7 of them at once. Then literally before any other gameplay other than screwing in a screw you have to escape lava and physically right after that you fight another boss.The good stuff of it is that it looks nice and has good music the usual. Its the fun kind of challenging 90% of the time. Goodstory and characters I guess im too tired to go into detail. good night even tho its 4 o clock pm.Also there is a part while you ride a giant rock lava snake in a volcano and crash it into a wall . 10/10 best game.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2016
												Owlboy is a beautiful, retro-inspired platformer that delivers fun and emotional story telling, a neat twist on platforming, and wonderful roster of characters. The gameplay is reminiscent of a more linear Metroid. This game does SO much right with just a few minor, albeit annoying, flaws slipping through the cracks. First off, this game is gorgeous. It totally captures the snes age, retro feel but with modern day pixels. Sprites are well designed and the landscapes are intuitive and fun to explore. The gameplay is very fun and pretty unique and discovering hidden areas feels very fulfilling. The buddy characters add a lot of dimension to exploration and combat and the teleportation mechanic is very well done. Iinitially, I was a little disappointed with the runtime. I beat this game from start to finish, while in no particular rush, in 7 hours. However, those 7 hours were so packed with content and fun I really can't complain. The pacing is top notch. There were multiple times where I intended to play for 30-45 minutes and ended up playing for 2 or more hours. The story really chugs along and gets you invested right off the bat. I highly recommend this game!!

content:
Posted: December 30, 2016
												Owl boy is like that blonde cheerleader from high school: you wait ten years for your chance to be with her, but, when the time comes, she's nothing but a pretty face. Owl boy is absolutely gorgeous. I'd read reviews, watched youtube videos, etc., and was well aware going in how pretty it was supposed to be. Nothing prepared me for the first zoomed out shot of the overworld. Jaw literally dropped. Then I started playing. Then I started waiting for it to be good. Then I started praying it would evenutally become good. It never did. Just like the blonde cheerleader, owl boy is gorgeous and overflowing with charm, but it doesn't have a single inch of depth. 90% of the game is spamming 'roll' to get around the map and holding the left mouse button. That's it. It never advances beyond that. Even the intermittent stealth scenes are just spamming 'roll' to move from obstacle to obstacle. That's it. No strategy, no skill, no challenge. The occasional puzzle and loads of spam. The emotional payoff of having a mute, mostly unrelatable protagonist doesn't payoff until the last scene. It's not worth 7 hours of playtime for a one minute cutscene of emotion. I hate every word of this review because I wanted so badly to enjoy this game and be able to support the indie devs putting in the hard work to make games we crave. But, sadly, this is even more lifeless than AAA action FPS games. I would not call this adventuring, platforming, or even 'tactical twin stick' as I have seen it described. D-Pad studio obviously has talent and knows how to make a game look good. I think they just forgot gameplay along the way. I want to say they forgot to have their game beta-tested for the 'fun-factor' before committing to it, but I doubt that's the case.

content:
Posted: January 19
												Owlboy was a game I honestly expected to be the big indie darling of the year. It looked fun, simple and beautiful. I was very ready to watch a brand new indie mascot emerge and hang with the likes of Meatboy, but sadly I feel Owlboy will be a soon forgotten character. It's visual art style is one of the few interesting parts of the game. Gameplay and overall game feel are terribly bland by comparison.Owlboy starts off in a lovely little town full of characters to talk to, houses to enter and small places to explore. This set a great tone for the game almost like that of a Zelda adventure, but it doesn't continue on this path. Although it continues to expand the lore and allow you to talk to a bigger cast of NPC's as you progress through the game, it starts to become a nuisance. I have a huge problem with the amount of exposition presented in the game. Most indie games with interesting lore (or even AAA games for that matter), give you the option to dive into the deep expository elements of the game. The key word is option. Owlboy chooses to make the story of the game unavoidable, with a false sense of importance. Especially for a game so short, I just don't care about the finer details of the 'owl lore'.The gameplay doesn't make up for this expostion overload. It lacks variety, despite seeming like it will have some with multiple companions. The game suffers mostly from a slow pace. The games flying mechanic is great at giving a sense of freedom, but the pace severly stunts this feeling. You'll be spending most of the game auto-targeting enemies and mashing the shoot button, with the occasional stealth section oddly enough. The game lacks any serious upgrade feature, and the shop acts mostly as a way to track your collectables. The few upgrades you do end up receiving happen later in the game, and judging by the difficulty of enemies and bosses, you wont really feel the difference. Most enemies are quite easy, and there's no real penalty for death.To end on a high note, I must stress how great the art style of this game is. The environments are always new and interesting, the characters are cool and well designed, and the game mixes a good variety of light and dark tones. I haven't seen an indie game in quite sometime that  has such a solid art design as this. It has no gimmicks and it serves no ultimate purpose to the gameplay. It's just beautiful.With all of this said, I hope to play future D-pad Studio games and enjoy them, taking the faults of Owlboy into consideration.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 15, 2016
												This game is a game that starts so well and I want to like it so badly but i just cannot. The graphics are really great they add so much to the game.The story starts really interestingly for first 30 minutes but it soon becomes really bad same with the characters at first you feel like this might be a platformer that has characters and story like monkey island but they soon lose their charm.I am on the last level of the game currently and I just want it to end and i have felt this way for most of my time in the gameThere are occasionally really great moment but they become more few and far between the more you play.Most of the game is ridiculously easy but there are some certain difficulty spikes at times that feel like they are there just to prolong the game. Some of the bosses get really annoying and certain platforming and puzzle sequences get frustrating. I dont play a lot of platform games so this might vary from person to person.I find the controls work well sometimes but when they dont work they really make you mad. They are quite clunky but there are parts where you need to jump, or do a prolonged jump or to jump and fly which all use the same button and it just doesnt work well often its hard to beat a platform difficulty spike area just because the controls are working against you.I think people review this game on how good it could have been rather than how good it actually is.Also in certain sections, usually around the difficulty spikes it makes you have to go through a cut scene type thing every time before u do the awkward bit. Yes you can mostly skip the cut scene but it takes time and it just prolongs the time it takes to get you back trying that part again.As well as that the cut scenes and dialoges often totally break the flow of the game.Overall I somewhat enjoyed some parts of the game but most of my play time I found either bored or frustrated.For me the price of this game is nonsensical. Steam price is 22.99 as of writhing this but it is in no way worth more than 4.99.I have played around 12 hours of this and probably enjoyed one or two of them. I do regret buying the game and i even more regret the time i put into it.Yes it could be great and yes at times it is great but for the most part in my opinion and experience it is not very good and way way way over priced. Dont believe the hype.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2016
												I saw this game pop up on steam and youtube recently. It looked pretty good, but I never bothered to give it a go. Bored one day, I picked it up and gave it a whirl.And boy, what a whirl it was!Owlboy is a platforming/puzzle game with so much charm it hurts. I loved it from start to finish and I honestly can't think of any negitives about Owlboy.It has a nice story, a atmospheric and beautiful soundtrack, characters with boatloads of personality and a enviroment that looks so good, each screen is an absolute treat to the eyes. Controls are fluid and combat feels great.In terms of both it's structure and visuals, this reminds me a lot of Cave Story, a much loved game. If you like Cave Story, you'll like Owlboy too.While in Owlboy's story nothing particuarly blew me away, not even any reveals (that I won't spoil). There were some heartening scenes near the end which were lovely and I wish I could experience again, but I never really said "OH SNAP!". It was a pleasent ride regardless.Enough rambling. BUY IT ALREADY!

content:
Posted: November 13, 2016
												What a beautiful game in every sense of the word.Before I sing its praises, I have to admit that I completely understand the criticims:- short game- some fairly annoying platforming due to the flying mechanism- the cut scenes taking the game out of your hands oftenWith that being said the positive aspects of the game are SO DAMN GOOD, that in my view they outweigh any potential negatives.  Reading other reviews, they've hit on the pros (art, sound, gameplay) so I won't beat that dead horse.  While I agree with superlative from the other reviews, for me, the thing that made this game an absolute classic was the feeling it gave me while playing.  The story was genuinely affecting, making me run the gamut of emotions, and feeling them right along side Otus.  Going through this adventure with my little Owl protagonistc just genuinely made me happy.  What a wonderful experience.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2016
												In the passing years since I’ve started writing about games, I have been loathe to refer to any of them as “charming”. It just feels like a cop-out adjective: something that could very easily be applied to any number of indie games that put a heavy focus on character, story, and a friendly or sometimes melancholy atmosphere. There have been a ton of clever, inviting indie games that have been released in the past decade, and an endless stream of them could use that forbidden adjective. Shovel Knight, Firewatch, Minecraft, Spelunky: the list goes on and on. “Charming” just sounds simultaneously lazy and condescending, and I’ve tried to avoid it.But here today, I am forced to use that word when it comes to Owlboy. Because no other word encapsulates the feeling I get from D-Pad Studios’ indie platformer better than that troublesome little moniker, so let’s just get right into it, shall we?Owlboy is charming.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
												While the core gameplay can be fun, it suffers from the developers and testers being too good at their own game and ramping up the difficulty (although it only took me two attempts at most to get through any area I had trouble with).This, however, is something I can forgive, but what I can't get passed is the fact that 90% of the NPC dialogue spoken to or about the main character is nasty or belittling, often being outright lies. This nasty dialogue is often unskippable, and is often long winded. If you had some way of reprimanding these NPCs, that would be fine, but they are characters that you're fighting to protect, and you have no way of interacting with them other than to talk to them to receive their scathing disapproval.All in all, it's a really demoralising experience, and I have no motivation to pick up the game and continue, knowing there's just going to be another tirade of nasty remarks coming my way despite completing objectives and defeating boss monsters successfully. It's such a nasty contradiction; play the game well and you're rewarded with mean and nasty people telling you you're worthless and useless. Consequently, I've sought a refund for this nasty waste of time.

												Most of the time spent in this game involves sliding the character across every available surface to try and find invisible walls that have no tell. It is tedious and not fun. I played for 9 hours, then while sliding through a wall my character fell outside of the level. Now when I load it puts me back into a location I am not supposed to be that is blocked on both ends due to previous scripted events and I am completely blocked.Also towards the end of the game there is a minigame that involves memorization and intense precision, which are not skills that the rest of the game requires. content:
Posted: November 22, 2016
												This game was enjoyable overall, but failed in very key areas that just undermined the whole experience for me.Do you know the saying, "Show don't tell?" I don't think the devs have, the storytelling is often very heavy handed, and the dialouge isn't very natural.The game is overall pretty easy, but the bosses present difficulty spikes that I didn't find enjoyable. I'm no stranger to difficulty, I play Dark Souls, but the bosses often felt repetitive and unrewarding.The biggest breaking point imo is the price. I beat the game in 6 hours, and that's with finding ~1600/2500(?) of the collectibles, and 2/3 of the big collectibles. If this game was priced at 15$ I fell like that would be more appropriate.

												Retro evolved.  Every SNES will shed tears for not being able to add a gem like this to their library.  Soundtrack is top notch. Posted: January 23
												It's too easy. Just way too easy. That's a big problem for me and I just wanted to get that dissenting opinion out there since I haven't seen much posted about it in other reviews.Additional problems I have with this game are that there are just too many things that slow the pacing down to a crawl. From the sleepy story, to the unchallenging gameplay, to the poor level design with required backtracking to solve "puzzles" I feel like this was more of a time sink than a game.Artwork, Music, Controls all get an A plus. Maybe even an A plus plus if your into this particular style.Gameplay, Exploration, World-building, Fun Factor and everything else are lackluster and I would say D is about the best grade they could possibly worth.For me this is going straight to the overhyped indie garbage pile along with Undertale, Cave Quest, and  Five Nights at Freddy's.

content:
Posted: November 10, 2016
												This game looks very, very pretty.Pretty much every other aspect of it fails. The story is VERY weak, and pretty much drops the ball in trying to make the world around you feel fleshed out and interesting. The game plays a lot like a simplistic Zelda, and ends roughly at the story point in which Zelda games go to their second half. The gameplay is very superficial, and mostly involves spamming your dash a whole lot to make the game move faster, along with shooting unsatisfying weapons. The game also loves to wrestle control away from the player in order to force him to go through ♥♥♥♥♥♥ dialogues and cutscenes.I finished this game and was shocked at just how little there was to it. That 6 hour completion time is misleading, as I had to restart around halfway through, having lost my save the first time around.I do not recommend this game, as it's extremely overrated.

content:
Posted: January 2
												TLDR; pretty, frustrating, bland and inoffensive.This is a game where every platformer trope has been taken wholesale and cobbled together in an inoffensive and cliched manner with the single exception that the main character can fly. There was never a question of "should we put boss fights in the game?", the question for Owlboy was "how many can we cram in there?". A boss fight has never been fun in a video game it wasn't fun doing the same fight 20 times in the 90s it's still not fun now.Also: collect all the coins to unlock all of the upgrades? Hunting for coins behind secret walls is not a suitable replacement for content. I did not get all of the upgrades because the game was already frustrating, and the game was made all the more frustrating for not having the unlocks they provided.The controls are frustrating at times, the dodge button cannot be pressed at the same time as aiming, leading to a lot of frustrating clusterf**ks with many trivial (and they are almost always trivial) enemies on screen and you having to devote your thumbs to either killing them, getting hit a lot in the process, or dodging their attacks. The inability to do both left the game feeling clumsy and poorly thought out.Another bugbear with controls is that there is a dash button that makes travelling through the spacious game MUCH faster. So I played this game constantly mashing B just so I could get through it quicker. There's no excuse for this, it's just dumb game design.There's also the matter of the few scenes where the game requires a lot of precision for platforming sections where your flying ability has been hampered. These sections would benefit greatly from having fine control and precise input, alas if you have a controller plugged into your computer at all you cannot use the keyboard because for some reason it disables the jump key. Bizarre.There's also no fine control. So you are better off using the DPad rather than a joystick most of the time. If the joystick is a little left, it's the same as pushing it all the way to the left. Stupid.The story is middling. Standard "bad guy wants to end the world because reasons" tropes abound. The characters are distinctly individual but I found very little reason to actually care about them.The protagonist is mute because all protagonists are mute. Nothing new to see here apart from the bullying the main character gets for it.At many points in the story I got very lost, owing mostly to previously completed level sections being explorable again without any warning that you've been there before. By the time I realised I had already explored that section days before (and forgotten because it all looks the same) it was another 10 minutes of mashing the dash button just to get back to where I started.The art style is absolutely lovely and it's obvious a lot of man-hours went into it; if the devs had spent as much time on having a vision for their game and sticking to it rather than making concessions for every man and his dog then they might have created something really special.As it is, I can't recommend Owlboy as anything other than a very pretty, thoroughly samey platformer that will appeal to no-one and offend no-one.

												Pros - Most beautiful visual pixel art I have ever seen in a video game. Ever. Period. This is almost something thats undebatable for me.Hand crafted. Every inch. Beautiful characters, comedy, love, easy to fall for. Cons - Easy. Casual Audience. Lackluster puzzles that are more repetition + add more of something instead of creatively challenging the player. Like it wants to be zelda but struggles to warm up the fire. Overall, appeals to a very wide audience, I don't honestly think it's worth the price tag. At all.... sorry... 9 years or not, the quality is high but the content offered doensn't reflect the high price tag. Other platformers/metroidvania style games offer much more at a lower price tag. Conclusion 7/10

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
												This game was 10 years in the making and it looks gorgeous. The pixel artwork is fantastic and they took great pains in animating all the stuff. Absolutely phenomenal artwork. But sadly artwork does not simply sell a game. This game has done nothing innovative in terms of gameplay. The gimmick here is that it is a platformer but you can fly. The main character can fly and has a spin attack and a dash attack which I think was only useful to break some walls. You can carry your pals one who has a shotgun and can burn things,the other who has a gun which shoots pellets and the third who has kind of a websling. You get these pals are various stages of this 8-10 hour game. So they basically shoot for you and the controls use the mouse to shoot,WSAD for movement and double pressing W makes you fly. The level design is average at the most with you mostly shooting enemies and solving very trivial puzzles which involve button pushing for the most and nothing else. This is the most uninspiring gameplay I have ever seen. It is not fluid at all and the main character moves so slowly. It becomes a pain navigating the levels with such a slow character. The levels are also dungeon like so there are celings to stop you and there is not much use of the vertical flexibility that could have been achieved. The boss fights are very simple with very easy to figure out patterns. The last    boss gave me some trouble but I finished that in 3 tries after figuring the pattern. I generally do not care about a game story and completely ignored that one but you can talk to folks and figure out whats happening. I found the cutscenes very annoying and they sometimes popped up randomly which was very annoying. Also there is a level the last one which is very annoying as they do not ley you fly and it is absolutely the worst level designed and is completely against the flow of the game. I would not recommend this game. it was an absolutely chore to play with nothing innovative in the gameplay and a very slow moving character. Also the character switching is clunky where you can get the pal you want to use teleported to you. Absolutely boring gameplay.

content:
Posted: January 9
												Horrible endgame. Player spent the whole game playing a flying platformer, but the ability of flight is taken away during endgame, during which the game is a gimped jump platformer. Since the UP key is used to transition from jump to flight during regular game, if somehow game detects player press UP during endgame jump, the jump is cut short. This makes analog control impossible. Only 2 major mechanics progression during the game (when acquiring new allies). Player is required to use the same ally to do damange for most of the game, as the other ally's attack is cooldown based. Boss does get harder, however due to lack of abilities, the harder bosses plays like a crappy fighting game, where invulnable frames matter. No map travel, making doing achievements/collections a pain.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2016
												i had immediate crashes immediately after leaving owlboy's house but re-enabling windows media player via programs and features > turn windows options on and off > media features > windows media player solved it.to the commenters complaining about me not sending a bug report: if the bug reporting in the game actually worked i would've sent one---the bug report thing in the game seems to have lots of pertinent information for debugging but unfortunately i couldn't interact with it due to another bug occurring from having a controller plugged in.  issues that prevent you from being able to progress more than 5 minutes into the game are worth being brought up to people thinking of buying a game when it just came out.  you'd be irritated preordering a game and having it not work at all on a brand new computer you just bought.  i'm glad the devs are working on it and i am absolutely not the only person who disables unwanted services and programs on their computer.it's a fantastic game.  the artwork/animation is incredible.  i've heard people complain about the writing being childish for whatever reason and i don't understand it----it has a ton of charm and hits quite close to home for me.  the music is phenomenal.  the gameplay is a little bit weird to get into but i warmed up to it by the time i made it up to the owl temple.  i'm sure the design and difficulty of the "dungeons" and whatnot will improve as the game progresses.  it's different for sure and is worth checking out and i will definitely update this review once i have time to progress further.i definitely hope the patches will improve the stability of the game because from what i've played so far it's pretty great.

content:
Posted: January 7
												I really wanted to like this one - the visuals, music, and quirky characters are all done fantastically well, and D-pad absolutely deserves a ton of credit for creating them with their limited resources. Unfortunately, while I'd say this game's 9 years of development were well-spent on those aspects, the gameplay desperately needed more attention. It's great for about the first quarter of the game, but starts relying on weaker mechanics after that for the sake of variety. I'd still have recommended it if not for the last stage of the game, which robs you of both flight and your friend's abilities in order to force some god-awful platforming sections on you. Owlboy's controls weren't meant for platforming, and this section makes that painfully clear. It killed the game for me.

number of helpful: 5 of 16 people (31%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 28
												Owlboy is the worst kind of bad game- a game I had high hopes for; a game which had so much potential that it shines through even the crud that is its final form.Let's go back a step though- what does Owlboy do right? From the very first trailer I and almost everyone else who saw it was enchanted by the visuals, art style, and music. That part still holds. Retro art is ironically old now, but it's done well here unlike in some indie games, and the music is strong enough that I bought a few tracks from the OST on the composer's website. The thing is, Owlboy never really goes beyond that.The Combat is incredibly barebones. Owlboy lifts up to 3 partners, which basically means 3 different guns you can freely switch between unless the partner is missing for story reasons. These get 1 minor upgrade each over the course of the game, and are otherwise unchanged. Enemy selection is very limited, with 1-2 types in each area. Thankfully, the boss fights at the end of each area are a bit imaginative and mix things up, but that's just not enough variety and challenge. You do not gain any extra movement abilities or powers beyond the guns (which unlock slowly over the course of the story).Let's talk about the Rings. I hope I wasn't the only one getting serious Superman 64 vibes from that part of the trailer. Owlboy can fly around opening chests to get coins, or fly through rings to get coins. This isn't currency, though. Think of them more like Feathers in Assassin's Creed. They're collectibles and they unlock things in a "shop". The quotation marks are because you can't choose what to unlock, they simply unlock automatically at certain coin thresholds, in a linear order. These are mostly cosmetic changes for Owlboy (content padding) with the 3 minor upgrades for your weapons mixed in. The whole thing reeks of unfinished features and playtime padding, which is kind of sad for a game that took 10 years to develop, regardless of the dev team size.The worst part of the game is the Level Design. The devs simply went full retro with these. Owlboy levels rival the worst of nonsensical NES level designs with nonsensical layouts that aren't very interesting to play through. I cannot describe the disappointment I felt when I entered the second major dungeon area- apparently a bunch of samey looking steel girder grafted to literal clouds, which formed a maze on the way to a major bad guy airship. The idea that some reviewers have described Owlboy as a Metroivania is a joke. There's no exploration here; routes are 90% linear and the only thing that can be missed are small hidden alcoves with extra chests and floating rings.In summary, just stay away. Watch the trailer again to experience a quick sense of wonder, without having it spoiled by actually playing the game.

number of helpful: 10 of 29 people (34%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 8, 2016
												Owlboy is a game with wonderful visuals and music that took a long time to make that is utterly mediocre and not really worth your time. (Note: this review does contain slight spoilers)Let’s talk about the positives. The visuals are fantastic. Some real top notch pixel art. Save for some questionable art direction (ie the red flash from the shotgun attack, lack of some button UI), the art is some of the best modern pixel art you’ll ever see. Characters are detailed and full of expression. Background are beautiful and have a real sense of depth.The music is wonderful. It’s pretty typical video game-y adventure music, but it’s well orchestrated and there wasn’t a single track that felt was overly repetitive or annoying. The writing; aka the plot, dialogue, flavor text, is all serviceable and generally inoffensive. There are some genuinely touching moments and a decent little plot twist. However the ending feels like a non-ending that essentially amounts to generic time-travel related trope that we’ve seen done better in games. The character’s motivation towards the end of the game are forced and it, excuse the pun, it doesn’t land on its feet. Unfortunately the gameplay is the weakest part of this game. This game is riddled with a lack of polish that prevents it from having a good feel to it. You cannot remap the buttons for either gamepad or keyboard/mouse (I highly recommend you never attempt to play this game using keyboard/mouse as those controls are inexcusably awful.) The level design often demands a level of precision that the controls do not allow for. Example: You roll with the B (Circle), but aim with the Right Stick. Sometimes you’ll need to roll to avoid an attack while aiming, but can’t remove your thumb from the right stick fast enough. There are stealth sections that are either tedious or outright terrible. These are often poor with sensible checkpoints and any small screw up results in near instant failure. There are at least 3 of these throughout the game with the last one being essentially a whole dungeon. At least you can fly in that last one. The main gimmick of this game is that the player can fly. It’s not an original idea by any means. Games like Aquaria, Insanely Twisted Shadow Planet, and others have done similar things, but it’s still uncommon enough to be novel. However there are multiple points in this game where they take away the one unique thing about it and the results vary. The waterfall sections feel fine. In them you can only jump. The jump is super floaty unlike most other games and takes while to get used to, but those sections are usually very short. A single room or a bit more. You can’t attack other than the little spin attack that does no damage, but combat is usually avoidable or nonexistent in those sections. They’re actually nicely done. It’s the other times that are extremely questionable. There’s an early stealth section that’s pretty bad but the worst offender is the last area. There you can only fly for a little bit during it. Doing so will cancel all vertical momentum and slow you considerable. This would be fine if flying wasn’t so easy to trigger accidentally. By simply tapping up or jump again while in the air you’ll start flying. For most of the game this is great. You can just hold up and fly around. It feels expected, especially when using the analog stick. However, in that last section, if you start flying when you don’t expect to you’ll likely fall into an instant death trap. This causes you to countlessly restart what should be an fairly straightforward platforming section not because of your own inability, but due to unexpected control issues. It felt like an awful Mario Maker level.This sort of one-off mechanic that doesn’t quite feel right or is straight up bad is very common throughout the game. There’s a dungeon where everything is dark and you only have a very small radius of light. You have to navigate tight tunnels edged with spikes, but the controls are floaty and the spikes too easy to clip into. Often it doesn’t look like you should have hit them. Later on you’re riding a giant lava snake and moving it up and down to avoid obstacles, but the screen is constantly rotating and it just feels wonky and awful instead of super cool like it should have. There’s not a single area of this game where I could say “Man! That was a really well done and fun!”Combat in this game is, like so much else, lackluster. It’s boring, slow, and often times unavoidable since enemies will chase you until you’re dead. Boss battles are much the same (expect for the final boss which is actually pretty well done! Though they do make you do it three times). Typical bosses have either a safe area (generally towards the top of the screen) or a simple strategy that makes them a complete non-issue.Ultimately, I feel like the developers would have better spent their time making a bunch of small games instead of trying to prefect this game. They did not succeed. So much of its issues scream inexperience and stubbornness. Had this game come out a year or two after they had started working on it, it would have been a flawed but alright game that they could have built from. As it stands now, it’s a flawed game that does not live up to expectations. If you want to play game with beautiful pixel art that took 8+ years to make then go play AM2R instead. Owlboy is just not worth your time.

I almost finish the game and getting bored.Actually, I was getting bored from the beginning.My playtime is about 30 hours just because I pause the game and leave it be while I'm doing  more interesting activities like shopping, eating, sleeping which I usually don't care to do when I am playing good game.That means this is very boring game.I think it shouldn't be called as game.I would call it a nice pixel art book.I would recommend this... software if it was sold as the art book.But since it claims itself a game, it doesn't earn my recommendation.Controls are bad, actions and puzzle are boring, story is also boring. The only thing this thing is good at is showing a nice hand-drawing pixel art which reminds me of good old snes.

number of helpful: 6 of 24 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2016
												Pros: Very nice graphics, animations fluid and a lot of care was taken to give personality to NPCs and player characters. Music is fantastic. Little penguin guys are funny. The story is a bit sentimental at times, especially the ending. You want Otus to win!Cons: Not a lot of content, especially considering the price. They could have done a lot with character progression, or even secret doors placed throughout the world - why are there so few? Not at all challenging - you can easily finish in 8 hours. Controls can be wonky sometimes if you are trying to drop a teammate and pickup something off the ground. Upgrades almost meaningless, so not a lot of incentive to collect coins.In sum, I wanted to like this game but ended up disappointed. Games like Momodora, Axiom Verge, or Salt and Sanctuary are of the similar Metroidvania style but offer twice the gameplay with creative mechanics and deeper plots (at half the price). I don't think Owlboy was a very memorable expereince (besides the graphics and sound) and I wouldn't play it again.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2016
												This game is good if you are expecting a ridiculously low amount of gametime for a decent chunk of cash. 9 Years fooled me into thinking the game would have a decent amount of content but alas, even going slow it took me just 8 hours to complete the story - and I was afk for about 1 hour. The gameplay is nothing fantastic, the puzzles are laughably simple and calling it an open-world game is ridiculous, the linearity is unescapable. The one part where the game kind of shined is the story, the main reason I carried on playing was that the story was intruiging, until the end where it ends insanely abruptly after the easiest final boss to exist. I did want this game to be good and I would probably would have liked it a whole lot more if... well if the was a whole lot more. TL;DR ; Dont buy this game for outstanding gameplay or a lot of content - just buy it if you want an OK story.

												the game starts on a really high note, pretty neat flight mechanics and the partners you find add brilliantly to the gameplay...then it ends, in a terrible, underwhelming, super quick and underdeveloped ending.the story at some point felt like it would go places, but in the end it fell right back into a lukewarm cliché.a great start for a game that could be great, but ends up feeling like a demo.particularly the last part is a complete disaster as it even removes from you the best mechanics of the game for way too long... then it gives you back the ability to fly without even explaining why.definitely check it out if you want to spend 4 or 5 hours in an afternoon once the price drops below 5 or so, I strongly disencourage you to pay anything more than that for this game.

number of helpful: 29 of 83 people (35%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2016
												TL; DR: Good game, but the pricetag is a way too high. Steam won't let me post without giving it a thumbs up/down, so thumbs down because I didn't really enjoy the game, the price is too high, and the average score is too high.Virtually everything about Owlboy is good. The art, music, gameplay, presentation, and writing are all well done. It's clear that a ton of love and effort has gone into the game. Like anything, there are a few rough spots here and there (the platforming in one of the final areas was particularly frustrating) but overall, each part of the game is great. That said, I can't really say that I loved the game. For whatever reason, the whole never really came together as something greater than the sum of its parts (despite those parts all being individually decent). The gameplay is decent enough, but it wasn't quite mechanically engaging enough to pull me along. The checkpoint system is incredibly forgiving, so there isn't really any challenge. The whole idea of having companions never really plays out to be more than just having different weapons equipped, which feels like a bit of a missed opportunity. On top of that, the puzzles aren't very mind-bending nor the gameplay particularly exciting. Likewise with the story and characters. They were interesting enough, but I usually didn't really feel super interested in what was around the next corner. The music was uniformly well composed and performed, but often felt out of place. The world is very pretty and well-connected, but there isn't really enough going on to encourage a ton of exploration. Ultimately, it feels like you end up with the worst parts of a Metroidvania game (excessive backtracking through areas) without the good ones (the feeling of excitement to use a new skill/ability to open new areas and find secrets). I realize the game isn't necessarily meant to be a Metroidvania, but the style of the world is reminiscent of one.All that said, the quality of the individual components of the game gives it a bit of charm that settled in by the end of the 8-10 hours I spent with it. I can't give it an outright recommendation because of the price and the lack of cohesive greatness, but it is by no means bad.Edit: The more I've been thinking about it, I just didn't really find the game to be fun. Plain and simple. And because none of the other elements really stuck out to me as being really exceptional, I wasn't left with a great impression overall. If you find the game fun, I think it will feel really, really great but I didn't because the gameplay didn't really grab me.Edit 2: Fixed TLDR for people who can't read good.

content:
Posted: November 7, 2016
												I'm probably going to get blasted for this, but this is perhaps the most boring game I have played in 2016 and many years before. Gone Home is equivalent to how bored I was in Owlboy. In fact I went to bed the night after I played it, woke up, then went the ENTIRE NEXT DAY before I remembered "oh yeah I played Owlboy didn't I, I should refund it." It was that forgettable. I have never played a game I literally forgot the next morning; they're either too good or too bad. This one was just too mediocre."But you only played for 47 minutes!" True! To which I defend myself by saying I went to a friend's house for the weekend and observed as he played it there, since he told me to buy it. At no point did I think "I should buy the game again." The gameplay is generic, the levels are generic, the story tries and fails to be meaningful, and the only redeeming quality are the graphics. It pains me that such cool graphics are in a game so utterly boring as this one.I'm also annoyed at some reviews claiming this is the best platformer of 2016. You spend a majority of your time FLYING, which means you CAN'T PLATFORM. Child of Light had this issue. This game is not a platformer, and it barely qualifies as a puzzle game since the puzzles are laughable.I don't want to say I didn't stay for the ending... Instead I'll say I couldn't stay around for the ending.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2016
												Absolutely loved the first half of this game, but in its second half it becomes a painful reminder that there just isn't a lot of love for the casual gamer by the gaming industry.  The difficulty/tedium level increases exponentially, to the point where I finally gave up for good after probably 40+ attempts at completing one of the last segments of the game.  I know I'm in a minority wanting games to be easier, but some of us don't have the time or patience for games that feel more like work than play, and it would not be difficult for developers to include a "story mode" that lets us wimpy gamers bypass the tough scenes if we want to.  I enjoy the story, characters and artwork of this game, but don't enjoy the type of gaming that has you repeating segments ad nauseum to learn the choreography of precision timing scenes.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2016
												I really wanted to like this game. I remember loving The Legend of Zelda and Metroid and I hoped it would be a similar experience, but it’s not. In my opinion, Owlboy barely qualifies as a game. It feels more like an interactive story that leads you around by the nose through various set pieces. I’m about half-way through and there's been no more than one or two fun scenes. It’s too easy –as an example, it’s almost impossible to take a wrong turn. When you’re finished with an area the game often literally closes a door behind you as if to say there's nothing you missed, just keep moving – way to kill the mystery. The puzzles are simple and the clues to solving them are telegraphed. The retro Art and Music are great but the gameplay is boring.

number of helpful: 23 of 296 people (8%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 3, 2016
												The story was lackluster and poorly written. Molstrom just dies without you ever fighting him, despite being the ultimate war machine built by the Owls, and Solus never confides into Otus his reasoning for using the relics, despite saying that he considered Otus to be his only friend. There were too many unnecessary, irrelevant things to the story that were communicated while tons of other more pertinent questions to the story were left unanswered. For example, what does the engraved stone with the Roman numerals on it mean? Why are there plants overgrowing in some areas, and how did no one realize that they broke the wind machine in the Owl Temple? Who wrote the Book of Nocteus, and why was it prophetic?There may be more to the end of the universe, but this story did not do a good job of convincing me that there is.I could go on about the oversight in game mechanics, but I feel as though they pale in comparison to the lack of effort put into the story.However, I will say that this game is beautiful. There were many times that I was just awestruck by the detail put into it. I can't reasonably put my enamorment into words, but the art alone made this game worth it to me.I would not recommend this game, though, because I believe great games have great stories. This, sadly, was not one of them.(EDIT FOR CLARITY—11/5/2016):I have taken the spoiler tag off not to spite anyone here, but to more easily make it understood how incomplete the story is.The authors attempted to create many twists within the story, only to neuter it by creating major flaws in the character arcs of Solus, Molstrom, and the unknown Book of Nocteus author. Taste is subjective, but the story is not written well on an objective level, and I had to create an argument with apropos evidence by stating such a thing.A game with a good story should allow you to get immersed and lost within it. This game does everything within its power to prevent this, from the complete and utter destruction of Advent after Anne says to come by her house in Advent to learn more about her, to the lack of historical explanation of the Owl race. This game goes out of its way to make the story undigestible.This will be my last update, as the story of this game is not worth discussing further.https://support.steampowered.com/kb_article.php?ref=4045-USHJ-3810My review is not against steam rules, and you are not required to read reviews before purchasing this game.Should you find anger after reading my review, then I suggest you reevaluate why you sought out reviews in the first place.

Posted: March 19
												It could be said that this game is short. Another could find that that the collecting is somewhat tough to go through. A lot of people also were having a hard time grasping exactly what story the creator was going for at the very end.At the moment I began to explore the world, every second I spent going through every inch of this game begging for another reason to stay just a little longer to discover more, and even many hours after 100% the entirety of the game, I wish that I could spread my love for this game with every breath I take. I gladly spent those beloved hours captivated by how this game felt and how it made me feel. That feeling is something rare and precious. It is not perfect as just a game, but I pray there is more content to look forward to.If anyone reads this looking for a reason to play it, I want you to just take my word and buy it. You'll wish you could pay more for it. It also, like many thing, is a personal experience you want to go into with as little exposure as you can.

Posted: March 20
												Owlboy was a fun, highly enjoyable game.  The graphics and music were well made and a perfect throw back to the 16 bit era.  The characters were fun and interesting, and provided depth to the world.  Gameplay was fun and enjoyable.  The game was overall average difficulty and can be completed in about 4-6 hours depending on how fast you want to rush through.  It's a pretty linear game, with extra trinkets to find, but not necessary to complete the game.  For those complaining about the price, I'd say either wait for a sale or it's not the game for you.  If this was an older time, this game would have been a full retail priced game on the snes or genesis, and people still would have enjoyed it.

Posted: March 23
												Was very conflicted about this one, because I played the worst part of the game right before ending it.Good:* Awesome soundtrack.* Fun dungeons.* Godly artstyle.* Interesting story.* Huge overworld + endless flying (seriously, I get more enjoyement just out of flying around it than I get from entirety of some other games).Bad:* BOGUIN CHALLENGE (It's so bad I wrote a script that completes it for me. Why put a reflex challenge THAT HARD in a game that has oherwise fairly balanced difficulty?)* No fast travel (The world is huge, so It would be great to be able to travel from some places to the others. It's not that big of a deal, as it allows to feel the hugeness of the world, but still...)* Boguin challenge. * Tone shifts (sometimes the game goes from cute to grimdark in 10 seconds and it's disturbing).* Boguin challenge.Technically Boguin Challenge takes 30 sec. to complete (although I spent about 4h on it), so 99.9% of the game if awesome and 0.1% is my personal hell.

Posted: March 22
												A very touching game...

Posted: March 25
												One of the best games I've ever played.  It's beautiful, mysterious, story-filled, and has a fairly long play time.  The soundtracks are also some of the best I've ever heard in a game.  Buy this game immediately

Posted: November 3, 2016
												Ever wondered if old games where really better than today's or it's just nostalgia ? This game has a clear answer to that.Visually, in my opinion, has the best pixel graphics ever made, you will have a grin on your face going through the stages and locations of this game, the art is just gorgeous, the colors and the wonderful animations tight so good with the excellent controls.Gameplay-wise it implements an original flight mechanics that really works, zones are designed to be explored both horizontally and vertically, flying is really responsive and it just feels great.It has a really good ost, with both calm or sad themes to "grit", adventurous musics.The story is interesting with a good plot-twist towards the ending, and if i have to pick a negative side of the game i would say its length, the game is 7/8 hours long and it's not only a $/hours ratio issue, it's that it's a pity that such a game with fantastic characters and ideas ends so quickly, even if it's a different genre i had Chrono Trigger vibes from this game, the plot was sucking me in but unlike chrono it has not real time to fully develop, regardless this is the only issue i had with this game, everything else was not good, it was excellent.I really hope to see more games like this in the future.

Posted: March 23
												It's a lovely game with wonderful pixel art and a touching story with some good humour as well. I enjoyed it a lot but would have been grateful for some in-game map and the ability to "teleport" to areas directly - at least after finishing the story (for collecting all coins). It's a pretty large world and searching stuff after the main story got a bit tedious. The controls (I played with a X-Box controller) are good but not perfect. The levels are quite diverse with some rather difficult parts but they are well thought out and never so long as to get frustrating (even when needing several attempts). Overall I think difficulty is very well balanced. I spent 12 hours with Owlboy and can heartily recommend it. It's a game made with a lot of care and love and it shows.

Posted: November 18, 2016
												This is an indie platformer. Do you want one of those? If the answer is yes, then you should buy this game. It took me 15 hours to do everything. + Amazing Art+ Solid Story+ Gameplay is solid (Don't expect anything revolutionary) - Cost a good bit for a short game with little replay (This doesn't bother me, but I know this is important to a lot of people)It's just a cute little game.

Posted: November 26, 2016
												I honestly could not recommend this game enough if I tried, I played it from beginning to end in one sitting without getting even slightly bored of it because of the fact the game just gets progressively more enjoyable as you go along. The way this game is open world enough to explore extra areas while still being closed enough so you don't get lost or confused is a great feature many games could learn from. The story may seem distant or dragged out at the start but very early into the game everything starts tying together and crafts this amazing adventure you get sucked into and never want to leave. I would go into more details about this game instead of just saying "this feature is great" or "this game is amazing" but it's something you HAVE to experience for yourself, even if you don't enjoy playing pixelated games- (which for a pixelated game it has pays a lot of attention to small details such as effects, sounds, animations, particles, ect. to make everything look, feel, and sound extremely smooth) -I HIGHLY doubt you'd regret buying Owlboy.

Posted: November 11, 2016
												Art: 9/10 Basically the best pixel art I've ever seen. However, some animations felt slightly under par, particularly on some party members.Music: 9/10 Actually really really good.Gameplay: 6/10 My two biggest issues with the game as a whole are the enemies and movement mechanics. The bosses are way too easy, I only died to the final boss once and most other bosses I did not die at all on. There are no enemies outside of bosses that were a real threat, outside of "trap" enemies, and the static obstacle Pirates. The greatest depth in movement is tapping B every half second, or much later on (for basically a single level), using a grappling hook thing.  This game I feel would be greatly improved by adding extra abilities to the player throughout the game, and having more varied and difficult enemies, as well as making the bosses more difficult.However, this is coming from a person with 3000 hours in the Dark Souls series, so take some of that with a grain of salt. In addition to those issues, the levels often seem very simple. All of them are entirely linear, with weak puzzles that feel more like chores than anything.Story: 7/10 The story at times is rather generic, however at other points it is extemely engaging. Kind of a mixed bag here.Overall: 7/10 Needs more depth, and difficulty.

Posted: November 11, 2016
												Owlboy is among the most fascinating games I've ever played. I can't put my finger on the exact reason, but something about it captivates me in a surreal way. I can't determine whether it's the well-realized art style, amazing music & sound design, responsive gameplay, or engrossing story. I think it's truly a combination of all of these things; but, whatever the reason, I couldn't put Owlboy down. Yes, there were a few moments of frustration (controls being a little inconsistent in some later-level platforming, a few boss encounters) but, overall, my complaints about Owlboy are easily drowned out by my gushing praise for the remainder. If you enjoy platformers, or games with wonderful stories, I urge you to play Owlboy. It is worth every cent, and every minute. Congratulations to the team for finally putting it out, you created something truly special here.

Posted: November 24, 2016
												Story – Owlboy stars a young protagonist named Otus who, after a series of events, ventures forth into the floating world to protect it from fearsome pirates. While the premise starts out fairly simple, the plot thickens and turns in a way later on that will leave the player engaged. The charming character designs coupled with their unique personalities (some of which also have backstories to discover through dialogue and environmental interaction) also lend to populating the game with interesting and memorable characters. Late in the game, Owlboy’s story will leave the player with a nice mystery behind the lore of the game’s world, which has already left players coming up with theories on how it ties to the current events happening around Otus and friends.Gameplay – Owlboy’s gameplay is unique in which the player will spend most of their time flying above ground while carrying one of three companions you’ll unlock as you progress through the game, each with their own unique way of dealing with enemies and puzzles. It essentially comes down to a gunner to shoot enemies/objects at long range, a shotgunner that deals a lot of damage at short range and can be used to burn obstacles, and a companion that can trap enemies and zip the player around the level to avoid hazards.Unlike most platformers, this game takes a Zelda/Metroid-esque approach where the player explores an open world and will find themselves in dungeon-like areas to progress through the story, rather than progressing right to the next level. Combat in the game primarily consists of the player using the gunner character to shoot at enemies, but sometimes may require timing or melee hits to reveal enemy weaknesses. The first half of the game is relatively easy, with the latter half ramping in difficulty, especially bosses.There are plenty of unlockables, collectibles and hidden achievements in the game, some of which are hidden behind walls and in plain sight. If you’re a perfectionist, this will add a nice chunk of time to the game’s length which is both a good thing and bad thing. Good thing is there’s plenty to collect, like weapon upgrades for your characters, hats, story bits and an upgrade for Otus himself. Bad thing is, while there are a few shortcuts in Owlboy’s world, the lack of fast travel will make getting those last 3 coins you missed in the second dungeon a bit of a pain.Music – Owlboy’s music is wonderfully composed as each piece sets the mood and pace of whatever setting/situation you may find Otus and friends in. The overworld music has a feeling of grandeur while escaping harrowing situations has a tense sense of panic and dread. The soundtrack is definitely many will find themselves listening to while the game itself isn’t playing.Graphics –Owlboy’s graphics are rendered in beautiful pixel art featuring vibrant colors, characteristic animations, night/day cycles and hand crafted environments. Many background graphics are unique in that they rarely share tiles sets and appear as grand set pieces for dungeons, character’s homes, and boss showdowns. Characters are brought to life through expressive poses, subtle sub-pixel animation and character interaction that really leaves the player empathizing with them. This really comes across through Otus, who heavily relies on these animations as he himself can’t speak. Turned eyebrows, cheery smiles and bulging eyes all lend to the character and easily communicate to the player what Otus and other characters are feeling.

Posted: November 24, 2016
												Owlboy.The game is an action platformer.You play as "Owlboy", a mute fledgling owl that is forced to spread his wings and thrust into an adventure like no other. The art style: Is wonderful, with its vibrant and colourful display, its locations are wonderful; you can really see that this was a labour of love, rather than a rushed game.The Music: The music is truly fantastic, it really helps to create emotion, whether that being melancholy or wonder, it has a track for that; I couldn’t help but find the soundtrack and listen to it again. The fact that it is fully orchestrated helps wonders too. The Story:I felt that the story captivated me and kept me well engrossed, making me want to come back to play the rest almost every night. The story took me about 6-7 hours to complete, but I did not get all of the collectibles that are on offer. I was not disappointed. The Combat: The combat is something that I enjoyed; you pick up and carry one of three different characters to act as your weapon each with a unique still set that will be useful in your travels. There are a large variety of enemies that you will face and a good amount of boss fights that will engage you. I only wish the boss fights were a little more difficult.I honestly loved this game and I recommend it to you whole-heartedly.
