Posted: November 24, 2016
												After dealing with Owlboy for a full video series where I played it, it left a good impression on me as a game itself. Uncertain if I can link that, so here's just the review!In all honesty, it's hard to rate Owlboy as anything less than 'Amazing' in almost every aspect it tries to touch upon. Gameplay is solid, the map is solid, the characters are great, the art is pretty and stylish, and the story overall is told well... But there are still flaws. In the story itself, there are a lot of things that are hamfisted or simply not explained well enough and most characters come off as negative because of that. Now, a majority of them are still fine and that's why I said they were great, but there are definitely a few I feel have fatal flaws that simply aren't explored in the gameplay. That is my major complaint.Another major complaint is a build up that never receives a payoff. Something that may hint for things to come now that the foundation has been set, but... It could have been handled better. This game was amazing, there's no doubting that, and I'd definitely recommend it to anyone who likes action platformers like this that are very story driven. There's also a lot of hidden things that just aren't really focused on unless you really want to 100% the game, which is a plus. It's nice when a game likes to show you its story through actual work instead of just an hour long cutscene, though there are plenty of small cutscenes through this game as well.Regardless, this game has flaws and a few major ones too, but it's not a bad game. Gameplay was simple, clean, and overall fun, but ultimately ended up becoming repetitive or just annoying, particuarlly in certain situations. The music was always on point, though, and there were only a few points where the art was an issue, particuarlly when dealing with enemies that have arkward hit boxxes or move a lot. That being said..... The information I have states the game took over 10 years to come out. In these 10 years, it got a lot of support and a lot of people were looking forward to it. In no way do I think anyone who did wish for it is disappointed and I am definitely not disappointed either in buying it... But it could have been better and I feel like 10 years was more than enough time to make it better. There's a lot of small things that really make this game just barely reach 'Amazing', but it's still amazing nontheless. I'm looking forward to more from this group and hopefully this game will allow them to see flaws they otherwise missed because of either lack of experience, or simply not trying to focus on fixing them. Hopefully it'll take less than 10 years next time, possibly for a sequel. Story: 7/10Art: 9/10Gameplay: 8/10Music: 10/10Characters: 7.5/10 (One specific character has a good moment, but overall is pretty meh.)Overall: 8/10. Could use work, but it's still an amazing game that people should pick up if they enjoy this genre.

Posted: November 6, 2016
												Okay I love this game. Highly recommended. I've got about 4 hours logged in the game and this is the first game in a long time that I want to continually revist. So here's what I like about the game sprinkled with some opportunities I think the developers might consider:Music - the musical score in this game is absolutely wonderful. It can be delightful, brooding, somber, exciting, uplifting, everything. It's so wonderful, I don't know how else to describe it. I can't really go into depth about it since I'm no audiophile, but lemme say it really greatly adds to the mood and setting of the game at any given point.Graphics - this is a 2D game of course, but as far as 2D games go, this game looks absolutely gorgeous. I will say here that sometimes the environments feel somewhat empty, and the lack of a map or map hotkey makes navigating somewhat difficult but it's not unbearable and never really feels like it's a huge hinderance. I think it may make collecting all the extra stuff a little hard but I think not spoonfeeding stuff to players isn't a HUGE problem. Gameplay - the game is really responsive, I never find myself doing something I didn't want to do, same with the aiming and all. The whole concept of carrying different gunners to do and accomplish different things is really cool and it's a clever gameplay mechanic. The puzzles are pretty fun, not too difficult though, but again, no hand holding here and it's great. Story - I leave this one up to you guys. I really enjoy the story line, I know some of you out there will say it's a tried and true story, done plenty of times before. But that doesn't stop me from really enjoying the story. My only wish is that the game doesn't end quickly. I'm only 4hours into it, I hope theres a lot more of the story left. I'm not going to assign a number value but I'm going to say this game is great. I really love it. I hope the game lasts quite a bit longer, but I'll append this Review when I'm done to give a good idea of how long it takes. Highly recommended, if you need a new story driven game that doesn't hand hold you through every single piece of it, look no further, speak no more.Edit: I finished the game, I have 9 hours logged and I could've finished it a lot faster honestly. I really love this game, the ending is memorable and I look forward to what the creators have next in store. I wish the game was longer though, that's probably my only gripe.

Posted: November 8, 2016
												This is a remarkably well made retro platformer. The music is outstanding. Reminding me of Final Fantasy. The gameplay is really solid with a light metroidvania feel that had me feeling mildly confused about where I was going most of the time. You just fly around, but use the power of your friends to combat and traverse portions of the environment. They're easy to use and control and have clearly defined roles. Problem is that you have little time where you are using all three at once. There are a couple sections that felt out of place like the cannon flight, but they're few and far between. My only other gripe is that the game really gives you zero context for how an enemy is defeated or a section traversed. It's all trial and error. Visuals are peak retro. They use the term hi-bit and I like it for this genre of graphics. I really liked the character animations. Otus's surprised face gave me a giggle every time. Well worth the asking price.

Posted: November 5, 2016
												this game.. few words can describe it. absolutely gorgeous, very fun and intuitive, music is masterfull just all around perfection. this game has the feel of alot of other great games it at times reminded me of Metroid and at other times legend of zelda but it also has it's own unique flair. the only  thing is some sections can be frusturating and annoying but the rest more than makes up for it. it was a HOOT to play.

Posted: November 6, 2016
												It's weird for a "Metroidvania platformer" to have the entire game make you essentially ignore platforms, but this game has two good arguments for playing it: the environments and the music.Now let me be clear: a lot of games get praised for their score and I've played a number of games that are famous for their scores, but this is probably the first in a long time that I felt encouraged to put the controller down for a little while and just listen.The backgrounds and artwork are very detailed in a very subtle way: I didn't actually notice it at first (I was exploring and a bit lost) but for a game with that old-school X-bit look, there's a lot more attention to detail than I expected.The controls are simple (I always mess them up in boss fights though) but I'm not sure how I feel about so explicit a plot in a Metroidvania game.  It's new to me and I'm unsure if it helps or hurts the game.

Posted: November 6, 2016
												This is basically a super gorgeous Shantae game.  Which is great, because those are fantastic platformers, they just don't spend 10 years on each one meticulously doing amazing little one-shot animations.  Now you get the best of both!If you haven't owned a Nintendo console it's hard to imagine the magic of this type of game.  Shovel Knight is another good comparison. If you've got minimal twitch reflexes (It's easier than Aquaria and Shovel Knight, nowhere near as sadistically evil as Ori and the Blind Forest, and again about the same as Shantae games) you should give it a shot. It's gorgeous, bittersweet, very funny at times, and a very satisfying ending. Worth full price for me.

Posted: November 8, 2016
												PROS:-Simple yet challenging mixture of 'platforming'/bullet-hell/twin-stick shooter-Gorgeously realized world-Characters with depth and growth - a character I'd seen as an absolute♥♥♥♥♥♥made a surprising turn towards the end.-Very well-told story-Epic soundtrack-I like that upgrades aren't so much 'bought' as 'earned', where you get them by collecting coins, but the coins aren't actually spent on them.CONS:-Some frustrating set pieces. An actual platforming bit towards the end is rather frustrating and made me aware of a certain over-sensitivity in between jumping and actually flying-I'm sort of in two minds about the ending-You don't have much health, and opportunities for healing can be few in dungeons-Some checkpoint placement can range from irksome to downright sadistic-Some graphical effects (such as firing a character's musket) can be somewhat disorienting - but I've found myself to be somewhat sensitive to that kind of thing.All in all, this game's a real hoot. (I regret nothing.)

Posted: November 12, 2016
												Owlboy was an absolutely amazing game. I literally couldn't walk away, I played the my whole first runthrough in one afternoon, and didn't pause for more than 30 minutes that entire time. The story was completely captivating, the visuals were stunning, the music was outstanding, the characters were incredibly well designed, and the combat was unique and challenging, but fun.I can't help but compare this game to Undertale, as both are simply designed, but still story-rich games that manage to tell a unique and powerful story. Obviously, Undertale saw incredible success and had insane amounts of players, but I absolutely preferred Owlboy. The graphics were glaringly better, the story was even more impressive, and the sheer amount of unique mechanics and ideas put this game all the way over the edge for me.Some of the later boss fights were a bit challenging for me, mostly as a result of my inexperience with combat in Platformers, but that did frustrate me a little bit because it felt unfair that I had to spend so much time repeating the same battles over and over and had no option to lower the difficulty because there simply isn't a difficult setting. That said, the combat mechanics definitely made that issue a lot more pleasant to deal with. I had never seen anything like the combat in this game, and the aspect of switching between gunners during combat to access their unique abilities was really fun to learn and play around with.The music in this game was truly great. To go back to my earlier comparison, I know the entire gaming community was raving about Undertale's soundtrack, and I definitely see where they were coming from, but this game was on a completely new level for me. The mixture of orchestral and electronic music was a really good choice for this game. It seemed that every new piece of music I heard throughout the game felt perfectly placed, and did such a good job at setting the tone for the situation.Overall, this was a great game, absolutely one of my favorites I've ever played.I give it a 9.5/10, and recommend it to EVERYONE. The only obstacle is that combat may be difficult for players not experienced with Platformers, but the same is true for just about any game from this genre.

Posted: November 23, 2016
												Owlboy is a relatively short but extremely high-quality Sidescrolling Action-Adventure game.You play as an Owlboy who tries to protect the world from pirates but in some way seems like he screws up in some way or another. The main thing is that you fly, you grab things and you can grab people, who you use in order to shoot.It is heavily inspired by classics like metroid, but most importantly Zelda. Although even though its visuals really show its inspiration from Zelda, it does lack a certain quantity and variety of puzzles that the Zelda games offer. Its story is as beautiful as its artstyle and its characters are charming and somewhat relatable.All in all, a great game that might seem expensive for its duration, but has such a high quality and refinement of both artstyle and gameplay that makes it absolutely worth it for a lover of the genre or someone who is just getting into it.

Posted: November 23, 2016
												•	Storyo	The game revolves around Otus, a young mute Owlboy who is lackluster at all things his mentor deems as important to being a proper being an owl. In this game an owl is the protector of the denizens of the floating islands that make up the world. Throughout the game Otus meets new companions who serve as his weapons on his journey to save the floating islands from sky pirateso	The story told is a familiar take on the Hero’s journey, however it’s done well. Dialogue is well written and character development is well paced. The game is sparse with its NPCs and makes the ones who are in the game pretty significant, if not to the main story then to the side quests that are placed throughout the game.o	However, even with the side quests mentioned prior, this game is short. I made sure to talk and return to most npcs after each pivotal moment of the game (for anyone interested most of their dialogue changes frequently) and completed all but 2 of the side quests, aand reached the end screen in 7 hours.•	Technicalo	As Otus is an owl, a majority of the game is navigated via flying. This gives the game a unique feel to its platforming. The levels are designed well around this form of movement and makes exploring the game rewarding.o	Otus can’t attack on his own, but instead carries his allies around as weapons. His allies hang under him as he flies them around. While this is a cool concept, I found my allies getting snagged on terrain at tense moments as the ally pretty much doubles the size of your controlled sprite. This results in some situations where the controls feel clunky.o	Every level has its own theme that are visually stunning and every room in the levels are distinct, which assists in preventing the player from getting lost.o	However, the game lacks a mini map makes it difficult to back track through completed levels. While going through a level the first time is easy and intuitive, the shortcuts opened as you progress make it easy to overlook rooms when returning to collect missed coins. A mini map would fix this.•	Final Thoughtso	While there are certain parts of the game that become frustrating due to control issues and the game runs a bit short for the price tag, I would still wholeheartedly recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of 2d adventure games and games with touching stories.

Posted: November 11, 2016
												Art: 9/10 Basically the best pixel art I've ever seen. However, some animations felt slightly under par, particularly on some party members.Music: 9/10 Actually really really good.Gameplay: 6/10 My two biggest issues with the game as a whole are the enemies and movement mechanics. The bosses are way too easy, I only died to the final boss once and most other bosses I did not die at all on. There are no enemies outside of bosses that were a real threat, outside of "trap" enemies, and the static obstacle Pirates. The greatest depth in movement is tapping B every half second, or much later on (for basically a single level), using a grappling hook thing.  This game I feel would be greatly improved by adding extra abilities to the player throughout the game, and having more varied and difficult enemies, as well as making the bosses more difficult.However, this is coming from a person with 3000 hours in the Dark Souls series, so take some of that with a grain of salt. In addition to those issues, the levels often seem very simple. All of them are entirely linear, with weak puzzles that feel more like chores than anything.Story: 7/10 The story at times is rather generic, however at other points it is extemely engaging. Kind of a mixed bag here.Overall: 7/10 Needs more depth, and difficulty.

												Owlboy is among the most fascinating games I've ever played. I can't put my finger on the exact reason, but something about it captivates me in a surreal way. Posted: November 10, 2016
												A labor of love from the best pixel artist alive right now.Owlboy is not a game for everyone. It's rough around the edges as far as gameplay goes. The controls are pretty tight, but not super tight. The puzzles are very clever, but not incredibly clever. The game is mostly bug free, but not completely bug free.Overall I felt I got my money's worth, and I'd surmise that most people alive to experience the SNES era of action platformers will also appreciate the game. Younger gamers most likely won't, as the lack of polish in a number of areas won't make up for the stunning imagery and supurb sound design.The game also has a number of fun and interesting set pieces, but they tend to be over before you can really appreciate them. In addition, there are a number of clever platforming puzzles that don't get the full treatment. Once you get the hang of a new puzzle concept the game pushes you into the next. There are also several sections where you can sort of bumble your way through. The game can feel challenging in some places, but more often than not it's a matter of figuring out the preferred way of solving the problem in front of you, rather than mechanically getting good.That said, the very last level of the game does away with this and demands platform jumping precision in an environment you are not familiar with. It's not too hard as, mentioned previously, once you get the hang of one concept the game shunts you on to the next, but it was an odd choice.There are numerous small details that ultimately brings down the experience. The reloading time for the musket is one. The lava level has a number of puzzles in the dark that can be muddled through without understanding them. The game is in desparate need of a map system as, while the maps in dungeons are linear, they can be confusing to navigate. In addition, the game borrows elements from Zelda, but without a map or easy way to mark which locations require more searching to get that vaunted 100%, it kills a lot of the desire to fully explore and re-treat previous areas for the last few coins.On the subject of collectibles, there seem to be three side-quests in the whole game. One involves rescuing a number of adorable penguin-like animals, who unlock an interesting if daunting mini-game. The second involves a secret in the first dungeon which doesn't seem to ever get fully explained. The third is collecting each and every coin in the game, which is kind of a hassle since, unlike many metroidvania titles, there are no clues as to what constitutes a hidden wall or passage. Or if killing every enemy in a location will unlock a chest. The lack of clues and helpful tools to get around the map or explore kill off the metroidvania vibe.In addition, the maps for dungeons are virtually 100% linear, so in essence it's less like playing Metroid, Zelda or Castlevania classics, and more like playing the more modern Zelda titles where you hardly ever backtrack and simply solve each puzzle and dungeon in sequence.With the complaints out of the way, the story is pretty on point. The characters are endearing enough, not charming enough to be remembered for a long time, but not hateful or annoying either. There are also a number of strong, darker moments in the game that would really amp up the emotion if the characters were a little bit more fleshed out.I think, the greatest crime of Owlboy, is that aside from the stellar visuals, the game is the most solid B+ title I've ever experienced. No doubt the long development time was devoted to the visuals and animation, I feel as though the small team could've used that time to iterate on the design and polish the game up even more. I wonder if 6 extra months of development time would've vaulted Owlboy from an interesting game for pixel art enthusiasts and nostalgic fans, into a true indie game darling and platforming classic.No doubt, enough love and care was put into the title, and there is definately a feeling that Owlboy be placed among other titles such as Cave Story, Noitu Love, Undertale, et al. But it's that lack of finish that ultimately squashes it's aspirations.I recommend it, and I think it's worth the price. But if you're expecting the next Undertale, perhaps wait for a sale?

Posted: November 8, 2016
												PROS:-Simple yet challenging mixture of 'platforming'/bullet-hell/twin-stick shooter-Gorgeously realized world-Characters with depth and growth - a character I'd seen as an absolute♥♥♥♥♥♥made a surprising turn towards the end.-Very well-told story-Epic soundtrack-I like that upgrades aren't so much 'bought' as 'earned', where you get them by collecting coins, but the coins aren't actually spent on them.CONS:-Some frustrating set pieces. An actual platforming bit towards the end is rather frustrating and made me aware of a certain over-sensitivity in between jumping and actually flying-I'm sort of in two minds about the ending-You don't have much health, and opportunities for healing can be few in dungeons-Some checkpoint placement can range from irksome to downright sadistic-Some graphical effects (such as firing a character's musket) can be somewhat disorienting - but I've found myself to be somewhat sensitive to that kind of thing.All in all, this game's a real hoot. (I regret nothing.)

Posted: November 6, 2016
												Okay I love this game. Highly recommended. I've got about 4 hours logged in the game and this is the first game in a long time that I want to continually revist. So here's what I like about the game sprinkled with some opportunities I think the developers might consider:Music - the musical score in this game is absolutely wonderful. It can be delightful, brooding, somber, exciting, uplifting, everything. It's so wonderful, I don't know how else to describe it. I can't really go into depth about it since I'm no audiophile, but lemme say it really greatly adds to the mood and setting of the game at any given point.Graphics - this is a 2D game of course, but as far as 2D games go, this game looks absolutely gorgeous. I will say here that sometimes the environments feel somewhat empty, and the lack of a map or map hotkey makes navigating somewhat difficult but it's not unbearable and never really feels like it's a huge hinderance. I think it may make collecting all the extra stuff a little hard but I think not spoonfeeding stuff to players isn't a HUGE problem. Gameplay - the game is really responsive, I never find myself doing something I didn't want to do, same with the aiming and all. The whole concept of carrying different gunners to do and accomplish different things is really cool and it's a clever gameplay mechanic. The puzzles are pretty fun, not too difficult though, but again, no hand holding here and it's great. Story - I leave this one up to you guys. I really enjoy the story line, I know some of you out there will say it's a tried and true story, done plenty of times before. But that doesn't stop me from really enjoying the story. My only wish is that the game doesn't end quickly. I'm only 4hours into it, I hope theres a lot more of the story left. I'm not going to assign a number value but I'm going to say this game is great. I really love it. I hope the game lasts quite a bit longer, but I'll append this Review when I'm done to give a good idea of how long it takes. Highly recommended, if you need a new story driven game that doesn't hand hold you through every single piece of it, look no further, speak no more.Edit: I finished the game, I have 9 hours logged and I could've finished it a lot faster honestly. I really love this game, the ending is memorable and I look forward to what the creators have next in store. I wish the game was longer though, that's probably my only gripe.

Posted: November 3, 2016
												This is absolutely gorgeous. This apparently has been in development for nine years. I've never heard of it until yesterday, but this is what a game that looks like it has been worked on for almost a decade. The sprite art is stunningly gorgeous, but screenshots don't do it justice because the animation, well, I could say it's the icing on the cake but I would rather call it the cake on your other cake.So many little details are in the environment and character animations. I don't mean that in the same way modern triple A games get praised for adding basic details that Nintendo 64 games had. There was clearly genuine effort put into these animations. Triple A games tend to look good in screenshots and from a distance, but up-close you can see just how robotic the characters act. This game looks fantastic from a distance and in screenshots, but gets better the closer you look.Pixels seldom remain still on characters and environments that would logically be moving. It is not necessary for the game to inform you by text what emotions characters are feeling, because you can see for yourself. Characters will stand with a different posture appropriate to their expressions, they twiddle their thumbs, shake their knees, sweat, avoid eye contact, get red in the face, and many more subtle ways of conveying emotion. No need for a giant thought bubble with an emoticon. The protagonist may be silent, but I understood everything he wanted to say.The gameplay isn't bad, either. It's smooth, perfectly responsive, and has a lot of remapping options, although the default controls are perfect anyway. Gamepad, at least. I don't know how good the keyboard controls are but platformers and keyboard controls have never got along well.Just get it now, even if it's not on sale. It's also on GOG.com, which I would recommend over Steam because it's DRM-free. If I had known it was on GOG, too, I would have gotten it from there.

Posted: November 8, 2016
												This is a remarkably well made retro platformer. The music is outstanding. Reminding me of Final Fantasy. The gameplay is really solid with a light metroidvania feel that had me feeling mildly confused about where I was going most of the time. You just fly around, but use the power of your friends to combat and traverse portions of the environment. They're easy to use and control and have clearly defined roles. Problem is that you have little time where you are using all three at once. There are a couple sections that felt out of place like the cannon flight, but they're few and far between. My only other gripe is that the game really gives you zero context for how an enemy is defeated or a section traversed. It's all trial and error. Visuals are peak retro. They use the term hi-bit and I like it for this genre of graphics. I really liked the character animations. Otus's surprised face gave me a giggle every time. Well worth the asking price.

Posted: November 3, 2016
												Owlboy at its’ core is a beautiful and chipper story about failure. It teaches you as the player that failure will definitely come and that you can overcome it. The game hits you over the head constantly with hard obstacles and puzzles, but you persevere. Otus fails at being a true Owl, but he continues on. Alphonse fails at being a pirate. Getty fails at being a solider and Twig, well I won’t spoil that.Owlboy shows us that through failure there is a future and through our shortcomings, there are others there to lift us up. Destruction is another form of creation and failure is a new beginning.PROS+ Beautiful graphics+ Heart warming and unique story+ Tight controls+ Amazing castsCONS– Frustrating end game platforming

Posted: November 5, 2016
												I often call Owlboy the "Undertale of action platformers", and that's exactly what it is! Owlboy is a beautiful 2D adventure set in a world floating in the sky. You'll explore ancient ruins, fight monsters, aquire friends with unique abilities, and battle challenging bosses. Everything here is so carefully crafted, from the balanced difficulty to the design of the levels. You'll never be truly lost in any dungeon, and you'll always end up going in the right direction anyway. The art itself is so beautiful, even if I got lost somehow, that I was in disbelief. The sheer effort that went into the animation and pixel art is ASTOUNDING! The story alone is incredible and compelling. There is nothing better than a group of friends going up against overwhelming odds! What a classic tale full of tension and hope! For this review, I am not going to do my usual summary of the positives or negatives. Because there really isn't a single negative to say about Owlboy. Maybe the odd stealth sections are a minor flaw, because they do a good job breaking up the usual gameplay, but everything else is so well made. In fact, if you don't care about collecting everything or finding all the secrets, the collectable coins are designed exactly to give you the upgrades you need just by playing normally. That is polish and care on a higher level! Owlboy is another "indie darling" that deserves to sit next to Shovel Knight and Undertale!

												It's weird for a "Metroidvania platformer" to have the entire game make you essentially ignore platforms, but this game has two good arguments for playing it: the environments and the music.Now let me be clear: a lot of games get praised for their score and I've played a number of games that are famous for their scores, but this is probably the first in a long time that I felt encouraged to put the controller down for a little while and just listen.The backgrounds and artwork are very detailed in a very subtle way: I didn't actually notice it at first (I was exploring and a bit lost) but for a game with that old-school X-bit look, there's a lot more attention to detail than I expected.The controls are simple (I always mess them up in boss fights though) but I'm not sure how I feel about so explicit a plot in a Metroidvania game. Posted: November 3, 2016
												This is absolutely gorgeous. This apparently has been in development for nine years. I've never heard of it until yesterday, but this is what a game that looks like it has been worked on for almost a decade. The sprite art is stunningly gorgeous, but screenshots don't do it justice because the animation, well, I could say it's the icing on the cake but I would rather call it the cake on your other cake.So many little details are in the environment and character animations. I don't mean that in the same way modern triple A games get praised for adding basic details that Nintendo 64 games had. There was clearly genuine effort put into these animations. Triple A games tend to look good in screenshots and from a distance, but up-close you can see just how robotic the characters act. This game looks fantastic from a distance and in screenshots, but gets better the closer you look.Pixels seldom remain still on characters and environments that would logically be moving. It is not necessary for the game to inform you by text what emotions characters are feeling, because you can see for yourself. Characters will stand with a different posture appropriate to their expressions, they twiddle their thumbs, shake their knees, sweat, avoid eye contact, get red in the face, and many more subtle ways of conveying emotion. No need for a giant thought bubble with an emoticon. The protagonist may be silent, but I understood everything he wanted to say.The gameplay isn't bad, either. It's smooth, perfectly responsive, and has a lot of remapping options, although the default controls are perfect anyway. Gamepad, at least. I don't know how good the keyboard controls are but platformers and keyboard controls have never got along well.Just get it now, even if it's not on sale. It's also on GOG.com, which I would recommend over Steam because it's DRM-free. If I had known it was on GOG, too, I would have gotten it from there.

Posted: November 3, 2016
												What seemed to be just a little indie game with over 9 years of development, Owlboy is an adventure to behold. I finished this game two days after the game had released. Why? I absolutely fell in love with the game. There's a lot of things that really hold this game and make you just want more. While there are many MANY good things about this game. There are, however some spots I really was disappointed in. Now I won't be spoiling the whole ordeal on what I am talking about, but I will make reference to it so this review does HAVE SPOILERS AT THE END OF THE REVIEW ON ITS OWN SECTION BUT IT WILL BE SPOILER FREE!!!Owlboy is an Indie adventure game where you control Otus, a mute Owl who apparently has a lot on his shoulders when things don't really go his way. He and his friend Geddy are tasked with watch over their village when a huge group of bandits known as the Pirates invade, taking an Owl relic that is stored in the village. And off we go on our adventure to get that back and stop the Pirates and their plans. One of the first things I've noticed in game is the presentation along with the soundtrack. Holy crap this game has detail in its animations. Props to the devs and animators for a very polished game. The scenery looks beautiful and it sets the mood in the beginning as a light-hearted adventure. Otus himself is a mute, but the amount of detail in his responses, whether he is twiddling his thumbs when he's nervous, he covers himself with his cloak when he's sad, its all there and I wasn't expecting how I would feel for the poor guy. One effect though I had with the looks of the game were at some points, textures didn't spawn (which were resolved by resetting the game) and there are some weird bugs like if you eat a healing item and get hurt at the same time, it produces some weird result. Nothing gamebreaking, but I think that needs to be addressed.Speaking of feeling, this game can really tug on your heartstrings. You can get attached to these characters and then suddenly the feel train will hit you. I remembered that I at least teared up or even flat out cried at some sections because what was happening and how I didn't want bonds or spirits to break from the main cast. This story is very well done and the pace is very fluent. There weren't times I wanted to put down the game because I was just done. No, like I said before, I wanted more. When it finally ended, I was pleased with what I got. The game's difficulty isn't that bad either. It's very easy to get into and the game will test your knowledge of when to use certain partners, There are some hard spots, but it isn't too bad.Now lets talk about that gameplay huh? So Otus, as a mute owl, he really can't attack. He can stun people with is little spin, but thats all he can really do other than his little dash (which I'll get to in a minute). So the game pairs you up at first with your best friend Geddy, Geddy has a gun, which Otus can carry him and he can fire at enemies. This is an interesting mechanic as you need to manage having your partner on you while also dodging enemies, solving puzzles. The whole game would be a boring cake walk if Otus can attack. Because of this, there are special sections were Otus is alone and he has to sneak past enemies. There are a number of stealth sections in this game and they are handled pretty well. I never got bored of them as they went by pretty fast. Not to mention you have a great source of movement. Oh my god the movement. I mentioned Otus can dash either in the air or on the ground. As a speedrunner, I absolutely love games with amazing movement, and Owlboy is no exception. Sure there are a lot of times I spammed the dash to get point A to point B in a timely manner, but I never felt rushed. The regular flight speed that Otus has is very optimal. At no times when I was exploring a dungeon that I needed to move around by dashing, only when I needed to backtrack or dodge incoming fire. There is even an upgrade you get that makes your movement even better so that in the later parts in the game when you have more freedom to backtrack and collect any of the game's currency to buy the extra goodies. Overall, the game is a gem. It was worth the wait of 9 years of development and polish. I didn't hear about this game until youtuber VideoGameDunkey where he had said he had a really good feeling about this game. I looked into it, and gave a lot of hope. Owlboy is a must play if you like adventureous games with a story that really likes to hit your soft spots. I absolutely loved it and am looking forward to speedrun this game!Owlboy gets a 9.5 out of 10 for me. ~LuckPercentSRL---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------SPOILER SECTION! SPOILER SECTION! SPOILER SECTION! READ IF YOU WANTSo with all the praise I just gave this game. Why did I give it a 9.5? There are two small disappointments I had with the game's story.So at the end, it appears that Otus had fallen because he activated the anti-hex to save the world. In the end, we get this little section of him talking to all his village friends and they appear to be happy, saying bye sort of feeling, like a memory sequence. We find his teacher at the end who explains some things and where he is. Then it ends and we see him falling from space to.....his death? Is he alive? I'm not sure. It looked like he was dead initally, but his master say the realm he is in gives him a section chance? And then we see him falling from space so is he still alive? Arrrg! I just wanted to know and it just ends off right there! So yes, the ending is a bit disappointing. Don't get me wrong, there are still a couple of things that make it great.Also, Captain Molstrum seemed like an interesting antagonist. He was hyped up to be this unstoppable baddie who, with a relic, absolutely obliterates Advent with one blow. We all wanted to get back at him and I was so ready to fight him in like the 3 sections you have contact with him, and you don't get to at all. He gets killed by the plot and I was sad about that. Now this isn't to say the final boss was boring or a wasted potential because I did enjoy fighting him. I'm just sad that we get this hyped baddie and we don't even get to fight him.

Posted: November 5, 2016
												TL;DR : This game is astounding, 9.5/10._________________________Owlboy is a breath of fresh air in the gaming industry, something different from the casual FPS or other cash-grabs with no real game. And allow me to explaing why. In this game you play as Otus, a young owl living in the town of Villie along with his bestfriend and partner: Geddy. While you go on your adventure you will find out that as Otus you are unable to kill an enemy yourself, for you can only stun them or knock armor off of them. This is where the innovation begins, as you must pick up Geddy to kill an enemy, for Geddy (and other teammates you will get later on) will be the only ones able to kill an enemy.  As you fly along through the story, you may also notice that you can trail off from the given path to adventure else where, to find secrets of the land and stories untold...and maybe a few more coins laying around. I find that this type of level design in super exciting, because I love to explore, and while on the topic of levels, the many levels of this game all feel different making each and everyone a different journey to be had. Now, to the juicy stuff...pros and cons.Pros: - The music is phenomenal. - The art is gorgeous. - The enemies are different. - Levels are designed well to keep the game interesting. - Characters are lovable. - The story is in-depth, while being a rollercoaster of emotions. - Sprites and animations are wonderful. - Exploration is fun.*- Boss-fights are also fun and different.With all these pros you'd think there'd be no cons, right? Nah there's like 2.Cons:  - The game isn't too difficult, I only died a couple times, but that was from me being stupid.*- Along with the first con, the boss-fights are not too difficult.The game is fun and innovative and competely worth your time and money, I just wish they had a difficult slider or something, because I found myself going through levels with ease.Oh well, a game doens't need to be difficult to be a masterpiece. I give this game a 9.5/10 just because it was pretty easy and it felt like I was "flying" (heheheh) through the game.

Posted: November 3, 2016
												I am not a nice person. I judge things by their faults, not by their strengths. It is a system of subtraction. For everything that displeases me the game needs to have something equal or greater in order for me to enjoy it. Games that are "flawed but good" do not get my recommendation. I am hard, I am critical and I find little pleasure in things anymore. I have prejudged them all and found them wanting. I tell you this so that you might understand the weight of what I say next. Owlboy is a masterpiece unlike any I have seen for a long time. It is not only a joy to behold, but to experience. I am not one for graphics making the game, but the screenshots and whatever video you have seen of this game does it no justice. It is stunning from start to finish. The characterizations, the movement, the attention to detail, the colors and the vivid landscapes. Everything is uniquely designed and is so amazing you won't be able to take it all in through a single playthrough. As you play, keep your eyes open and attentive and you will be endlessly rewarded.The music is a marvel. I am going to go and buy the soundtrack. Its really just that great. There's flow and character and mood and melody. Everything is weird and different but it all fits together. Character themes and areas and even the sound effects just flow seemlessly to set the tone of the adventure. If you love old soundtracks for the classic game of bygone then you will not be disappointed.Story and writing are not what I would expect out of this game nor did I anticipate it to be such a high point. It has epic adventure without feeling forced. The characterization is excellent. There's comedy, which is genuinely funny and light hearted, but its only a pause from the rising gravity of a situation gone extremely wrong. There's intrigue and development and those who are careful to watch it unfold can notice some very interesting things early on that will pique your curiosity.Its a fun game to play. The controls on keyboard and mouse are simple enough that you don't struggle against a steep learning curve but certain segments will have you hammering away at keys in order to switch up moves and having you scramble during some of the faster paced segments... but the game is very forgiving. It will throw you into a situation, but its not guaranteed instant failure if you mess up. You get multiple chances and if you've worked on what the game has taught you then you will easily fall into the reflex of knowing what to do. The areas feel good, feel smart. They're crisp and never requiring pixel perfect jumps or for you to count frames in order to succeed. Its fun. There's a few minor bugs to the game. I've had to deal with one, but honestly I can't blame the developers; its a problem with XNA and I daresay anyone developing a title like this one would have been bit by the same thing. They're working on it, and I've had no issue with performance outside having to reinstall WMP. Its worth the money new. And that's high praise.

Posted: November 23, 2016
												•	Storyo	The game revolves around Otus, a young mute Owlboy who is lackluster at all things his mentor deems as important to being a proper being an owl. In this game an owl is the protector of the denizens of the floating islands that make up the world. Throughout the game Otus meets new companions who serve as his weapons on his journey to save the floating islands from sky pirateso	The story told is a familiar take on the Hero’s journey, however it’s done well. Dialogue is well written and character development is well paced. The game is sparse with its NPCs and makes the ones who are in the game pretty significant, if not to the main story then to the side quests that are placed throughout the game.o	However, even with the side quests mentioned prior, this game is short. I made sure to talk and return to most npcs after each pivotal moment of the game (for anyone interested most of their dialogue changes frequently) and completed all but 2 of the side quests, aand reached the end screen in 7 hours.•	Technicalo	As Otus is an owl, a majority of the game is navigated via flying. This gives the game a unique feel to its platforming. The levels are designed well around this form of movement and makes exploring the game rewarding.o	Otus can’t attack on his own, but instead carries his allies around as weapons. His allies hang under him as he flies them around. While this is a cool concept, I found my allies getting snagged on terrain at tense moments as the ally pretty much doubles the size of your controlled sprite. This results in some situations where the controls feel clunky.o	Every level has its own theme that are visually stunning and every room in the levels are distinct, which assists in preventing the player from getting lost.o	However, the game lacks a mini map makes it difficult to back track through completed levels. While going through a level the first time is easy and intuitive, the shortcuts opened as you progress make it easy to overlook rooms when returning to collect missed coins. A mini map would fix this.•	Final Thoughtso	While there are certain parts of the game that become frustrating due to control issues and the game runs a bit short for the price tag, I would still wholeheartedly recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of 2d adventure games and games with touching stories.

Posted: November 2, 2016
												Last year we got a little indie title that blew us away and now we get one that also manages to look awesome as heck.At very first let me tell you one thing. THIS IS NOT A METROIDVANIA!Sure, today its cool to slap this tag on EVERY FLIPPING INDIEGAME, but this is not a metroidvania, its more like a Zelda plattformer... an Action adventure. If you want to see what a Metroidvania is, then go on and play Axiom Verge, Metroid, Shantae and the Pirates Curse or Castlevania. If you aren't braindead you'll see the difference.Owlboy awaits you with it's stunning visuals, interesting characters, solid gameplay and soothing soundtrack.Yeah, soothing, I mean the background music for the action packed sections of the game was cool too, but its nothing that I would remember for a long time... nevertheless, it gets ya pumped for what is happening and thats all I want.The Visuals are, as I said, incredible. You really feel the passion that went into the animations and every little rock.The games story and characters are something that i would rather leave without any big spoilers... especially since the game has just been released. All you have to know is that its pretty good and gives the adorable characters a solid worldbuild to exist in.The game will take roundabout 5 hours to beat and 7-8 to absolutely complete it the first time.its not too hard but surely will wipe the floor with your sorry behinds if you're not getting the hang of the situations you are in.Overall, I absolutely have to recommend this game.Its a really nice axperience, even tho I highly doubt it will leave the same impact as Undertale did a year ago, since Owlboy really explains every little thing whilst Undertale gave the player tons of content to specualte about... there will surely be no clickbaity Game theory about this game... which is bad, since Owlboy deserves all the attention it could possibly get.

Posted: November 6, 2016
												I would like to start this review by saying that this game took 9 years to make.  9 years that were totally worth waiting for.  This is what game developers should aspire to.Owlboy is a short, metroidvania-style game made by D-Pad Studio.  I stumbled upon this game shortly before its release, because Savant: Ascent (A previous title by the same studio) was such a fun game, I wanted to try it out again.  When I reinstalled Savant, I noticed a small news article on the game page talking about Owlboy's upcoming release.D-Pad Studio has, in my opinion, the best pixel art style out there.  And Owlboy is no exception.  Througout the entirety of the game, I was amazed simply by how beautiful every area was.  This game has no map, but it's not needed, because the great art style lends itself to some gorgeous landmarks, to help you find your way.  Sadly, there is no form of fast-travel, but it isn't necessary, due to the speed at which you can traverse to a new area.Savant: Ascent really had done gameplay well.  Owlboy kept to these tight controls and fun gameplay, while adding a short, but powerful story.  While sometimes difficult, no part of the game ever felt frustrating, and I always kept coming back.  This was mostly due to the varied cast, all of whom had well written dialouge.  As such, many of the game's characters were some of the most relatable characters I've come across in recent years.Owlboy may be a short game, but there are a decent amount of collectables, and I could definitely play through the game again, to experience some of the emotions this game will bring out.This is one of the best games I've played in years.  Do NOT let this one pass you by.

												This is basically a super gorgeous Shantae game. Now you get the best of both!If you haven't owned a Nintendo console it's hard to imagine the magic of this type of game.  Shovel Knight is another good comparison. If you've got minimal twitch reflexes (It's easier than Aquaria and Shovel Knight, nowhere near as sadistically evil as Ori and the Blind Forest, and again about the same as Shantae games) you should give it a shot. It's gorgeous, bittersweet, very funny at times, and a very satisfying ending. Worth full price for me.

Posted: November 11, 2016
												Art: 9/10 Basically the best pixel art I've ever seen. However, some animations felt slightly under par, particularly on some party members.Music: 9/10 Actually really really good.Gameplay: 6/10 My two biggest issues with the game as a whole are the enemies and movement mechanics. The bosses are way too easy, I only died to the final boss once and most other bosses I did not die at all on. There are no enemies outside of bosses that were a real threat, outside of "trap" enemies, and the static obstacle Pirates. The greatest depth in movement is tapping B every half second, or much later on (for basically a single level), using a grappling hook thing.  This game I feel would be greatly improved by adding extra abilities to the player throughout the game, and having more varied and difficult enemies, as well as making the bosses more difficult.However, this is coming from a person with 3000 hours in the Dark Souls series, so take some of that with a grain of salt. In addition to those issues, the levels often seem very simple. All of them are entirely linear, with weak puzzles that feel more like chores than anything.Story: 7/10 The story at times is rather generic, however at other points it is extemely engaging. Kind of a mixed bag here.Overall: 7/10 Needs more depth, and difficulty.

Posted: November 11, 2016
												Owlboy is among the most fascinating games I've ever played. I can't put my finger on the exact reason, but something about it captivates me in a surreal way. I can't determine whether it's the well-realized art style, amazing music & sound design, responsive gameplay, or engrossing story. I think it's truly a combination of all of these things; but, whatever the reason, I couldn't put Owlboy down. Yes, there were a few moments of frustration (controls being a little inconsistent in some later-level platforming, a few boss encounters) but, overall, my complaints about Owlboy are easily drowned out by my gushing praise for the remainder. If you enjoy platformers, or games with wonderful stories, I urge you to play Owlboy. It is worth every cent, and every minute. Congratulations to the team for finally putting it out, you created something truly special here.

Posted: November 22, 2016
												So, I'm extremely picky when it comes to games. But I cannot stress this enough. Owlboy is one of the best games I've played in my lifetime. Easily one of the best in the past decade. It brings back the GOOD nostalgia of when I was 9 playing my Sega Genesis in my room late at night in my PJs. The score is fantastic, the visuals are top notch, and they're pixel graphics because they need to be, not because they want to be. I tire of modern games with modern game mechanics that use pixel art because it's cool. Owlboy uses it with a top tier respect and quality for the view to enjoy. The gameplay mechanics are great and accent each and every puzzle with touch of perfection. The story beats move forward and never bog the pace down or make the player slug though something they don't want to. The writing is on par with games of the era and give a wave of sadness, joy, and comedy. The crescendo moments of the game will make you smile and wish you could play them over and over again. I finished the game and was blown away by how much I enjoyed it. It made me feel an array of emotions while enjoying every second of all the bits and pieces used to make such a fantastic experience. I absolutely love this game and will recommend it to every person I know. You're doing yourself a disservice by not playing this game. Owlboy 10/10

Posted: November 10, 2016
												A labor of love from the best pixel artist alive right now.Owlboy is not a game for everyone. It's rough around the edges as far as gameplay goes. The controls are pretty tight, but not super tight. The puzzles are very clever, but not incredibly clever. The game is mostly bug free, but not completely bug free.Overall I felt I got my money's worth, and I'd surmise that most people alive to experience the SNES era of action platformers will also appreciate the game. Younger gamers most likely won't, as the lack of polish in a number of areas won't make up for the stunning imagery and supurb sound design.The game also has a number of fun and interesting set pieces, but they tend to be over before you can really appreciate them. In addition, there are a number of clever platforming puzzles that don't get the full treatment. Once you get the hang of a new puzzle concept the game pushes you into the next. There are also several sections where you can sort of bumble your way through. The game can feel challenging in some places, but more often than not it's a matter of figuring out the preferred way of solving the problem in front of you, rather than mechanically getting good.That said, the very last level of the game does away with this and demands platform jumping precision in an environment you are not familiar with. It's not too hard as, mentioned previously, once you get the hang of one concept the game shunts you on to the next, but it was an odd choice.There are numerous small details that ultimately brings down the experience. The reloading time for the musket is one. The lava level has a number of puzzles in the dark that can be muddled through without understanding them. The game is in desparate need of a map system as, while the maps in dungeons are linear, they can be confusing to navigate. In addition, the game borrows elements from Zelda, but without a map or easy way to mark which locations require more searching to get that vaunted 100%, it kills a lot of the desire to fully explore and re-treat previous areas for the last few coins.On the subject of collectibles, there seem to be three side-quests in the whole game. One involves rescuing a number of adorable penguin-like animals, who unlock an interesting if daunting mini-game. The second involves a secret in the first dungeon which doesn't seem to ever get fully explained. The third is collecting each and every coin in the game, which is kind of a hassle since, unlike many metroidvania titles, there are no clues as to what constitutes a hidden wall or passage. Or if killing every enemy in a location will unlock a chest. The lack of clues and helpful tools to get around the map or explore kill off the metroidvania vibe.In addition, the maps for dungeons are virtually 100% linear, so in essence it's less like playing Metroid, Zelda or Castlevania classics, and more like playing the more modern Zelda titles where you hardly ever backtrack and simply solve each puzzle and dungeon in sequence.With the complaints out of the way, the story is pretty on point. The characters are endearing enough, not charming enough to be remembered for a long time, but not hateful or annoying either. There are also a number of strong, darker moments in the game that would really amp up the emotion if the characters were a little bit more fleshed out.I think, the greatest crime of Owlboy, is that aside from the stellar visuals, the game is the most solid B+ title I've ever experienced. No doubt the long development time was devoted to the visuals and animation, I feel as though the small team could've used that time to iterate on the design and polish the game up even more. I wonder if 6 extra months of development time would've vaulted Owlboy from an interesting game for pixel art enthusiasts and nostalgic fans, into a true indie game darling and platforming classic.No doubt, enough love and care was put into the title, and there is definately a feeling that Owlboy be placed among other titles such as Cave Story, Noitu Love, Undertale, et al. But it's that lack of finish that ultimately squashes it's aspirations.I recommend it, and I think it's worth the price. But if you're expecting the next Undertale, perhaps wait for a sale?

Posted: November 9, 2016
												This is a really good game, but there's a few little things that I just can't quite ignore.The game, for the most part, is fairly easy with a few rather unforgiving and difficult sections torward the end. Luckily, these are far between enough that it doesn't make the experience a slog to get through, but it did hamper my enjoyment  a bit.The story really isn't anything to write home about in terms of originality. The bad guys are bad for the sake of being bad, the good guys are plucky underdogs, and there will be plenty of hunting for ancient artifacts. Where this story shines is in the character interactions, which are all very well animated and fun to watch... And surprisingly, you will want to see all these characters' story play out.And that leads me to my biggest bugbear; the ending. To put it simply, there just isn't enough of it, and it leaves on a rather unsatisfying conclusion. It wasn't so terrible that I wanted to curse my purchase, but it was bad enough for me feel very disappointed. Maybe there is another ending buried behind the various collectibles, but I've never been good at hunting all that stuff down, so my best bet is to wait for someone to post a youtube video of it.End of the day though, I'd say this game is worth is picking up, but if you need a satisfying ending...? You may wanna wait for it to go on sale first.TL;DR version: Great game, disappointing ending. If you're fine with that, buy it. If not? Wait for the sale.

Posted: January 22
Product received for free
												Let’s start from the beginning shall we?Owlboy?Owlboy is a 2D platformer developed over the course of 9 years with little to no funding (with the money coming from the devs pockets) and currently avaliable for PC. The game has been one of the most awaited indie games since its first announcement back on 2008-2009, sporting HD Quality pixel art, a huge world and an emotional storyWhat’s it about?Although many say its a Metroidvania (and the early shots and demo pointed towards it), the game is actually an action/exploration plataformer with some Metroid elements (namely the sequential progression through adquisition of new abilities) and Zelda-like dungeons.The game puts us into the cloak of Otus, a mute young owl who lives on a small village named Vellie which is overseen by his mentor Asio, a strict and demanding owl. Alongside his good friend Geddy, they guard Vellie and help its inhabitants. His life changes one day when pirates attack his hometown and steal a treasure from it, thus beginning his journey.How does it play like?It has 2 main mechanics: Otus’ ability to fly freely anywhere and grab objects and people, thus the game follows an upwards sequence of progression instead of the more traditional right-side. His grab ability allows Otus to carry a variety of objects to help him reach new places or solve the dungeon puzzles, be it by interacting with the object or throwing it against monsters. Grabbing people allows them to tag along and, if they can, assist Otus with offensive options. With that being said, Otus has no offensive means to defeat enemies himself, instead stunning them for a short period of time on which you can run away. Otus moves at a pleasant speed both walking and flying, and his jump trayectory can be controled as well (akin to Megaman), so he makes floaty jumps.Across the journey, Otus will also meet people that will be always avaliable for him to call and assist him at all times. Without spoiling anything, their abilities provide more efficient ways to deal with most situations and will prove to be valuable as you go along.The game has the options to control with keyboard/mouse, or a controller if so you wish. I haven’t tested on a controller since I no longer have my X360 controller, but on keyboard and mouse it controls very nice. You use the keyboard to move and change/call partners, and the mouse to aim and interact with your companions and the world.Ok, but how is it?Owlboy is a more relaxed and chill game compared to other options, which can be appreciated right from the start. Though it does have its energized moments, the game goes at a more pleasant pace, allowing you to take your time and not stress yourself.The world of Owlboy is colorful, big and filled with small secrets and caves all across, its most shining quality being that its an scenery to look at and delight on the amount of detail on it, from the greens of Vellie to the heights of Strato, inside the caves below or the Owl structures. With its stylized presentation and crisp sprites, Owlboy easily scores being one of the best looking indie games of the decade.The music adds more flavor to the journey, each piece having a distinct personality for every place in the world. Just listening to the title screen music sets the mood for the game’s story, it knows when to play, where to play and how to make it pack a punch. The choice of instruments is also very fitting too, with energetic compositions of strings and flutes for the overworld, booming and imposing trombones and percussion for the pirates, just to name a few.Story-wise, Owlboy’s is centered around Otus’ coming of age, which gets to you soon thanks to the lighthearted and more emotional moments, as well as the more intense parts, without being out of place. Its a rollercoaster and a blast, all in the good way. I could go on and on, but then I’d be spoiling.Gameplay wise, it works really well and the game is also relaxed on this aspect too (which is fitting with the more artistic elements previously mentioned), but is not free of some small flaws and maybe a nitpick of mine.Soaring through the sky and exploring with Otus is always a delight and the owl and partner abilities are all satisfactory to use. Monsters roam every most places, but they can be either dealt with quickly or just be left alone, so in most cases you can ignore monsters if you want.The world also has spread across every place series of ring trails from which you’ll be getting the game’s currency, in order to obtain some small trinkets and some upgrades too. Is not mandatory to obtain these but they certainly come in handy for the later parts.Are there any issues?Though the game does not have much flaws really, it does have one glaring issue: the complete absence of an in-game map. Such a tool is practically a must and seeing how the game does not have an option for a map seems rather confusing, especially because (given the topic of the game) owls do map their environment. Though exploration is encouraged and works great, a map would have been a very welcomed addition to avoid some moments where the player may get lost.Some minor flaws are found only on the beginning of the game but I consider these as nitpicks: at times one can see rocks that look like they are covering some kind of secret passage and are honestly kind of misleading because those stand up from the rest of the scenery. Also would have been nice if Otus could defend all by himself against enemies instead of just stunning them, at least against the small ones after a certain point if you want. It does feel a bit like a chore to be changing partners just to get rid of small pests while exploring the overworld; and the ability to put down things on a more tactful way instead of only throwing them. I get Otus is a bit of a ditzy but even then its weird to just toss things to put them down.A command to make partners stand aside instead of just respawning them would have also been welcomed, since there were times I did need to get something or enter somewhere but they stood in my way, it takes just a moment but it can get a bit annoying. I also have an issue where there’s a certain ability that makes a prior one completely useless and still occupying space. And also to give the option to resize the window, the game looks really gorgeous, but I’d like to have it not taking quite the share of my screen if I play windowed.And, maybe its just me, but the game’s writting starts a bit too mean spirited, I’m not saying its bad but it is kind of jarring given the situation when it happens and the rest of the game. I also would have liked if the last upgrade could have been obtained a bit more early to use it more, as well as a certain secret for lore, but I guess it is justified since that upgrade is mighty good and that secret gives a whole new layer of complexity to the ending. It would have also be nice to have other hidden collectibles around, like a medallion of sorts or some artifact to use, the coins only last for so long and in some areas the game almost gives them to you quite generously, it sort of makes it feel a bit short (maybe it is just me since I’m a more explorer type of player). And also the minigame: I am a bit upset that it had to be a mandatory element for the completionist and also a sort of abrupt change of pace, but it fits within the story itself so I guess it was a tough call.So, should I play it?Though with few flaws (well, few and a relatively big one), Owlboy is a charming game that definetively was worth the time spent on it, both by the devs and myself. Despite some of my personal issues, I really did enjoy all the way through and I feel that it does deserve more exposure and acknowledgement. Its a project of love that aims not to be the best game ever made but being a pleasant experience.

Posted: December 29, 2016
												This game is amazing in almost every aspect. The music, aesthetics, gameplay, soundeffects, characters and so forth. Everything is neatly tied together and has formed this amazing experience called Owlboy. Even if the game felt a bit short, I can't help but feel satisfied with the game in the end. Owlboy was a huge enjoyment for me, the controls were tight and felt amazing to play around with and the level design completmented the overall gameplay very well. Furthermore, the music and art for this game was jawdropping, it added so much character to the game and so much charm and (to me atleast) the artstyle feels unique and stands out from other pixelart games, as this feels like a mix between old and new. Thus all locations and characters are memorable and loveable. Not only does the game offer something pleasant to look at, but the story was quite good as well. Owlboy had interesting characters with nice and somewhat unexpected twists, although nothing to write home about. To fully understand what I am talking about one has to experience Owlboy themselves.The only thing I can see people complain about is that the game can be a bit pricey. 22,99€ is quite a lot of money for a ~6 hour long game, however Owlboy brings an innovative prespective of the platforming genre and the whole experience is truly magnificent. When I finished the game, I thought to myself "Well, this was a bit short. Was it really worth all the money?". At the same moment I asked myself that I noticed how dumb that question was, as I already know the answer.Yes, it was worth every penny. If you think you might enjoy this game, I'd suggest you purchase it right away as it is one of the most unique Indie experiences I've had in a long time. Pros:+ Art and Music = Jawdropping+ Gameplay felt good, smooth and natural+ Good level design+ Likeable charactersCons:- Can be a tad bit priceyHope you found my thoughts helpful even though I didn't cover every aspect of the game!

Posted: November 27, 2016
												This game is one of the most atmospheric, lore-rich indie games I've ever played. It has so much to explore, and the backstory is amazing. The way it all comes together at the end gave me such a satisfying feeling. It was a feeling of both completion and emptiness: you had gone through the story of the game, but it's all over. You get so hooked into the game that it leaves you sitting there at the end, dumbfounded. Not in a bad way, either. It makes you turn over the final events of the game in your head, lets you go over every bit of the story that you can now piece together into something amazing. It's an amazing game, and I would definitely play it again.

Posted: November 16, 2016
												Fun, cute game, but suffers from slow pacing and wonky controls, especially with switching around teammates. Additionally, there's this NPC in the game who basically physically and emotionally abuses her coworkers (well, let's be honest: slaves), but it's portrayed as being funny because she's, well, she's a girl - and girls, I guess, aren't "supposed" to be physically/emotionally abusing. But, for someone like me - who, uh, has a history with this sort of thing - this hit a little too close to home, and made me feel extremely uncomfortable to see it portrayed in such a lighthearted manner. Despite all this, I'm assuming that most people don't really care or aren't as affected by it as I am, so I really recommend the game, so long as you're one of these people. Of course, just be aware that the game does start off rather slowly and that the controls are a little loose. Both are relatively mild concerns, I think, so they're easily outweighed by the game's charm, music, and general enjoyability. Pros:- Charming pixelated graphics and animations- Fitting music- Personable and memorable charactersCons: - Slow pace- Loose controls- That one questionable NPC (to me, at least)

Posted: November 14, 2016
												Even 16-bit-era fans that are experiencing "pixel art fatigue" owe it to themselves to feast their eyes and ears on Owlboy. The art direction and animation are on a whole other level of polish that will remind you of countless games without ever feeling like style for nostalgia's sake, and the feel of the controls hold up masterfully on a gamepad OR mouse and keyboard.There's so many disparate elements coming together that Owlboy SHOULD feel like the gaming equivalent of a high concept album; twin stick shooting, ballistics, grappling, platforming, storytelling, and exploration... The fact that it DOESN'T is a testament to how polished and focused this feels compared to many ambitious indie games.Part of me wishes the mechanics dove deeper and demanded more challening combinations of your abilities, but the length is just about right for a narrative adventure of this scope.I loved Owlboy, and it left me wanting more without wearing thin.

Posted: November 14, 2016
												Got totally wrapped up in this one. Beautiful artwork, charming and memorable characters, fantastic sountrack, responsive and intuitive controls, nice story to unravel around a whimsical world of floating islands and owls. Nice mix of environments to action\platform your way through. Maybe it's more action\adventure as most of the time you are airborne but still a decent amont of platforming. Summoned up lots of Zelda-esque memories for me. Clear inspiration from Kid Icarus, Zelda etc. There is even a NES in the background of the professor's observatory in Vellie! Otus is one of my favourite characters to come out in ages. I did believe there to be 2 or 3 more dungeons left just before I actually beat the game and wished there was but it took me 14 hours (collecting most of the coins) in total at a relaxed pace. Given the price and the high quality finish of this game it gave me more than enough playtime.

Posted: November 11, 2016
												I like this game. Figured I'd put it right up front for people who wanted the synopsis up front. The "Hi-Bit" artsytle brought me back to my childhood of playing snes games but updating the resolution and more frames of animation so the overall effect may be a retro call back but not dated at all. The prologue shocked me, the Main character Otus while mute is quite expressive. Whenever he messes up and is chastized his expressions sadness and shame from the bullying he recieves is frankly pretty sad. I was suprised by the weight that interactions like these that Otus has throughout the game and it gives storytelling layers on top of the standard misfit saves the world story we've played dozens of times before.Graphically I can't express the loving care that went into this, if the artstyle this game uses becomes the next trend sign me up.  Animations are fluid, the interactions between sprite and environment are animated well, and the backdrops are stunning.Gameplay the game isn't 100% linear but exploration to find addtional coins or rares lore items makes for time investment  outside of the main questline. Combat at first is a little repetative but as you you gain companions and discover some of the nuances that aren't distinctly shown to you things become more managable.  There is a heavy emphasis on puzzles with occasional boss fights peppered in to keep the action diverse so you're not doing the same thing for too long.  There are a couple  frustrating areas that i had to take a break and come back later but overall I think the game is well paced.In closing this game was a nice suprise that I hadn't heard about even though i follow the indie market pretty closely for the most part. It is good for about 10-15 hours of fun for an average skilled player. I would reccommend to anyone who likes platformers.

Posted: November 8, 2016
												This is a remarkably well made retro platformer. The music is outstanding. Reminding me of Final Fantasy. The gameplay is really solid with a light metroidvania feel that had me feeling mildly confused about where I was going most of the time. You just fly around, but use the power of your friends to combat and traverse portions of the environment. They're easy to use and control and have clearly defined roles. Problem is that you have little time where you are using all three at once. There are a couple sections that felt out of place like the cannon flight, but they're few and far between. My only other gripe is that the game really gives you zero context for how an enemy is defeated or a section traversed. It's all trial and error. Visuals are peak retro. They use the term hi-bit and I like it for this genre of graphics. I really liked the character animations. Otus's surprised face gave me a giggle every time. Well worth the asking price.

Posted: November 6, 2016
												Okay I love this game. Highly recommended. I've got about 4 hours logged in the game and this is the first game in a long time that I want to continually revist. So here's what I like about the game sprinkled with some opportunities I think the developers might consider:Music - the musical score in this game is absolutely wonderful. It can be delightful, brooding, somber, exciting, uplifting, everything. It's so wonderful, I don't know how else to describe it. I can't really go into depth about it since I'm no audiophile, but lemme say it really greatly adds to the mood and setting of the game at any given point.Graphics - this is a 2D game of course, but as far as 2D games go, this game looks absolutely gorgeous. I will say here that sometimes the environments feel somewhat empty, and the lack of a map or map hotkey makes navigating somewhat difficult but it's not unbearable and never really feels like it's a huge hinderance. I think it may make collecting all the extra stuff a little hard but I think not spoonfeeding stuff to players isn't a HUGE problem. Gameplay - the game is really responsive, I never find myself doing something I didn't want to do, same with the aiming and all. The whole concept of carrying different gunners to do and accomplish different things is really cool and it's a clever gameplay mechanic. The puzzles are pretty fun, not too difficult though, but again, no hand holding here and it's great. Story - I leave this one up to you guys. I really enjoy the story line, I know some of you out there will say it's a tried and true story, done plenty of times before. But that doesn't stop me from really enjoying the story. My only wish is that the game doesn't end quickly. I'm only 4hours into it, I hope theres a lot more of the story left. I'm not going to assign a number value but I'm going to say this game is great. I really love it. I hope the game lasts quite a bit longer, but I'll append this Review when I'm done to give a good idea of how long it takes. Highly recommended, if you need a new story driven game that doesn't hand hold you through every single piece of it, look no further, speak no more.Edit: I finished the game, I have 9 hours logged and I could've finished it a lot faster honestly. I really love this game, the ending is memorable and I look forward to what the creators have next in store. I wish the game was longer though, that's probably my only gripe.

												This is the firast game I have written a review for, and it is for good reason.  I would never have bought this if I hadn't seen it in that one videogamedunkey video.  This is one of my favorite games.  The effort D-Pad Studios put into every pixel of this game is impecable.  And the soundtrack!  It sounds like John williams wrote the music  himself.
