Posted: February 4
												I'll give this game 75%. My worst complaint is about the colour palette. The scenery art exquisite and, during daylight it matches perfectly with the gameplay, at dusk, however, since the main character is brown and the ambience is darker your avatar will somewhat blend with the background, straining your eye.While it is a good game, the controls (gamepad only, particularly DS4) at some point near the end won't work properly if you use the analog directions ( L3 ), if you accidentally move it up to much it will give the same result as pressing jump (X) twice, which will screw you up at that point in the game.Some secrets are poorly connected and will only reward you with lore, which isn't exactly captivating. Some cutscenes and checkpoints could use a little tuning. The last fight isn't hard, but it was fun.

Posted: April 8
												So I didn't want to write a review for Owlboy until I finished it. Because this game does have a story to tell and I wanted my review to make use of that. After 10 hours of gameplay, I have done so! But I'm not a 100%er so there's probably a good amount that I've missed.You can look and see that graphically, it is GORGEOUS. But what you might not know is how fantastic the music is as well. It's all real orchestration. Beautiful, beautiful music.The gameplay. This is what mattered. And after playing it, I can say it was like if you took the flying mechanics of Kirby, mixed that with the level design of a metroidvanie type title and you'd have Owlboy. But there is more to it than that. The ally system is the unique thing that stands out for Owlboy. Otus, the protagonist can pick up his allies and switch between them at will to use their different abilities.The abilities are used for combat and puzzle solving in a delightful way. I loved it.The story has a great twist. And it has a relationship arc between the protagonist and his mentor that really struck a note with me. This game did make me cry.I highly recommend it. It's landed among some of my favorite games of all time.

Posted: February 1
												This platformer feels different from more traditional platformers. Sometimes, this gap from the expected hurts the game. For example, the player is introduced to the capitol city via its ugly bottom—it feels more like a single building than the vast city it means to represent. Later, two different panoramas of the city are shown. Why, then, weren't one of those beautiful backgrounds used to introduce the city?Level design is not intuitive. You'll often loop back around the same level. Swapping from traditional platformer to a sort of stealth mode or a jumping puzzle or a sidescroller or a gauntlet is often jarring, but this spontaneity has its advantages. The unexpected can be exciting and new—some of the puzzles in this game I've never encountered before in any platformer I've done. There's no clear physical progression, which makes the end come rather unexpectedly. New moves are not unlocked as the player plays, and neither does difficulty ramp up over the course of the game (the hardest part, for me, was a boss fight somewhere in the game's middle). The closest a first-time player might come to understanding their in-game progress is probably from looking at the number of trinkets they've collected, of which there are a clear and finite number.Developers clearly had an overarching story in mind, and where that overlaps with the story that is actually told is apparent, because in those cases, the game's story feels impressive and players might feel engaged in it. The story that is actually played through, however, is incredibly confusing, full of false-starts and switchbacks and entirely too much falling action. The story sometimes cops out on explaining how the player gets from one place to another (apparently the snow level is about a minute's walk from the jungle level). Despite not being a traditional platformer, and despite how dearly this game screams to be optimized for user-friendliness, this game is good thanks to its unique feel, its top-quality aesthetics, and its epic ending.This is a good game, if only six hours long.

Posted: November 24, 2016
												Story – Owlboy stars a young protagonist named Otus who, after a series of events, ventures forth into the floating world to protect it from fearsome pirates. While the premise starts out fairly simple, the plot thickens and turns in a way later on that will leave the player engaged. The charming character designs coupled with their unique personalities (some of which also have backstories to discover through dialogue and environmental interaction) also lend to populating the game with interesting and memorable characters. Late in the game, Owlboy’s story will leave the player with a nice mystery behind the lore of the game’s world, which has already left players coming up with theories on how it ties to the current events happening around Otus and friends.Gameplay – Owlboy’s gameplay is unique in which the player will spend most of their time flying above ground while carrying one of three companions you’ll unlock as you progress through the game, each with their own unique way of dealing with enemies and puzzles. It essentially comes down to a gunner to shoot enemies/objects at long range, a shotgunner that deals a lot of damage at short range and can be used to burn obstacles, and a companion that can trap enemies and zip the player around the level to avoid hazards.Unlike most platformers, this game takes a Zelda/Metroid-esque approach where the player explores an open world and will find themselves in dungeon-like areas to progress through the story, rather than progressing right to the next level. Combat in the game primarily consists of the player using the gunner character to shoot at enemies, but sometimes may require timing or melee hits to reveal enemy weaknesses. The first half of the game is relatively easy, with the latter half ramping in difficulty, especially bosses.There are plenty of unlockables, collectibles and hidden achievements in the game, some of which are hidden behind walls and in plain sight. If you’re a perfectionist, this will add a nice chunk of time to the game’s length which is both a good thing and bad thing. Good thing is there’s plenty to collect, like weapon upgrades for your characters, hats, story bits and an upgrade for Otus himself. Bad thing is, while there are a few shortcuts in Owlboy’s world, the lack of fast travel will make getting those last 3 coins you missed in the second dungeon a bit of a pain.Music – Owlboy’s music is wonderfully composed as each piece sets the mood and pace of whatever setting/situation you may find Otus and friends in. The overworld music has a feeling of grandeur while escaping harrowing situations has a tense sense of panic and dread. The soundtrack is definitely many will find themselves listening to while the game itself isn’t playing.Graphics –Owlboy’s graphics are rendered in beautiful pixel art featuring vibrant colors, characteristic animations, night/day cycles and hand crafted environments. Many background graphics are unique in that they rarely share tiles sets and appear as grand set pieces for dungeons, character’s homes, and boss showdowns. Characters are brought to life through expressive poses, subtle sub-pixel animation and character interaction that really leaves the player empathizing with them. This really comes across through Otus, who heavily relies on these animations as he himself can’t speak. Turned eyebrows, cheery smiles and bulging eyes all lend to the character and easily communicate to the player what Otus and other characters are feeling.

Posted: February 2
												If you're looking for a game that is super groundbreaking and a completely new experience, Owlboy is not that game. However, if you're looking for a game that has beautiful pixel graphics, an incredible soundtrack, fun levels, and enjoyable characters, Owlboy meets all of these requirements and how. Owlboy is one of those indie games that is so beautifully crafted that it not only commands a great sense of nostalgia, making you recall the great platformers you played as a kid, but is also precisely executed in a way that you aren't choked by the musk of stereotypical YouTuber that you get from playing most other indie titles. With the great music, the awe-inspiring backdrops, and the very likable characters, Owlboy is one of those games that may not shatter the earth in concept, but is a worthwhile experience nonetheless, very much worth every penny.

												I had an absolute wonderful time with this game. Just an overall high level of craft and vision put into its look, sound, and design. It really shows.Likes-Georgous to experience. Interestingly designed. So well animated.-Story. Well written and I genuinely enjoyed how it played out. Soundtracks is full of catchy, rich, well produced orchestral music.Not so Likes-There were a few times I was ready to skip a combat scenario because I was just more interested in the world and story.-Grab button can feel a little loose.

Posted: February 7
												Owlboy is a beautiful game that feels like the gameplay of a Metroid game (with flight) and the story of a Zelda game where mixed into one masterpeice. The art style is gorgeous, the music is sensational and it is one of the few games that brought a tear to my eye at its conclusion. And as a speedrunner, it is amazing that this game is also fully speed-runable.My only negatives are that Otus (the owl you play as) moves a little too slow, so you have to resort to the dash mechanic most of the time (which lost some of the games immertion for me)  and (spoiler)the ending "boss fight" against the pirate captain didnt make you feel empowered and powerful like at the end of games like Super Metroid did  to make your journey seem worthwhile.Overall this game is great for anyone and well worth the price tag.

Posted: February 1
												A labor of love, in search of greatness - 78/100Owlboy is a neo-retro platforming adventure which aims to recapture the magic of the old 16-bit games we might have played back in the 90s. It was in development for nine years, and while it competes with the very best in some aspects, in others it falters, leaving a game which is good, but not great.Pros:- Beautiful pixel art, some of the best in any game, new or old- Charming soundtrack- Attention to detail in the animations, character/enemy design and other art- Story holds attention, when it is being advanced- Some good boss fights- Collectables, upgrades, and secrets- Heartwarming, non-cynical approach to dialogue and character design and developmentCons:- Mediocre level design: 1. Lots of wasted space 2. Predictable, uninteresting layouts 3. Simplistic puzzles- Combat feels perfunctory: 'shoot and they die', most enemies do not require any special tactics- Controls are not 'tight' on the level of say, Shovel Knight or Ori and the Blind Forest- Story advances slowly in the first 1/2 of the game, mostly predictable during this time- World layout: 1. Sorely needs a map 2. Big, empty, and slow to traverse 3. Not always clear where you're supposed to go- 'Saving the world' story is incongruous with the small handful friendly NPC's you encounter: no sense of the scope of conflict or storyOverall: A diamond in a fair amount of rough. Shovel Knight and Ori and the Blind Forest provide superior platforming experiences. Still fun and worth it however if you are a fan of the art and platformers in general.

The game really left me wanting so much more by capturing my sense of wonder and holding tight to it every step of the way.Its real central weakness is the control schemes. Hitting smaller enemies is a chore, and at too many points you need to be attending to several factors at once while dealing with being a huge target. This is offset by the game being rather forgiving, but I found myself wishing that I hadn't died in the first place, simply because I couldn't get attacks to connect despite seeing enemies coming.This is all more than offset by the incredible writing, look, and sound, but still, a game this stunning made me want to give it the best of myself, and to a degree, it wouldn't let me.

												Absolutely charming, beautiful, and showcases fantastic gameplay mechanics that I haven't seen in many other games. However, without spoiling too much, it suffers from Mass Effect 3 Syndrome. It's also a bit short for the price. If it ever is reduced slightly in price, I would highly recommend that you purchase the game simply for how fresh and original the game is. The start might be a bit slow, true, and the story is a bit iffy, but the vibe of wonder (all thanks to the scenery) combined with the gameplay (who knew that carrying, and sometimes throwing, someone twice your size around while they gun down mobs could be so exhilarating?) makes it a solid game to add to your collection. The ten years truly show, but I just wish that they dedicated maybe another year to fix that ending. With five being average, 8/10. What a HOOT to play.

Posted: January 8
												Owlboy looks and sounds wonderful. From a presentation standpoint it's fantastic.As a game it's... fine. There's a fair bit of variety in the ~8 hour campaign  and enough collecting to do on revisiting areas to give it a bit more time, though it's certainly not a long game either way. The main mechanics all work decently well, though switching between characters with the scroll wheel was janky on occasion. The story is solid though a bit predictable in places. A few loose ends don't get wrapped up very well and it feels like there were some obvious holes to fill. There's also the cannon minigame which is genuinely awful and has a really bad control scheme. But that's completely optional and only needed for 100% completion so ehh, whatever. I did enjoy this game but I also imagine I'm not going to particularly remember it in a year and I don't know if it's worth its asking price - I got it for $20 and that still felt like too much, regardless of how much time was put into making the game it just doesn't justify its price in my opinion, but, oh well. Still a fun enough game, get it on sale for $10-15 and that should be totally fine.

Posted: January 10
												I purchased Owlboy on a whim simply because I liked the look of the visuals, had no idea what to actually expect in terms of gameplay, but in my first sitting I found myself asking the question "Is that a fish wearing a top hat?". Yes. Yes it is.Owlboy was a wonderful experience right from the title menu, the whole thing just looked gorgeous. The character expressions are adorable and incredibly well done, I found script writing mostly ok, though because it's all text based I did have a jarring moment with one character before I understood the speech pattern. I can't deny though I always have a little extra patience for games with such a great art style, but even putting that aside, I found pretty much everything about the game to have a quality feel to it.If Owlboy interests you enough to be reading the reviews, you'll definitely enjoy playing it. Highly recommended.

Posted: December 30, 2016
												Ohhhhhhhohohohohhhh my god.I have a general aversion to sidescrollers made after the SNES era because they usually end up being♥♥♥♥♥♥poor gameplay wise, and try to sell you with pixel graphics (8 bit! wow!). Sometimes the gameplay works but the graphics are ugly. Sometimes the gameplay works but is so insanely broken or difficult you just want to give up within five minutes because it's garbage.Welcome to the game that changed my mind, lads and ladies.Owlboy is, by far, the best game I've played in 2016, and is one of the best games I've ever played. This game is, at heart, a love letter - no, a love novel - written to the Golden Age of sidecrollers. The controls are precise and well thought-out. The art is utterly GORGEOUS, and is likely what pixel-graphics would have become if they had not been succeeded by 3d models. The music and sound design are PHENOMENAL. And that's just from the title screen alone. As I said, I tend to disdain retro-style sidescrollers for various reasons. They usually try too hard to capture the magic of the glory days, and too often fall short. Owlboy does not. This game was in development for a long, long time, and unlike other games I could mention (cough cough No Man's Sky cough cough), this game has turned out beautifully. Since people like pros and cons lists, I'll whip one up here. Cons first.Cons:- The game has a difficulty spike about halfway through. It's sudden, but not totally unexpected as the game practically warns you that it's about to get toooough. I think it could have been balanced out a little better in difficulty, but it's not impossible, and you definitely improve as you go. All enemies can be defeated by playing the game - and by that, you shouldn't have to look up a walkthrough to figure out how to beat an enemy, even after the difficulty spike.- There are a few small gameplay segments that seem poorly timed at first, but this could be largely attributed to my using a controller instead of keyboard/mouse. I found myself trying to press the A button, right trigger, and move both sticks at the same time frequently in the last half of the game.- Rolling to sprint does get annoying after a while, and it does slow down the game unnecessarily.- The story lacks flesh in a few minor places. Some characters inexplicably disappear. - While I'm certain it's a design choice, there are some instances where the framerate on animation seems a bit slowed down. It looks more SNES-y, but it is a bit out of place with the rest of the game. If you know the terms, it's like these portions were animated on 2s instead of 1s. They don't look bad, just noticeably different from the rest of the game.- Possibly low replay value, depending on what one values in a game-F**K THAT MINIGAME. YOU'LL FIND OUT.Pros:- Secrets everywhere. No, like, you're going to have to explore every nook and cranny or look up a guide if you want to 100% Owlboy. The game gives hints but does not point them out blatantly.- Fluid, responsive controls- Interesting puzzles that aren't so dense you can't figure them out- Fairly forgiving respawn system- Gorgeous graphics- Superb Sound Design- Magnificent music- AMAZING ending (no spoilers)- Interesting, sympathetic characters. You'll love them, you'll hate them, you'll remember them. Well, except for the handful that just disappear, apparently.- I mean, this is my GOTY. Seriously. This is the best retro sidescroller, and one of the best games overall, I have ever played - and I've played quite a few. This game did what very few games do - it gave me a story I wanted to see to the end, and the gameplay was fun enough that I didn't want to just go on Youtube and watch a playthrough - I wanted to EXPERIENCE it for myself. It's sorta like Undertale in that it's a story that is definitely best experienced by playing, but instead of just being music and story, it also has amazing art and gameplay. And yet they sell it for so little. This game is worth more than they're asking for, in my opinion. I hope, if a sequel is planned, it can live up to this "mastapeece."9.9/10.

												Highly recommend this game. Went into it looking for a story-driven dual-stick shooter with a lot of story and polish and a complex combat system, and this game delivered on all fronts. The story may leave you in tears at times, and the pixel art is breathtaking. If it were up to me, the combat would be more involved, instead of just having 3 different companions to choose from. However that is not to say that the combat doesn't get difficult; these devs know how to make your heart race in panic and fear as well as push all the right buttons with touching moments. This game has everything and there's no reason not to get it.

Posted: January 10
												I purchased Owlboy on a whim simply because I liked the look of the visuals, had no idea what to actually expect in terms of gameplay, but in my first sitting I found myself asking the question "Is that a fish wearing a top hat?". Yes. Yes it is.Owlboy was a wonderful experience right from the title menu, the whole thing just looked gorgeous. The character expressions are adorable and incredibly well done, I found script writing mostly ok, though because it's all text based I did have a jarring moment with one character before I understood the speech pattern. I can't deny though I always have a little extra patience for games with such a great art style, but even putting that aside, I found pretty much everything about the game to have a quality feel to it.If Owlboy interests you enough to be reading the reviews, you'll definitely enjoy playing it. Highly recommended.

Posted: January 7
												This is the kind of game I've been wanting to play for a long time. Owlboy to me is the best representation of a lost era of video games in between when everything went from pixel to polygon; from 16 to 64. 32 bit games were mostly explored on a 240x160 screen. I know it isn't technically a 32-bit game, but Owlboy and a lot of other PC games like it display to you what could have been if developers had taken things a little slower in the late nineties and early aughts, transitioning from 2D to 3D.Owlboy suffers from linearity, which is forgiveable because you have to take in every last pixel-perfect hand-crafted setting. The fun factor of Owlboy is above standard, so it's not just a masterpiece of visual art. There's a lot of thrills to be had in most of the big battles, especially past the first few.If you've ever tried to draw anything on a computer by hand pixel-by-pixel you will love this game.

Posted: January 8
												Absolutely stellar game with fun gameplay, and an amazing, engaging story that entices you to journey through Otus' world and learn about its history. Truly a work of art with years of effort, love, and care put into it. Highly recommended.

												Lots of heart, very charming. If I had children I would make sure they played this game at some point. Writing, art style, and gameplay are all excellent. Posted: January 15
Product received for free
												I quite thoroughly enjoyed Owlboy. The art is beautiful and the story is engaging. The gameplay isn't revolutionary in any way, but it is still solid and fun to play. I wasn't too sure about this game at first, but I had gotten it as a gift and decided to give it a try. I was surprised to find just how nice a game it was. It starts out a little slow and simple, but as you go forward and get more abilities, the difficulty ramps up to match. The only real negative point I came across was that one setion of the first cave you go to gets blocked off meaning if you haven't gotten all the coins, there goes your completionist run. The tip I can give for that is to be sure to hug the walls and defeat all the enemies you come aross. A chest will appear with the gold once you've defeated everything in some areas.Pros:Engaging storyBeautiful lookGreat soundtrackFun, smooth gameplay that gets better the further you getCons:Takes a bit to really get engrossingOne area you can't get go back to after completion, hurting the completionist runHope this was helpful and I hope you enjoy the game as much as I did

Posted: January 16
												This game is simply put: beautiful. From the orchestral soundtrack punctuating every environment and story beat to the gorgeous display of 'hi-bit' pixel art craftsmanship Owlboy is a feast for the senses. It tells a simple story of an owl boy in his village but manages to infuse that story with surprisingly potent emotional arcs with characters who's motivations can change from fun NPC character in a platformer to a cuttingly real motivation of loss and despair, or shame, or unforgiving anger. The game feels tailormade to me in the sense of its artistry and fun platforming mechanics. It's the kind of game I would love to be a part of in the making. If you're anything like me, or even if you just enjoy solid platformers, then you should definitely pick this game up.

Posted: February 4
												This is the firast game I have written a review for, and it is for good reason.  I would never have bought this if I hadn't seen it in that one videogamedunkey video.  This is one of my favorite games.  The effort D-Pad Studios put into every pixel of this game is impecable.  And the soundtrack!  It sounds like John williams wrote the music  himself.  The amazing visuals and orchestral music blend PERFECTLY together with the environment and art style of this game.  I don't know how they did it, but the developers of this game managed to capture emotions using the lush and vibrant environments and soundtrack.  Personally, my favorite place in the game was Vellie.  The raw amazement I felt when I flew through that beautiful town surpassed (barely) Bioshock: Infinite.  The characters were all so likeable and the bosses!  Rarely does a game come along nowadays with so many bosses, and all of them are unique and later in the game, I thought some were challenging! (I think it's just that I'm bad at video games though lol)  The story had me very interested and I never wanted to put it down!  I think that the cutscenes blended very well with the gameplay, and the transitions were completely seamless throughout the whole game.  I would give this game an 11/10.  So much work was put into this game and you can see it in every pixel.  Thank you D-Pad Studios for letting me buy this masterpiece.

												Take the moment in Chrono Trigger when you make it to Magus's castle for the first time, and the screen pans up to show you in amazing detail all of the castle. Posted: February 4
												I'll give this game 75%. My worst complaint is about the colour palette. The scenery art exquisite and, during daylight it matches perfectly with the gameplay, at dusk, however, since the main character is brown and the ambience is darker your avatar will somewhat blend with the background, straining your eye.While it is a good game, the controls (gamepad only, particularly DS4) at some point near the end won't work properly if you use the analog directions ( L3 ), if you accidentally move it up to much it will give the same result as pressing jump (X) twice, which will screw you up at that point in the game.Some secrets are poorly connected and will only reward you with lore, which isn't exactly captivating. Some cutscenes and checkpoints could use a little tuning. The last fight isn't hard, but it was fun.

Posted: April 8
												So I didn't want to write a review for Owlboy until I finished it. Because this game does have a story to tell and I wanted my review to make use of that. After 10 hours of gameplay, I have done so! But I'm not a 100%er so there's probably a good amount that I've missed.You can look and see that graphically, it is GORGEOUS. But what you might not know is how fantastic the music is as well. It's all real orchestration. Beautiful, beautiful music.The gameplay. This is what mattered. And after playing it, I can say it was like if you took the flying mechanics of Kirby, mixed that with the level design of a metroidvanie type title and you'd have Owlboy. But there is more to it than that. The ally system is the unique thing that stands out for Owlboy. Otus, the protagonist can pick up his allies and switch between them at will to use their different abilities.The abilities are used for combat and puzzle solving in a delightful way. I loved it.The story has a great twist. And it has a relationship arc between the protagonist and his mentor that really struck a note with me. This game did make me cry.I highly recommend it. It's landed among some of my favorite games of all time.

Posted: February 6
												Really good game. Does everything a good game should. Great music, great story, great characters. I love the hi bit pixel art style. Gameplay is fun. It shares that wonderful retro style but still remains utterly unique. But unfortunatly I have one major problem that almost made me stop playing.Owlboy will mixup the rules and puzles for each level. Its done really well and helps keep the gameplay interesting, but also means that with each new challenge you're thrown into the deep end. I died a LOT of times because the game would give no explenation to what I was supposed to do, or it would be way too hard right off the bat. In my first playthrough, I died somewhere around 100 times. Most of those deaths felt like they not my fault. I would enter an area and then be killed before I could understand what was happening. I spent around a third of the game being frusterated and wanting to quit. The only reason I kept playing is that the game is really forgiving with death. Almost every room is a checkpoint. But most levels only do this a few times then remain fun. All in all, I had fun with the game.♥♥♥♥ pirate levels.

Posted: January 17
												Wow, just wow. This game is amazing. It has really been a while since I played areally good 2D game likte this one. I just got into PC gaming not that long ago, and this was the first game I had in mind. I must say, this game is really worth playing. I currently have about 6hrs into the game, and I have loved every single minute of it. This game has a very solid story that will get you hooked on quite fast, the mechanics of the game and overall controls are amazing and very responsive, the soundtrack is just very pleasing to listen, and the characters themselves are very likeable. As you play this game, you will be immersed in the story and will grow fond of the characters. It is also really cool to see the main character, Otus, growth as the game progresses. Overall, I have really enjoyed this game and will continue to enjoy it. If you are looking for a good 2D/Adventure game with a good story, this is the game for you. Honestly, they even made sort of like an open world place, so they give the ability to explore quite a lot. I highly recommend this game!! :D

Posted: January 27
												This is one of the best games I have ever played. As you all most likely know it took around nine years to develop and in my eyes it was worth it. Everything about this game is amazing, the graphics (some of the best pixel art I have ever seen), the music, the story, the gameplay. The game was a joy from start to finish, but the ending might have been the best part. Im not going to spoil anything, but I was a little teary-eyed. It has some very unique puzzles and gameplay mechanics. It also has a very interesting story and unlike many other games, I actually cared about the story and lore. It has a wonderful cast of characters and areas to explore. It may not be the biggest or longest games, but it is certainly worth it. Best of all though, is how Otus grows throughout the game.

Posted: January 15
												I'm not a big fan of pixelated graphics. I grew up playing Atari and Nintendo and the whole style seems silly and indulgent, given all the beautiful things GPUs can do now. That said, this game is beautiful and brings me back to those Nintendo days with games like Kid Icarus and Metroid, but with HUGE graphical improvements. The gameplay? Amazing! Posted: December 29, 2016
												This game is amazing in almost every aspect. The music, aesthetics, gameplay, soundeffects, characters and so forth. Everything is neatly tied together and has formed this amazing experience called Owlboy. Even if the game felt a bit short, I can't help but feel satisfied with the game in the end. Owlboy was a huge enjoyment for me, the controls were tight and felt amazing to play around with and the level design completmented the overall gameplay very well. Furthermore, the music and art for this game was jawdropping, it added so much character to the game and so much charm and (to me atleast) the artstyle feels unique and stands out from other pixelart games, as this feels like a mix between old and new. Thus all locations and characters are memorable and loveable. Not only does the game offer something pleasant to look at, but the story was quite good as well. Owlboy had interesting characters with nice and somewhat unexpected twists, although nothing to write home about. To fully understand what I am talking about one has to experience Owlboy themselves.The only thing I can see people complain about is that the game can be a bit pricey. 22,99€ is quite a lot of money for a ~6 hour long game, however Owlboy brings an innovative prespective of the platforming genre and the whole experience is truly magnificent. When I finished the game, I thought to myself "Well, this was a bit short. Was it really worth all the money?". At the same moment I asked myself that I noticed how dumb that question was, as I already know the answer.Yes, it was worth every penny. If you think you might enjoy this game, I'd suggest you purchase it right away as it is one of the most unique Indie experiences I've had in a long time. Pros:+ Art and Music = Jawdropping+ Gameplay felt good, smooth and natural+ Good level design+ Likeable charactersCons:- Can be a tad bit priceyHope you found my thoughts helpful even though I didn't cover every aspect of the game!

Posted: February 2
												If you're looking for a game that is super groundbreaking and a completely new experience, Owlboy is not that game. However, if you're looking for a game that has beautiful pixel graphics, an incredible soundtrack, fun levels, and enjoyable characters, Owlboy meets all of these requirements and how. Owlboy is one of those indie games that is so beautifully crafted that it not only commands a great sense of nostalgia, making you recall the great platformers you played as a kid, but is also precisely executed in a way that you aren't choked by the musk of stereotypical YouTuber that you get from playing most other indie titles. With the great music, the awe-inspiring backdrops, and the very likable characters, Owlboy is one of those games that may not shatter the earth in concept, but is a worthwhile experience nonetheless, very much worth every penny.

Posted: February 5
												Even though I like this game a lot, I have some major issues with it. The story is great and the pixelart is absolutely outstanding and the music too, but the gameplay however is average at best.One of the main features in this game is collectables and that makes up most of the things I hate about this game (They're probably minor details for most people). This game desperately needs a MAP and a WARPING-ABILTY.Each section (dungeon) of the game feels a bit like a chore to get through and they are a bit too long and some of them are really hard to navigate through, so it does not really help that the lack of backtracking-friendliness is so severe. Once you're in a dungeon you CAN'T get out without going through the entire dungeon unless you just go out the way you came from.I don't feel like it's important to address why the story, music and graphics are good, you'll just have to experience that yourself and the same goes for the gameplay mechanics (which are not bad in any way, just not at the same standard as the graphics.Also the boss battles are awesome. They're al cool and different from each other, but some are just really ♥♥♥♥ing cool.Overall I had a pleasent ride through this game even though there are aspects that really grinds my gears. I give this game a good 8/10

Posted: February 7
												Owlboy is a beautiful game that feels like the gameplay of a Metroid game (with flight) and the story of a Zelda game where mixed into one masterpeice. The art style is gorgeous, the music is sensational and it is one of the few games that brought a tear to my eye at its conclusion. And as a speedrunner, it is amazing that this game is also fully speed-runable.My only negatives are that Otus (the owl you play as) moves a little too slow, so you have to resort to the dash mechanic most of the time (which lost some of the games immertion for me)  and (spoiler)the ending "boss fight" against the pirate captain didnt make you feel empowered and powerful like at the end of games like Super Metroid did  to make your journey seem worthwhile.Overall this game is great for anyone and well worth the price tag.

Posted: February 1
												A labor of love, in search of greatness - 78/100Owlboy is a neo-retro platforming adventure which aims to recapture the magic of the old 16-bit games we might have played back in the 90s. It was in development for nine years, and while it competes with the very best in some aspects, in others it falters, leaving a game which is good, but not great.Pros:- Beautiful pixel art, some of the best in any game, new or old- Charming soundtrack- Attention to detail in the animations, character/enemy design and other art- Story holds attention, when it is being advanced- Some good boss fights- Collectables, upgrades, and secrets- Heartwarming, non-cynical approach to dialogue and character design and developmentCons:- Mediocre level design: 1. Lots of wasted space 2. Predictable, uninteresting layouts 3. Simplistic puzzles- Combat feels perfunctory: 'shoot and they die', most enemies do not require any special tactics- Controls are not 'tight' on the level of say, Shovel Knight or Ori and the Blind Forest- Story advances slowly in the first 1/2 of the game, mostly predictable during this time- World layout: 1. Sorely needs a map 2. Big, empty, and slow to traverse 3. Not always clear where you're supposed to go- 'Saving the world' story is incongruous with the small handful friendly NPC's you encounter: no sense of the scope of conflict or storyOverall: A diamond in a fair amount of rough. Shovel Knight and Ori and the Blind Forest provide superior platforming experiences. Still fun and worth it however if you are a fan of the art and platformers in general.

Posted: February 4
												I finally took the time to see what Owlboy gave to me as a player, and it gave me more than I expected.This game is really an amazing story, you are involved with the world, the story is good, the interactions with the NPC´S feel like they're different from each other, obviously, but those details give life to a game.The gameplay is fantastic, the controls are responsive, there are not a lot of glitches or bugs (in my playthrough).And also the art style is what brings life to this types of game, it's so coloful and detailed and very astonishing.So I can safely say that this is great game.

Posted: April 8
												So I didn't want to write a review for Owlboy until I finished it. Because this game does have a story to tell and I wanted my review to make use of that. After 10 hours of gameplay, I have done so! But I'm not a 100%er so there's probably a good amount that I've missed.You can look and see that graphically, it is GORGEOUS. But what you might not know is how fantastic the music is as well. It's all real orchestration. Beautiful, beautiful music.The gameplay. This is what mattered. And after playing it, I can say it was like if you took the flying mechanics of Kirby, mixed that with the level design of a metroidvanie type title and you'd have Owlboy. But there is more to it than that. The ally system is the unique thing that stands out for Owlboy. Otus, the protagonist can pick up his allies and switch between them at will to use their different abilities.The abilities are used for combat and puzzle solving in a delightful way. I loved it.The story has a great twist. And it has a relationship arc between the protagonist and his mentor that really struck a note with me. This game did make me cry.I highly recommend it. It's landed among some of my favorite games of all time.

Posted: February 4
												You'll read it alot, but when I say the art and compositions for Owlboy are phenomenal, I truly mean it. This is a wonderful game, and if you enjoy an in depth 2-D sidescroller, this is the game for you. The characters tange from likeable to lovable, yet some at times feel like they weren't as fleshed out as they were set up to be. The gameplay has an enjoyable base, and the puzzles are fun yet it is rare to feel challenged. I spent probably ~10 hours on the game, and thourghly enjoyed it, but wished it had just a BIT more story. I did play wishing it wouldn't end.It is not perfect, but I still enjoyed it for the story it told and would definitely recommend to anyone who truly wants to sit down and play a beautifil game. Hope you like it as well!

Posted: February 2
												If you're looking for a game that is super groundbreaking and a completely new experience, Owlboy is not that game. However, if you're looking for a game that has beautiful pixel graphics, an incredible soundtrack, fun levels, and enjoyable characters, Owlboy meets all of these requirements and how. Owlboy is one of those indie games that is so beautifully crafted that it not only commands a great sense of nostalgia, making you recall the great platformers you played as a kid, but is also precisely executed in a way that you aren't choked by the musk of stereotypical YouTuber that you get from playing most other indie titles. With the great music, the awe-inspiring backdrops, and the very likable characters, Owlboy is one of those games that may not shatter the earth in concept, but is a worthwhile experience nonetheless, very much worth every penny.

Posted: February 2
												This game is an instant classic!- Great music- Great story- Great gameplay- Character building- Fantastic ArtIt worths each penny, and it clearly shows why devs took 9 years to complete it. It's simply a masterpiece!

Posted: February 4
												This is the firast game I have written a review for, and it is for good reason.  I would never have bought this if I hadn't seen it in that one videogamedunkey video.  This is one of my favorite games.  The effort D-Pad Studios put into every pixel of this game is impecable.  And the soundtrack!  It sounds like John williams wrote the music  himself.  The amazing visuals and orchestral music blend PERFECTLY together with the environment and art style of this game.  I don't know how they did it, but the developers of this game managed to capture emotions using the lush and vibrant environments and soundtrack.  Personally, my favorite place in the game was Vellie.  The raw amazement I felt when I flew through that beautiful town surpassed (barely) Bioshock: Infinite.  The characters were all so likeable and the bosses!  Rarely does a game come along nowadays with so many bosses, and all of them are unique and later in the game, I thought some were challenging! (I think it's just that I'm bad at video games though lol)  The story had me very interested and I never wanted to put it down!  I think that the cutscenes blended very well with the gameplay, and the transitions were completely seamless throughout the whole game.  I would give this game an 11/10.  So much work was put into this game and you can see it in every pixel.  Thank you D-Pad Studios for letting me buy this masterpiece.

Posted: February 5
												Even though I like this game a lot, I have some major issues with it. The story is great and the pixelart is absolutely outstanding and the music too, but the gameplay however is average at best.One of the main features in this game is collectables and that makes up most of the things I hate about this game (They're probably minor details for most people). This game desperately needs a MAP and a WARPING-ABILTY.Each section (dungeon) of the game feels a bit like a chore to get through and they are a bit too long and some of them are really hard to navigate through, so it does not really help that the lack of backtracking-friendliness is so severe. Once you're in a dungeon you CAN'T get out without going through the entire dungeon unless you just go out the way you came from.I don't feel like it's important to address why the story, music and graphics are good, you'll just have to experience that yourself and the same goes for the gameplay mechanics (which are not bad in any way, just not at the same standard as the graphics.Also the boss battles are awesome. They're al cool and different from each other, but some are just really ♥♥♥♥ing cool.Overall I had a pleasent ride through this game even though there are aspects that really grinds my gears. I give this game a good 8/10

Posted: February 6
												Really good game. Does everything a good game should. Great music, great story, great characters. I love the hi bit pixel art style. Gameplay is fun. It shares that wonderful retro style but still remains utterly unique. But unfortunatly I have one major problem that almost made me stop playing.Owlboy will mixup the rules and puzles for each level. Its done really well and helps keep the gameplay interesting, but also means that with each new challenge you're thrown into the deep end. I died a LOT of times because the game would give no explenation to what I was supposed to do, or it would be way too hard right off the bat. In my first playthrough, I died somewhere around 100 times. Most of those deaths felt like they not my fault. I would enter an area and then be killed before I could understand what was happening. I spent around a third of the game being frusterated and wanting to quit. The only reason I kept playing is that the game is really forgiving with death. Almost every room is a checkpoint. But most levels only do this a few times then remain fun. All in all, I had fun with the game.♥♥♥♥ pirate levels.

Posted: January 29
This game is utterly unplayable on widows 10 muti monitor. It is not a multi-monitor/ Win 10 issue. I have been extremely excited about this game, but it does not have any support options for multple motitors. I think it is a georgeous game, but it will not lauch in any format other than 720p windowed mode. I am severly upset that a game with so much promise was not made to work on either my windows 10 2 mntor system or my linux box in any serviceable fasion. It is a game that is gorgeous with an amazing sound track that is utterly unplayable on any system that was not designed by the developers. I have never been so let down by a game simply becase of its lack of graphical support. I hope that the devs can sort out these issues, but unless I can get more more than 10 mins into the game without total failure, this is a hard pass.edit: I got the game running great on my Linux box. I still can't get it running fullscreen on my windows machine, and I have no idea what the conflict is. After spending some time actually playing it I can say this is an excelent 2D platform adventure game, at least for its first few hows. The soundtrack, visual style, animation are incredible. Game play is fluid and chalenging without ever feeling overly dificult. I look foreward to completing this game in the next week or two.
